After trying the abysmal Broken Arrow multiplayer test recently, I thought I'd give ol' WARGAME Red Dragon another try after years of updates. I now understand why people are so excited for Broken Arrow, even with how awful the multiplayer test version was (everything from netcode to balance was terrible, but the core gameplay elements and UI are so so much better than WARGAME's imo).

This game practically goes out of its' way to keep the game's mechanics murky and nonsensical, and if most RTS games have a joke of a tutorial, this one has a joke-of-a-joke of a tutorial (oh boy, PowerPoint slides that take up only 1/3 of the screen, what a fun and engaging way to learn the game...). Combine that with unsatisfying, slow gameplay, minimal effects, and a UI that you have to squint to use properly on ultrawide monitors, and it's a recipe for boredom honestly. Various units will seemingly at-random win or lose battles, which probably has to do with the ~50% average accuracy rating across the majority of units. Combat is a literal coin toss for most units, assuming all things are equal...
While Broken Arrow's multiplayer test was a disaster as far as balance and netcode goes, at least the better unit won in a 1v1 the vast majority of the time. In WARGAME, meanwhile, I've had dirt-cheap ATGM carriers outperform dedicated high-level MBTs in vehicular engagements across similar distances and under similar circumstances, even though the tutorial says something about HEAT ammo only doing 1 damage max against vehicles if it penetrates. This means that MBTs with the best AP ammo should be far-far outperforming the slower-firing, less-damaging 1-2 ATGM carriers that I have sitting in a bush somewhere on the map, even if they have the element of surprise etc. on their side.

This is before going into other elements of the game; all losses are permanent/you have no recursion options in a long match, R&R is literally as barebones as it gets, I'm not even sure if the game has hotkeys and if it does, they're not referenced in the in-game UI nor are they reasonably placed, you have no control over smoke launchers on vehicles as far as I can tell, infantry is really clunky to use, LoS cones/ranges aren't shown in any meaningful way in-game, you have to use 'muh command unit' to cap objectives (since when are the grunts not the ones taking territory in war, can someone explain that to me? lmao ok Eugen), bait-and-switch SEAD missions can't really be set up correctly, ships weren't very well-integrated and absolutely destroy everything unless hard-countered, etc.

I think I gave this game a fair try, I played with the deck system and skirmished against the AI but the game never really explained itself through gameplay or UI as I experimented with different things. I tried one of the campaigns but gave up after quickly realizing how clunky the meta-map controls were, I couldn't even arrange for an infantry brigade/company/whatever to attack a tile alongside a tank company that was supposed to lead the charge, even though both groups had the movement capacity to do so. This game is almost 10 years old yet it reminds me of an early access RTS as far as the UI and gameplay goes, which has been deeply frustrating and disappointing. At this point I cannot recommend anything made by Eugen Systems, they've done nothing but disappoint me since R.U.S.E. and I'm surprised that WARGAME has gained such a following in all honesty.

I've never seen a RTS game try so little to explain what's going on at any given moment yet have so many positive reviews, this is surreal, and I wish I could appreciate whatever it is that I'm missing out on that makes the game so great, because I'm not seeing it and I cannot recommend this game.

Got frustrated with how bad the Ai was in skirmish, so I decided to test out some decks and see what it does.

[h3]SUPPORT DECK:[/h3] Deck only has logi trucks, artillery, mortars and AA vehicles. Start of match it bought majority logi trucks, then artillery and anti-air here and there. Logi trucks stayed mostly at spawn for whole match. Artillery would run out of gas and ammo. Never get any resupply.

[h3]AIRFORCE DECK:[/h3] Deck had noncombat commander and the rest planes. Spawned just the commanders and charged them against the enemy to then get taken out. It did nothing after that. Not one plane was called in. The enemy however did call in about a dozen bombers for my lone commander.

[h3]AIRBORNE DECK:[/h3] Deck was only helicopter infantry and Stallion logi. It never called in any of the Super Stallions. It did however call in swarms of heli infantry to charge the enemies AA and never unloaded.

[h3]ARMOR DECK:[/h3] Deck was mostly armored with focus on ground vehicles. It had more logi trucks and helicopters than I can count. Vehicles would charge the enemy with no thought until they ran out of gas. Even with no ammo, they would still move forward until they ran out of gas. Not one of the logies resupplied.

I think it’s safe to say there’s no need to continue on testing. The Ai is a zombie swarm that does nothing at all. To call it an Ai would be a disservice to Koopas in Super Mario Bros FROM THE EIGHTIES! It clear, in 2024 as of today, no thought at all was put into the Ai into doing anything tangible. Not even an IF STATEMENT as a conditional for when a vehicle runs out of gas to refuel it with a logi. This is seriously embarrassing. Wargame Red Dragon released in 2014 and the task of adding an OUT OF GAS conditional has yet to be implemented into the game. WARNO and any other future products are a MASSIVE steer clear.

Although somewhat dated, I think this is still the gold standard modern warfare milsim-ish RTS. 

There's a huge variety of units, nations, and maps. The range and effectiveness of units is intended to imitate reality as much as possible. Units like artillery, aircraft, and main battle tanks are incredibly lethal. Concealment and scouting are very important. This makes ambushes rewarding and effective, but avoiding them can also be tedious. The result is an RTS that plays very differently than most others (in both good and bad ways). 

Determining which units can defeat what, how far different units can see or fire, and exactly how aircraft and anti aircraft should be deployed can be a frustrating exercise in trial and error, but it's also satisfying when it all comes together.

If you like this game as well as WWII, then Steel Division 2 is a little more polished.

Great improvement on the last game. Supply being more plentiful based on what faction you are playing would be interesting. AI needs a lot of micro which is challenging, but I wish they were smarter about missile firing, etc.

I have played this game for almost 400 hours and I can confidently say that this game is a complete failure and has nothing to do with the real characteristics of the equipment.
I don't know from what sources the developers took information about Soviet equipment, especially the AKULA helicopter. 
I think that the developers need to become a little more erudite in this topic and watch a lot of YouTube videos where, for example, the famous and invincible Russian-Soviet tanks (according to the developers of this game) defeat ordinary Bradley infantry fighting vehicles.

I've seen more than a hundred of the same comments and reviews, so I hope that the developers will not just pay attention to this, but start doing something about it.
And don't offer me to buy WARNO, because it has the same problems, maybe when the developers stop masturbating to the Soviet Union, everything will fall into place and then everything will be fine.

This was my entry-level foray into this genre. I did a bit of research before my purchase and went with WG Red Dragon. Thus far, I have not been disappointed. The game has a steep learning curve (for me anyway...being new to the genre). The game allows for micro-mgmt of individual/small group units. There is also a multi-command option for most units that I'm still learning to perfect. The beauty of this game though reveals itself by REQUIRING the use of a combined-arms force to win. This game will not allow one to 'spam' up on tanks and roll into the contested map grids to win...Lol...that's an easy win for the solo game AI...you will be vsf before you know it! As of now, my 46 hrs of gameplay have been limited to single-player "solo" skirmishes. The game has several campaign scenarios. However, due to the learning curve, it's best to start at the skirmishes first. The campaign scenarios begin as a turn-based dynamic style board game, but the battles are fought RTS. During my prior game research, I viewed the T-B approach to be a turnoff; the few times I've tinkered with the campaign portion of the game, the blend of the two game styles has surprisingly been to my liking.

If you know nothing of combined-arms warfare, you will die quickly. It's that simple. Luckily, there are several 'player guides' posted by those in the Steam WG RD community pages to help the novice player (the 2000's term is 'noob' ....I believe). Use them. The game offers a multi-player aspect. However, I purchased this particular game as a single-player escape. My understanding is that the online MP community is quite competitive....

In short, if you like combined arms warfare, you will enjoy this game. It will require a learning curve, if you're new to the genre, but the satisfaction of torching the competent AI is worth it. There are two basic ways to win the game, one is by points or total destruction. I enjoy the latter because...well...stemming back to my Corps days, I like total annihilation of the enemy. The game offers a time limit or no limit when playing by points or annihilation. If playing without a time limit, a skirmish game may take a couple hours (or more depending upon your settings) to finish. Run the tutorials and check out the player guides to understand the settings...there are many and they can be complex.

The game has plenty of depth and the AI difficulty can be adjusted...I've found it to be quite competitive. Enjoy!  SF

If, like me, you're of a certain age and your childhood was lived in a pre-home computer world - you would once have owned scale plastic soldiers and tanks, built model kits and played for hours using actual physical toys not digital facsimiles. Choosing who was fighting who, setting them all up on a battlefield that sprawled across the front room carpet before letting all Hell loose (and occasionally removing said soldiers from our pet dog's mouth) filled many rainy afternoons. The Red Dragon experience gives me the same feeling and satisfaction. It's like the greatest war chest of toy soldiers I have ever owned.

Before we start, I'm writing this for a specific niche of player, a curious beast seldom seen, cautious and wary of change, only seeking gaming pleasure in solitude. Yes, I'm writing a review dedicated to those offline, single player types and I make no apology for it.

This is the 3rd game of the franchise, and I've put a few hours into the previous ones, but this one seems to hold my attention as it gives me a host of options that allow me to play the game as I want it at the pace and difficulty I prefer (slow and easy - like my good self). More on this later.

As you probably know, Wargame: Red Dragon is a modern battle simulator set in Asia and allows you to create as many alternative history battles as your heart could wish for. With units ranging in date from the 1960's to late 90's, there's an impressive amount of hardware for you to get your virtual paws on. I'd say you're looking at well over 1500 units of all shapes and sizes, this game also includes naval elements (I'll get to that later).

In terms of countries, you've got a broad range of BLUFOR representation; US, UK, France, Germany and the REDFOR line-ups present you with some new faces such as China, North Korea and (as was) Czechoslovakia. Another awesome addition is the paid DLC which brings in Israel and a very under-represented nation - South Africa. There are a total 8 DLC packages, 4 of the free.

One facet of the game that enthrals me for hours is the ability to create your own decks. This allows you to mix and match units from any country (of the same side only - you can't blend Red and Blufor) but the scope within this is about limitless. You can restrict a deck to a specific country of course, or by certain date parameters or equally by unit type (mechanized. armoured) - these factors will offer greater rewards but will also obviously make for restrictions. The whole game balances these factors perfectly. Look at any unit and you'll find yourself weighing up speed versus armour, hit power against defence, experience versus quantity. 


Gameplay
After I've got a new deck, then it's time to try it out. My favourite option is Solo / Skirmish mode. Choose a deck, choose your opponent, chose your map, choose how long you want to fight and what the victory conditions are - then it's go-time! Personally, gaming should not be a stress-inducing adrenalin rush that pushes my blood pressure up and causes me to have teen-like computer rage. I set my opponents on Easy. I'm not ashamed to say this because I genuinely believe there are others out there that enjoy the distraction of gaming, without it causing them to step nearer to meeting their maker. Maybe it's an age thing. The BEST feature the guys at Eugen have added is the ability to control the speed of the game. Instead of my heart fluttering and having to spend time racing around the large map wildly clicking on every unfolding shitshow, I can now take my time. 

Side battles and tactical encounters can be savoured. I enjoy watching each of these vignettes, they capture the feel of battle perfectly and you can really see the loving detail that has gone into the games' development. As I write this, I'm reminded of a scene where I could observe a pair of Chieftain Mk.2 tanks manoeuvre across a wreckage strewn bridge, and they did so perfectly, steering round the flaming wrecks. Whilst this is one tiny snapshot of the hours I've spent, there are countless moments like this in every game. 

One aspect of the game that I really enjoy is how you have to adopt real life tactics. It's not the type of game whereby you can just spam the enemy with every tank you've got and they'll finally succumb to your firepower. Attacks need to be thought out, using balanced forces. Sending a column of tanks into battle without any air defence is going to get them in trouble - just as it would in real life. Understanding the relative strengths and weaknesses is key, as is knowing which units support each other. 

Red Dragon also has a series of campaigns too. I'm at the early stages of this and still finding my feet with it, which is code for "still getting my a$$ kicked". Varied challenges using a lot of units you'd probably never choose. All with a far east slant. 

I'm going to mention the Naval element. He's my take on it, it's not of any great depth (haha), shallow BUT does add a great twist by having enemy forces that can now attack from sea. The coastal/river encounters are much better than the all out sea battles but if you're expecting a "Harpoon" level of complexity, then this isn't the one. It's a nice sideshow, but I find I don't dabble with fishes too often.

OK man, you love this game, tell me what you would change? Aside from the naval section, I'm gutted that there aren't a couple of European maps. There's such a high representation of these nations, it would be great to see East and West Germany slogging it out without a backdrop of paddy fields and Asian inspired architecture. Sadly, there's no mod tools to allow this, and I think the devs have moved on to their next endeavour, so this isn't likely to happen. 

I've hardly broke the surface of this fine game but if you're looking for a modern, military RTS, that has a great level of detail, then I'd suggest you give this a chance.

A game that, while promising, offers zero good incentive to play it. If you don't like the insane micro of Starcraft 2 combined with some of the most exploitable mechanics ever seen in an RTS/RTT game, this isn't for you. Which isn't to say it's a bad game per se, it's just not (imo) a very fun one. Exploits like arty spam, helo spam, and tank spam make the game nauseating to try and play. Speaking of nauseating, I hope you don't like good hotkeys, because this game has none to speak of. Just in general. No hotkeys in an RTS game? AoE2 had this figured out TWENTY FOUR YEARS AGO. The amount of stuff missing from this game is heartbreaking, because honestly, this should have kept getting updates as opposed to WARNO, the absolutely terrible sequel that's also unfinished. 

My biggest gripe though? There's zero singleplayer content, so if you, like me, bought the game expecting a full game (again, AoE had this 24 years ago now.), Eugen wants you to know you can go fuck yourself or buy WARNO; another Eugen game with zero singleplayer content that will be getting some "soon" (as of two years ago). 

Save your money, go buy Steel Division 2, it's the only Eugen game that's even remotely playable. Even then, I would highly suggest avoiding Eugen as a developer. Their consistent history of not delivering is, for someone who's put hundreds of hours into their games, telling.

They keep mods on the forums to ban people, but do not support the game nor even censor the chat from horrendous abuses. While I would be entirely okay with the idea of non-censorship, the idea that it's only used to retaliate against people with dissenting opinions is telltale sign of rot, of which Eugen has much.

Yes! This is highly recommended for modern RTS fans where the focus is on more realistic combined arms combat compared to base building and spam rushing your opponent and who ever clicks faster wins. It offers a huge variety of units, strategies and ways to play the game. While often their is a few dominant metas - it is always possible to find different ways to overcome them and depending on your preferred play style.

Wargame chat is a meme on it's own and it can sometimes take a while to get a game. The community while smaller these days, still provides heaps of help learning or getting updated with unit balance changes and the current meta as well as the ability to arrange balanced games and work together as a team. 

The Wargame franchise really is a new standard for RTS games, just be aware that it can take a while to get a handle of the game mechanics - it can be punishing at first and have a steep learning curve, especially in multiplayer.  I really recommend this for anyone who is interested in a modern RTS.  No need to worry about base building, the game is purely about combined arms combat and controlling the battlefield. My only bugbear is that the AI could use a lot of work to really improve the single player experience (or and it can cheat haha)

Hoping for Wargame 4 - if they add modding tools, adjustable loadouts, workshop support, a map and campaign editor it could be the best modern RTS ever. The South African DLC (2021) was a much welcomed late content edition.

It's the ARMA of RTS games.  Don't bother with WARNO.  I haven't played it, but Red Dragon is superior to WARNO because you can have the unmitigated joy of concocting the craziest deck imaginable.  The deck builder is a good chunk of the fun in this game, and they restricted your possibilities in WARNO.  Yes, some units are more effective than their point value should indicate, but flexible deck-builder enables anyone to access those same OP units.

There is a lack of urban-heavy maps.  Also, every single map uses an East Asian tileset.  For a game that includes such a broad and historically accurate array of equipment, I'm surprised at the stark lack of map variety.  Both the appearance and "feel" of the maps in this game feel fairly homogeneous.  Some maps are arid mediterranean-ish and are light on trees, and a few have a fair bit of elevation, but overall they're just kinda same-y.

Wargame: Red Dragon impressively captures the essence of strategic warfare in an alternate Cold War setting, delivering a deeply engaging RTS experience. With 815 hours of gameplay, my appreciation for its complex and nuanced approach to military tactics has only grown.

The game's strength lies in its vast and varied arsenal, allowing for intricate planning and execution of diverse strategies. Each unit type, from ground to naval forces, is crafted with attention to detail, reflecting real-world military capabilities of the era. This variety enables a highly dynamic gameplay experience, where adaptability and strategic foresight are key.

However, the game is not without its flaws. Multiplayer sessions can be marred by technical issues like desynchronization, which can detract from the otherwise immersive experience. Additionally, the representation and balance of some nations feel less polished, impacting the overall strategic depth. The AI, while competent, does not fully capture the unpredictability of human opponents, leading to a more predictable challenge in single-player scenarios.

In summary, Wargame: Red Dragon stands out for its comprehensive and realistic approach to strategy gaming, offering a challenging and rewarding experience for RTS enthusiasts. Despite its minor drawbacks, it remains a highly recommended title for those seeking a deep and authentic military strategy game.

I do love the air combat though and some of the infantry expansions are great. I prefer the slower pace over the later Steel Division series. Its good, grab it on discount though because of its age.

Trying to take a much more modernized redux on the old turn-based strategy game "People's General" from SSI in 1998; this RTS just sadly falls flat despite good visuals. If you're new to this series, you'll have a very hard time trying to figure out what to do since there's no official tutorial system in the game aside from reading large paragraphs of "what to do" in-game, and that's it. Nothing more, nothing less. It won't show you how the game works or offer any idea to somebody wanting to try this. Campaign's are too difficult due to false difficulties that even going against a "Normal" AI will seem like you're going against a "Hard" or "Very Hard" opponent. Then once in-game, if you were looking for a great actiony styled RTS where you can see the carnage and explosions from units moving about like what you saw in the trailers for this game, well you're not gonna get that. It's impossible to see any of the units in-game due to how you have to keep track of EVERY detail of EVERY unit as you zoom back to the moon in order to see what you need to command and manage. Granted this is a nice feature which is rare to find in many games. But overall having to babysit so many units across big maps give you zero chances to actually see your units or look cloesly at the battle. It is the equivelant of playing "Axis and Allies" the board game in real time with boxes moving about the screen to tell you the name of units. This is sad since the detail that was put into these units is quite impressive, especially when you have 15+ nations to choose and assort with. As for the menu system, good luck trying to find and set up a game with a friend. As for the menu side of things, you are REQUIRED to make an account for this game due to it being a 3rd party company. Yes this is a small annoyance, but then trying to add your friend after setting up these accounts is frustrating since the adding buttons don't work unless you open them in a specific way.  I enjoy most RTS's, like Command and Conquer, Total War, and others, but this one doesn't do it right with all these small problems. It was a nice try, but sometimes the most basic things of playing an RTS need to be shown better.,

Wargame oh Wargame, where do I even start. I've been playing Wargame Red Dragon since within the first year of it's launch. I followed it back when it was in beta and had friends tell me all about it in the months up to when I could actually buy it myself. Since installation, it has never left my computer not once ever. Games come and go. Passions come and go. Friends are made and depart. I graduated school. Got a job. Worked for many years. I've aged, and yet I still always come back. I'll always come back.

Wargame: Red Dragon is my favorite Real Time Strategy game of all time. I was brought up on Command and Conquer, Age of Mythology, Empire at War and Medieval II: Total War. RTS is in my blood for as long as I can remember, and this game shines at the very top of all of them. The games from my chilldhood, my teenage years and then as an adult. It is the most complicated game I've ever played and mastered, and yet it still has this innate simplicity to it that remains beautiful.

There are no bases or building. There are no gathers or resources. There are no wonders or superweapons. There is only combat. War. Battle, carnage and death. How many millions have I sent to the grave to take a zone? A question that will never be answered. There is no one way to play. There is no meta that one must be a slave to. There is no requirement for actions-per-minute or micro intensity. Wargame has none of these. One may pick a nation from either side of the Cold War and put units in it. From the latest and greatest, most high tiered technological marvels. To Private Shabhead, his platoon, a beat up M113 and enough high explosive bombs to smite God Himself.

Nearly ten years later this masterpiece lives on, unknown to many and forgotten by even more. But I won't forget. I will still be here playing this game until they shut it down in favor of Eugen's latest RTS that is trying to do something else. I hope they come back, one day. Make Wargame 4, or even more updates. New maps. Nations. Anything really. But I don't think so.

I will simply say this, to any would-be buyer. Do you enjoy Real Time Strategy? Are you less interested in the minutiae of base building? Do you enjoy complex games? Do you enjoy games that make you think, and continually learn and evolve? If so, you may just like Wargame: Red Dragon.

I know I do.

Wargame: Red Dragon is the best example I know of a great RTS somewhat ruined by a toxic player base.

A modern military RTS, Red Dragon on its own is a genuinely good strategy game. Each unit, down to each type of tank, or aircraft have their own positives and negatives, it's very in depth. You'll even have to keep your units resupplied on the frontline with stuff such as fuel and ammunition to keep in the fight.

Red Dragon has a pretty large amount of nations and coalitions to choose from, some being better than others (North Korea). And again, they have their own perks and drawbacks. Red Dragon isn't an RTS where you can just send your whole army forward and expect immediate victory, you'll have to think, set up lines of defence, use recon to see what your enemy is planning and go on the offensive when it's appropriate in order to come out on top.

Personally, I love the destruction aspect of Red Dragon, sometimes you'll accidentally create Bakhmut 2.0 and end up with a completely destroyed town and thousands dead after a fight, it's a small but interesting and realistic detail.

This game doesn't work like your standard RTS, like Eugen often does, you build a deck of units to bring into matches, and decks can fulfil different purposes, such as having an armoured deck, giving you access to more tanks, and an airbone, giving you access to more helicopters and aircraft for example. It is very in depth, and gives Red Dragon much more replayability in my eyes.

Now, the negatives.

First of all, the community. My god. If you have never played this game before and want to, don't expect to be warmly welcomed lol. This is by far the most toxic (yet sometimes hilarious) community in a game I've seen, and I've played Rainbow Six Siege and Dead By Daylight. Expect insults, death threats and your mom jokes, and get used to them. Its normal.  However even I admit, Warchat is the last bastion of free speech on the globe.

Secondly, the AI. As someone who personally loves single player games, the AI in Red Dragon is a pretty big letdown. There is no form of strategy, it's just plowing units at yours until you kill them all or they kill all of yours. Regardless of what deck or type of deck the AI is given, it's almost always the same result.

Overall, if you're fine with pretty hostile players, and want a good RTS with modern units, this is a great choice. If you're sensitive to strangers saying how they raw dogged your mother, stay away.

Best RTS i have ever played( coming from someone that played a lot of them, including the 2 most recent Eugen games( STD2 and Warno) and that is due to a lot of factors:
-Simple interface and controls
-Easy to pick up at first, but extremely hard to master, this game has a huge skill ceiling, the difference between good players and bad ones is way more noticiable than other games of the genre, even ones that claim to have a competitive aspect.
-Decent Graphics for an RTS, even in today standards( Warno takes the crown here tho)
-Lots of deck building possibilities, with unspec, and specialized, nation, coalition or faction decks, making it have a lot more variety than other Eugen titles.
-Decent maps and good multiplayer, with ranked 1v1s, unranked 1v1s and team games in a variety of different modes, most of them being good-decent( except economy, fuck economy)
-Good Singleplayer campaigns and Missions.
-Warchat( if you are a real one)
But the game is not perfect, having its flaws, being:
-Poorly implemented Naval Combat(boring as fuck)
-Minority of maps is problematic, being unbalanced or unfun to play.
-Old Gen Graphics( its not a big deal for most functional human beings, but its still considered a negative trait for some people)
-Lack of Quality of Life changes added in recent Eugen titles: Completely understandable since the game is old, but still considered as a negative trait when comparing with other titles, in my opinion, it makes the game more unique and has a flavor of its own, since it holds your hand less.

I recently had the pleasure of diving into the captivating world of Red Dragon, a war game that continues to amaze players and maintain a devoted community long after its release. Let me tell you, this game is nothing short of exceptional. As a passionate strategy enthusiast, I find myself constantly drawn back to Red Dragon for its immersive gameplay and the lively community that surrounds it.

What truly sets Red Dragon apart is its vibrant and dedicated player base. It's incredible to see that even years after its launch, the game still boasts a large and enthusiastic community. The multiplayer scene is bustling, ensuring that you'll always find fellow commanders ready to test their skills against you. Whether you're looking for fierce competition or cooperative play with like-minded players, the community of Red Dragon offers an abundance of opportunities for engaging battles and forming lasting alliances.

Speaking of gameplay, Red Dragon delivers a meticulously crafted experience that blends strategy and tactical decision-making flawlessly. The game offers an impressive range of playable nations, each with its own unique set of strengths, weaknesses, and military units. From commanding the raw power of the American forces to strategizing with the precision of the British army, the possibilities are vast. Red Dragon accommodates a variety of playstyles, allowing you to shape your strategies and adapt to different scenarios.

The attention to detail in Red Dragon is astonishing. The developers have painstakingly recreated the complexities of modern warfare, from the intricately designed units to the lifelike terrains that stretch as far as the eye can see. Engaging in battles feels like stepping onto a real battlefield, with the chaos and intensity captured flawlessly. Whether you're orchestrating combined ground and air assaults or coordinating naval operations, Red Dragon's immersive atmosphere ensures that each move you make carries weight and consequence.

Visually, Red Dragon is a treat for the eyes. The highly detailed unit models and breathtaking landscapes make the game a feast for the senses. The soundscape is equally impressive, with realistic weapon sounds and explosive effects that transport you into the heart of the action. The synergy between the visuals and audio creates an unforgettable cinematic experience that adds an extra layer of immersion to the gameplay.

I must mention that Red Dragon does have a bit of a learning curve, which may prove challenging for newcomers to the genre. It requires patience and dedication to fully grasp the mechanics and intricacies of the game. However, once you overcome the initial hurdle, the rewards are plentiful. Red Dragon offers a deeply satisfying and strategic gameplay experience that will keep you engaged and continuously coming back for more.

In conclusion, Red Dragon is an exceptional war game that manages to maintain its popularity and attract a passionate community even years after its release. The immersive gameplay, thriving community, and meticulous attention to detail make it a standout title in the genre. If you're a strategy enthusiast seeking a game that delivers captivating battles and a vibrant multiplayer experience, Red Dragon should be at the top of your list. Prepare yourself for an unforgettable journey into the world of modern warfare.

 Once again the Wargame franchise has ditched the decent, long, well thought out and balanced "rts" campaign experience for the hectic, time limited, rushed online method of crash play. Don't expect any sort of actual combat planning sim here...its just another dump, spawn and move as fast as you can typical Wargame mess Ive come to expect since their last release. Theres so many different units, with so much possibility here, its almost sad they did this again. You'd think they wouldve learned after the Airlands botched single player campaign, but apparently not. 

You quite literally start EVERY battle, no matter what size of force with a 20min time clock..... and that just sucks right outta the gate. You have massive troop counts of all sorts, and all kinds of possible attack strategies......BUT.... it really doesn't matter with such limited battlefield time combined with the fact you have to accumulate recruitment points by capturing/holding sections before you can even start to deploy more. Even the thought of flying a covert group of seals in behind enemy lines, or planning a smart well executed assault on a section of land is almost absurd in this game.  By the time you fly them in, unload them and attempt to move them...your already crushed by the mass spawned army of tanks and artillery that rush and bombard your command unit 2minutes into the game. Youre best just to spawn a bunch of heli's or heavy tanks and just buttrush their start area EVERYTIME...and thats just lame.
According to the devs, in modern "realistic" war as they claim this is, all you need to do is find a good hiding spot for 20mins with your command vehicle... or just wipe out their command unit instantly and all those other hundreds of soldiers, armoured vehicles, helicopters and fighter jets you brought with you just decide its not worth it today, retreat before they even get to the battlefield and its game over, another province/state lost 

 I should restate for the record, this is not a review for the online play. I honestly couldn't be bothered to even try it online after sampling the 1player and watching the same 3 guys trolling the chatroom three nights in a row.  Such a dissapointment for Solo players yet again.

ONE BIG FAT THUMBS DOWN for a second dissapointing solo player Wargame...with another thumbs down on the side for the dev's themselves who once again created a great core game only to turn around and bury it with unneeded forced play restrictions and horrible community support... completely killing the entire "rts/strategy" playing experience!

Like building a 69 SS Camaro only to turn around and drop a civic motor in it at the end. It looks so good, it's almost insulting how bad they screwed it up.

Wargame: Red Dragon is nowhere near as good as it should be. 

I have played this game for 724.8 hours (according to Steam).

Great graphics and audio, great attention to detail on the units but the more you play the more you find it is lacking.

Very poor AI. This is more of an arcade "shoot 'em up" rather than an actual strategy game. AI dismounts at spawn points and runs to the fight. No flanking maneuverers, no diversions, poor logistics support, simply there is no strategy, just pile forward. 

AI spawn rates appears higher than player spawn rates.

Weapons on, or weapons off. No stealth option (return fire when fired upon), no ambush option. No return fire or tactical withdrawal if units are fired upon when a unit is instructed to move from A to B. The unit will continue forward without returning fire and usually be exterminated.

Helicopter dismounts, from "elite" units can take an age.  No tactical flying by helicopters (low flying), though you can adjust the height of the hover), when instructing a helicopter to land while in flight the helicopter will climb ridiculously and expose its position to opposing forces. 

AI enemy units have far greater accuracy over player units, with AI enemy often hitting first time and requires less shots to destroy player units. AI units require much more "hits" from player units to destroy the AI units. Tanks and AFV's can fairly quickly sink ships, but ships have little impact on tanks or AFV's.

Player recce/stealth units are quickly discovered. When directing artillery on to AI units, AI units then move. 

AI never uses helicopter logistics units.

Aircraft fly over enemy controlled territory (where enemy anti-aircraft units are undoubtedly placed) and get shot down quickly, rather than avoid enemy controlled territory. This occurs even when trying to set waypoints (click by click by click by click) to try and manage the approach to a target. 

Player often loses other units while trying to micro manage one unit. 

There is a glitch that remains unfixed (and never will be), when players select units, other units - anywhere on the playing map - will also be selected, and the player usually won't know until random player units move to random areas on the map, often getting attacked and destroyed as the units go for a wander through enemy areas.

And that claxon!!! No option to change the sound, reduce volume or switch off.

Wargame: Red Dragon could be absolutely awesome. 

But it isn't, sadly.

It's a complex game, There is no doubt about that. However what lies under the clouds of complex mechanics is a fantastic and infinitely re-playable game. But how so? Once you understand basic mechanics of war such as logistics (tanks can't run without fuel, AA can't function without missiles) and combined arms warfare (Tanks need AA support to protect themselves from aircraft), you discover that the game is easier than what it appears to be and from that, the experience will never be the same again. You will see that war is not black and white and there you will see the depth of the game makes Civilization 6 and Total war tremble and drool (they can't cope with complexity and smart AI).

However, this game is not for the faint hearted. It is a fast action precise and intricate game that requires actual though and critical thinking that many other strategy games don't require. Why is that? Point and clicking is no longer viable. Like the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Russia pointed and clicked its units on Kyiv and expected to take it. They did not. The game requires strategy and finesse and once you master it, You will feel infinitely prouder, especially when playing as the Chinese and beating the Americans who have more tanks, better tanks and an air-force that would make the average air enthusiast wet their pants at the sight of ever single armored unit being vaporized on the map because you forgot to place AA.
Just play the Americans, with the capitalist free liberal market behind their back, Its an easy win. They have more of everything and everything is technologically advanced compared to the concrete block wonderland that is the USSR and its speed bump puppet states called the "Warsaw pact".

I think to summarize everything into one sentence. Get the game and only play the Americans.

In depth real-time strategy game. Based on cold war era real life military units. Every unit type has a counter(s) in some way. Use combined arms and strategic & tactical play to defeat your enemy or conquer territories. Play with multiple other players online in combined arms to create an effective force.

I love playing with other people in tactical games. You can really use your wits and skill to out-manoeuvre the enemy or spring a surprise attack on them. The game is very in depth with advanced strategies such as strategically deploying smoke artillery rounds so that you can advance your units to a strategic position or take out enemy units. I love coordinating attacks with people on multiplayer or communicating and giving other people support when they call for supply trucks or infantry to area for example.

I dislike the high income games, so I mostly just stick to low income. There is not a massive player base, usually a few thousand people online I would guess, so it can take a few minutes to get a full game lobby.

Quite frankly, I'm surprised there haven't been more RTS games of this type. The Wargame franchise is truly a one-of-a-kind RTS game.

What I like most about this game is the combat requires good sense and planning while also minimizes the amount you actually have to micromanage. The closes game I can compare this to is [i]Company of Heroes[/i], but that franchise has a lot more nuance and micromanaging of units.

A couple other cool features of this game is (1) the "deck" building, and (2) the limited resources. 

(1) Prior to match-making, you can building your own "deck" of available units to choose from. Each unit comes with their own unique weapons, abilities, and costs to deploy.

(2) Like tabletop games, once your deck and resources are depleted, you are left with what you have deployed. Herein lies the grand strategy of the game.

Lastly, the units are balanced for the most part. Essentially every faction has their trump card. And the way the devs balanced this out was they might limit you to deploying only one unit of the type, making it expensive to deploy, or limiting the amount of ammo that unit has. Either way, every unit type has a counter. And no matter how good your unit is, even the most basic of counter units will act as a hard counter. E.g. AT soldier vs. tank, or simple AA gun (no rockets) vs plane.

I hope to see a new addition to this franchise in the coming years.

This is a great game. Lots of great combined arms tactical nonsense, great gameplay, deep mechanics, lots of units, great graphics. Be warned: this game has a steep learning curve, and it's much more based in real world tactics than your standard RTS. The addition of naval units is pretty fun, as now everything from river gunboats to destroyers is added to the fray, along with your standard assortment of tanks, trucks, planes, helicopters, and infantry. The number of units is pretty astounding, though I'd say about 40-50% of them are just recolors with new camo and maybe a different gun on top. This is especially bad on the Communist/REDFOR side, though the USSR did basically just export its designs to all of its vassal states, so this can be somewhat forgiven for the sake of historical accuracy. It's too bad that the multiplayer community is extremely small and the people in it are awful. Wanna play a game online? Be prepared to have half your team quit as soon as you start losing. There's really no penalty for it; hell, once enough people leave even I'll surrender. It's really not fun, unless you get to steamroll the other team, I guess. The multiplayer problems with this game could probably be fixed through just more exposure, or at least a fix to the matchmaking system so that you can join games in progress if someone quits out or something. Solo skirmishes are okay, and the AI is challenging enough even on medium difficulty (or maybe I'm just bad), though I've also heard it cheats, which isn't very helpful if you're just trying out a new set up for your army. If you want a highly-realistic RTS or are just tired of the standard RTS formula of games like Starcraft and Command and Conquer, or if you're a fan of modern military equipment, I'd recommend this, though I would wait for it to go on sale just in case you end up not liking it.

WarGame Red Dragon is probably the most addictive real time combat tactics simulator ... It is very hard to properly understand the mechanics (there are literally 1000s of online tutorials on youtube and you have to practice playing the game for quite some time) but once you start to get into grips with the tactical gameplay it is f@cking amazing ... At this price I consider it a MUST buy and despite all the hype around more recent similar games (with better graphics) I think it is still the best tactical military simulation / RTS in the Brigade level ... for those that do not want to get into online multiplayer (pvp)  the game still offers countless of hours of  single player both in Skirmish and in Campaign mode ... the only alternative maybe Broken Arrow , but judging from the demo BK will break your PC , where as WG RD plays flawlessly on top quality in any PC today ... Finally pay NO attention to graphics in games of this type , as you will NEVER see them in actual gameplay ... focus on mechanics , UI , controls and depth of gameplay  ... there in lies the grandness of Wargame Red Dragon

There are a few things that have caught my eye in this game that I hope are fixed/Improved on or Just Implemented in general due to some unrealistic moments that have happened here and there in this game.

1. When evacuating aircraft out of the warzone they SHOULD NOT be evacuating into enemy territory aka (making a turn left or right into their territory.) The Unbelievable amount of aircraft I have lost just evacuating them and they decide to do it towards enemy territory is frustrating!

2. When an Aircraft is being Fired on they should be doing Maneuvers not just deploying flares and continue going in circles. They should dodge those Missiles with flares to improve the chance of escaping those Missiles. 

3. Something nice that could be implemented into the next iteration is for Airborne Aircraft for us to set a boundary line mode where they will not cross into enemy territory and back to default mode which is what we have now. This reduces the chance of your aircraft going into enemy territory mindlessly.

4. Russian Tanks seem to be super OP to me. After watching Plenty of Russian Tank videos such as T-74 and T-80 videos They are made in this game to be very tough. In Conclusion, 

Each game serves different players. While I prefer Steel Division, I appreciate the nuances of Red Dragon. They are both complex, detailed, and tactical in their own way, but the implementation and the mechanics of Steel Division offer the player a more diverse and enjoyable experience. The campaigns of Red Dragon (of which I tried two), offer variety because the player makes their own choices, with battles connected from to the next, but each battle, especially when they occur again and again on the same map with similar units and outcomes become a repetitive bore.

This is my third time writing a review for Wargame Red Dragon. My first review was written after 40 hrs of gameplay, my second written after 200 hours, and this will by my final one as I feel that I truly understand the game now. This is my journey through Wargame Red Dragon.

I had started by watching a video on the game and sort of forgot about it for about a year, until my friend who had recently downloaded it reminded me of it. I read some reviews and decided to buy it. I started playing campaign and relised quickly that this game would take some time to learn, and the learning has never stopped, even now. My first 20 hours or so were brutal, I played one battle over and over, determines to defeat the North Koreans in the first battle of Busan Harbor. These battles taught me the importance of the, as the AI would throw themselves at me and I had to figure out a way to not only repel them, but to counterattack and destroy them. I can now say that should you decide to get the game, dont play the campaign for too long, play against a friend or skirmishes, you will learn more faster, and then play the campaign.

Between 20-30 hours or so into the game I almost exclusively played against the AI with my friend, each of us trying to learn as much as possible. We did, and soon a victory previously determined by luck was now determined by our skill to react. I then felt pretty good about myself so I decided to go into a 1v1 against someone on multiplayer. 
It was a slaughter, I remember sitting there thinking to myself how this could have happened as my push was wiped out through tactics and units I was only now getting exposed to. I asked the player after this game essentially how to get good, he told me to do what he did (he had 1300 hrs unknown to me) and play 10v10s. 

To this day, this is the best advice i received on this game. playing with that many people means i could sit back and play artillery while also watching my more experienced teammates  and how they played the game. This I did for maybe 30 or so hours, at the end of which I came out a completely different player.

The rest of my time had been a blur, battles mostly lost over time turned to mostly won, and I was having fun the whole time. I have read other reviews and have seen comments on the state of the community, and although I will say no sane person will look at or converse in warchat, I have also met people that I continue to play with to this day, both on wargame and other games aswell. The game itself has over a thousand units, and I can confidently say that I have memorized hundreds of them, their functions, and other units they pair well with.

This brings us to now, I can happily say that this game made up 25% of my 2022 playtime alone and I have no issues with that whatsoever. If your thinking about getting the game I cannot emphasize enough that you should. Behind the learning curve is sasitfication at what you have learned and done. Ive met cool people, facists, communists, many racists, and people with schizophrenia, this game has all of them.

Tactical RTS with loads of units and interesting mechanics.

Featuring units, vehicles, and prototype military equipment from the era in a "Cold War gone hot" (1950s-1995 mostly- some earlier ww2 equipment still obviously in use for many). Gameplay is heavily reliant on tactics and combined arms, though a proper helicopter rush with the right coalition is kind of hard to beat.
While some individual units are quite powerful almost nothing gets done in this game without some combined arms action, Infantry units can set up sneaky ambushes from along roads and take out tanks rushing a little bit too quickly to take good shots, but a proper push may require an artillery barrage or helo rocket salvo to stun or suppress entrenched units as you push forward with IVFs and tanks. You may need to drop napalm bombs or apply it in other ways to wipe out entrenched infantry in a few city blocks or heavily wooded area because you just can't get close enough to duke it out in CQC, your pushes and defensive lines need to be watched over by AA guns or SAMs to ward off helicopters and bombers/strike craft, but beware, sneaky SEAD slinging aircraft can snipe your exposed radar-bearing AA Guns and SAMS with ease, but are often juicy targets themselves.

Honestly this is the best Wargame has to offer in terms of being a complete package. It has multiple campaigns, most of which are a decent romp. The multiplayer is great (just don't look at wargame chat) and can be set up to provide a decent variety of interesting game types with... albeit lackluster map variety. The DLC generally all offer an interesting nation (coalitions sometimes too) to play in skirmish or MP, but we all wish they could have come with some campaigns.

I hope WARNO can one day catch up, but it is just missing a lot of stuff.

Also stay away from naval nonsense.
Amazing game ... 😉

I hated this game when I first tried it out. I hated it for numerous reasons: the fast-paced combat style that made micro vs macro management very difficult to balance, the fact that armor/AA combinations can just roll through everything, the failure of infantry to do literally anything, etc. 

Then I continued playing (because I'm a masochist), and I discovered something. The more I lost, the more I learned; the more I learned, the more I wanted to continue playing; the more I played, the more I started winning; the more I started winning, the more I enjoyed this game. Then up the difficulty and repeat the cycle. By the end of all of this, I have come to love Wargame for some of the very things I initially hated it for. 

So give it a shot->hate it->continue trying/learning->get gud(der)->start winning->feel better about giving it a shot->this game is awesome. Kudos Eugen.

I absolutely love this game, I played R.U.S.E. When I was younger on my Xbox 360. Getting into Wargame is essentially playing RUSE on steroids. I'm not sure if they're made by the same people or not. I haven't fully tried the main campaign and the "risk-esque" style that it allows you to play. I've mostly done Skirmishes on multiplayer or against/with AI. I have found however, installing the "Sandbox" mod does provide a better gameplay on the Skirmish side so you aren't farming for points the entire match only to get a handful of units out to defend. The gameplay is "realistic" to a point, vehicles have limited ammo/fuel, older vehicles like the Sherman and Stug are generally worse than the newer vehicles as well as having worse armor. The DLC doesn't make you overpowered by any means but allows you to enhance and learn new play styles as different countries. Not to mention all countries have a weak point and a strong point. I.E. UK has some very good aircraft and some decent infantry, America has some good armor and support units etc. 10/10 Would reccomend, I home they make more of these in the future.

One of the most immersive and in-depth RTS games I've ever played. Loving the late-cold war aesthetic as well as the plethora of possible armies (aka "decks") that you can make, even with the vanilla nations available. This game has an extensive campaign, however the AI is very lacking as it will always use a repetitive tactic of rushing its frontline units.

Deck building (creating your armies) and putting them to the test in Multiplayer is where this game truly shines. You'll find yourself fine-tuning your deck to suit whatever playstyle you like; from using a Motorized Deck to quickly take key sectors of a battlefield before the opponent does, to using an Airborne Deck and exploit your surplus of air assets.

Also the global chat is basically /pol/ that you can watch live.

tldr: Assclowns, autists, sweaty homosexuals, and people willing to waste at least an hour in the lobby apply here.

Decent games are either where 9/11th of the team leaves, because the opening segment of the game didn't work out in their favor, forcing you to fight against autistic individuals in a survival-based mode; or a complete stomp where everyone is well developed or at least able to communicate effectively.

Expect to get zergrushed by 50 separate helicopter units mounted with ATGMs and/or rocketpods and/or machine guns. Naval combat is the same in principle as well, but with the added caveat of "dude just spam anti-ship aircraft and dong-haes lmao".

Campaign is irrelevant, the AI cheats and makes moves in reaction to what you reveal to it. Neat editing style for the introductions and neat writing for the scenarios though. Except for Busan Pocket, that's just the Korean War but in the 80s.

>Tanks, vehicle recon, and stuff that's meant for killing vehicles or choppers and infantry should have a max range of 2 to 2.1 km.
>Make sure to get SEAD for units with RADAR weapons, bombers for straightforward use, and air superiority units.
>Use helicopters to create a deathball.
>Move any artillery units after firing and make sure to have them rendezvous with supply units.
>You'll have to micromanage your RADAR units if you want them to live long. Infrared is fine, outside of moving them when you feel that the enemy is going to bombard them. Therefore, order of commonality or importance should be "RADAR Missile, RADAR SPAAG/AAG, Infrared, AAG". 
>Any type of WW2-looking vehicle is for memes. The only relevant ones are the ones that can reach 2 km, or are cheap AAG.
>Infantry should have SHOCK for Training and possibly VERY GOOD for Stealth. Use them to hold down towns or anything urban. Don't depend on them to hit a target out of 1 km, unless their AT weapon has 1 km max.
>Don't do 10v10s unless you just try to not be re-tarded by providing some kind of support.

Also, fucking Israel has grenade launchers that can take out T-55s.

There, that's basically Wargame Red Dragon's depth. Also, read the Carrera series if you'd like if you want a feel for how your tactics should go. Each game doesn't carry over, make sure to use as much of your resources as possible and as efficiently as well.

Good (not great) simulation of mid-90's modern combat.  Over-values Helicopter impact, GREATLY overstates Soviet equipment including making liberally available experimental equipment that was never fielded, never fielded in numbers or fielded 20 plus years after the game's time frame.  That said, it does a terrific job teaching you the value of obscuring attacks, proper unit positioning, and the devastating power of artillery.  Is a very good game at teaching small unit battlefield tactics (not individual unit/squad level) but platoon level.

A surprisingly valuable resource for the young LT that needs to memorize NATO symbols and familiarize themselves with the functions of CAS and fires. This game will provide players with an abstract idea of many of the capabilities of military equipment under ideal conditions. Go into the options menu and set the symbols to NATO so you can get used to the unit designations. The ranges and capabilities are usually only off by a small margin, and this game can help you visualize your OPORDs if you are more of a visual/tactile learner.

Decent game but probably the nastiest online multiplayer community I have ever encountered. The sad reality as someone pointed out accurately on reddit is that Wargame's 'potential audience (autists, ex-soldiers, neo-nazis, russian nationalists) isnt big enough for it to be a comercial success'. To which someone replied 'nutshell.' https://www.reddit.com/r/wargame/comments/5nke5w/viability_of_wgrd_as_an_esport/

So it is no surprise the games community are so terrible. (However, I do hope they eventually make a new Wargame set in a near-future conflict with next generation technology and involving Nato, China, Russia and Iran etc - I can only hope this might generate a new player base of less vulgar people...). In Wargame: Red Dragon the online community are mostly (although not everyone of course (but must be 75%)) an aggregate of some really nasty people. I cannot recommend the game therefore because multiplayer is the best aspect and yet the games are always full of a lot of arrogant, argumentative, rude, aggressive and hostile people (nasty pieces of work sums it up). For this reason you can barely ever just enjoy a game without some sub-human racist trying to pick a fight over every aspect of the game or some egoist blowing his own trumpet so hard it makes you want to vomit with disgust. People sprouting pathetic insults everywhere, complaining constantly and sometimes even team killing your units to be antagonistic. If you can find enjoyment beyond this fact the actual game is pretty awesome. I however have decided to uninstall the game to avoid this perpetual abuse.

Even if you ignore the blatant lies on the features pages ( "1,450 units that have been meticulously reproduced from their source!" aahahahaha good joke, the bulk of them are repaints and the rest are reskins) this series of games is ultimately an unfun excercise in frustration as you are forced to constantly micro manage 20 or more utterly inept units or group of units only for your plans to come undone because of the constant luck involved (Did you just send a state of the art f-15 to engage a junk chinease copy of a junk russian plane, doesn't matter, he got lucky, your f-15 just missed with all of it's missiles and you lose your expensive plane). 

 But hey, at least it's fun to waste minutes of your time trying to find the exact pixel that will send your useless units into the bush that will turn them invisible. (= sarcasm)

2022 edit (since I got dragged back to it by friends): In short the game is a macro strategy decided by luck at the micro level with limited controls which constantly distracts you from both the macro and the micro level by the need to resupply everything topped of with an AI that's incredibly inept, cheating blatantly and unfun to fight.

 It also has no reason to exist because the extra naval aspect is not only a DLC at best but horribly implemented and only serves to further split the multiplayer community.

Quite simply put, one of the GOAT's of the RTT / RTS / Wargame genres. It definitely shows some of its age today when looked at side by side against newer Eugen titles, but it still holds it on with a staggering scope of content that no other Eugen title can compare to and the biggest community of all the Eugen titles. 

So would I recommend this game? Obviously, yes.
qa

It's a unique rts.

Think Men of War Assault Squad 2 + Starcraft 2. It has the rock paper mechanics of starcraft with some of the complexity of MWAS2.

It has the rock-paper-scissors of Starcraft in the sense that AA will counter-air, etc. However, if you don't hide your AA an armored bomber that could tank some light aa might just airstrike. There is an element of complexity like in Men of War, well it depends in the unit's unique mixture of stats, and how it's deployed.

Combine arms like real life is important in this game, and understanding that is easy. Doing it in a timely, effective fashion is hard. Say there's an open field, you want to push across, you'll need tanks for firepower, and AA to cover those tanks. If there is a forest or town on the other end of the field, you'll need some infantry to screen the town/woods, so your tanks can shoot the enemy infantry from afar without getting an rpg in the side armor. 

Coordinating all these units in a timely fashion to provide ample cover is difficult, and this game also has an economy. You get points over the duration of a match, and each unit in your deck cause X points to summon, so if you have a 180 point super heavy, and the enemy has a 100 point anti-tank plane, they are going to dive-bomb that tank despite aa coverage and walk away with an economic victory in that exchange. However, I think overcoming this learning curve is a great deal of the fun in this game, and the strats the variety of units enable are many and varied.

As far as micro-managing units go, you mirco high-value irreplaceable units in order to get your money's worth/ lower exposure. For example, you manually queue waypoints to plot a flight path for your bomber to avoid AA, etc.

I highly recommend this game.

I also like that I can focus on real time micro, my units don't miss for an hour and a half before wiping squads, flanks and scouting are rewarded and that the "cover system" isn't a snoozefest like CoH2 where you just have two hunkered opponents shooting like stormtroopers all day.

It's the best mix thus far of having real time tactical combat that feels almost turn based but fast and rewarding.

Have you ever wondered what the *TRUE WARGAME* Experience is? Well worry no more as here's a comprehensive list!
1) Join a multiplayer lobby only to be cussed out in 3 different languages (One is ALWAYS Russian)
2) Get mercilessly Heli-rushed by some guy with 800 hours just using that one heli deck
3) Wanting to test out a new deck that you just created to avoid using the meta to only get your world rocked by some Komandosi or Spetznaz
4) Wanting to try out a really powerful unit that an enemy was using against you, to only realize that A, its not that good, and B, it was only good because you're bad
5) Getting your expensive fighter jet that theoretically should beat anything get stunned by some drunk Ivan with a MANPAD so now your jet is left completely vunerable to even the North Korean Airforce
6) Getting frustrated to always loosing against FINPOL decks so you make one, only to get your 3-stack of Komandosi Nighthawked, and then ruthlessly pushed
7) Go back to BLUEFOR and make some deck that finally starts to click, until your glue sniffers sitting in you M163s and PIVADS to let a B5 bomber through and now you don't exactly have a fighting force
8) Decide to play with some artillery until all of your brand spanking new paladins that have been alive for 5 minutes to only get Smerched
9) Face a lot of DLC decks in Multiplayer
10) And finally, the crown jewel of the Wargame Expereince; The Global Chat. One does not explain this, one has to experience this

Overall, i despise this game due to all the mental torture it has given me. But then again sitting down with a couple of friends and playing together is super fun due to all the things you can do, including *BEST KOREA* deck spam.
To sum it up: 11/10, would get helplessly heli-rushed again

[h1]Migros & Carrefour vs BIM & A-101 Simulator[/h1]
Oyun gerçekten güzel ve hakettiği kadar büyük bir topluluğa ulaşamamış durumda. Oyun Soğuk Savaş döneminde geçiyor. (1975-1997). Başlıktan tahmin ettiğiniz üzere NATO pahalı, az fakat güçlü donanımlara sahipken, Doğu bloğu ucuz, çok ama daha zayıf donanımlara sahip. Oyun oldukça detaylı; Topçu, anti-hava, tank vs. neredeyse her türlü asker araç mevcut. Bunun yanısıra hepsinin bir menzili, hızı, görüş açısı, atış oranı, düşmanı panikletme, uçaklarda bombanın kilogramı aynı zamanda cinsi ve gizlilik faktörü var. Piyadeler de aynı şeylere sahipler fakat onlar da aldıkları eğitime göre sınıflandırılıyorlar. (Militan, düzenli, şok, elit) Oyunda olmayan tek şey denizaltılar. Ama hiç aratmıyor, zaten bu tür bir rtsye pek uyacağını sanmıyorum. Geliştiriciler oyuncuların stratejik dehalarını sınırlandırmamak için olsa gerek, T-34 tankını bile koymuşlar. ;) Hurra diye saldıramıyorsunuz, bölge ele geçirmeniz gerekiyor. Bunun için ise komuta birliklerini o bölgeye mümkünse ağaçların arasına yerleştirmek gerekiyor. Ve düşmanı gözetlemek için her zaman bir gözlem birliği veya helikopteri kullanmanız gerekiyor.

Kısaca kendi oynadığım ırklardan öne çıkan ünitelerini yazayım:
Rusya: Her konuda iyi.
Polonya: MORTAR YOK :O fakat iyi piyadeleri ortalama tankları var.
Doğu Almanya: Piyade ve gözlem konusunda iyiler, ağır tankları yok, uçak birimleri güzel ama çeşitliliği az.
Çekoslovakya; Destek birimleri iyi diğer birimler idare eder.
Çin: Neredeyse her konuda iyi fakat SSCB'nin biraz daha uyduruk hali. Ağır tankı yok.
Finlandiya: Piyade-tank olarak iyi, aynı zamanda amarıgadan cukkaladıkları f-18c gerçekten çok iyi uçak. Helileri kötü. Destek birimleri vasat diyebiliriz.
Yugoslavya: Piyadeleri iyi, tankları, gözlemcileri güzel. Hava kuvvetleri de iyi ama bombardıman uçağı seçeneği pek yok. Helikopterler çok az ve nispeten zayıflar. Çekoslovakya koalisyonuyla kullanmak akıllıca olur.
K.Kore: Piyade dışında tüm üniteleri zayıf. Çin-Sovyet ekipmanları kullanıyorlar.

ABD: Her konuda iyi.
BK: Piyade ve tankları iyi fena olmayan hava kuvvetlerine sahip, koalisyon halinde kullanmak çok daha mantıklı olur. Hava savunma sistemleri zayıf.

Every time there is a major world event involving warfare, I start this baby up.

I bought every single wargame ever since the European Escalation one.

I'm predominantly a player that doesn't play much multiplayer; I enjoy campaigns and good story setting. The political campaigns were extremely well done and interesting for me. While the DLCs they release are centric to ''factions'', I would love to see DLC releases of new strategic map campaigns.
Fighting the AI on the tactical map is sometimes a grindfest. It consistently shoves hordes of troops towards your positions and command vehicles (it knows where your units are). Fighting against advanced AI difficulties isn't easy because we're not computers : it's hard to micromanage multiple engagements effectively unless you slow the time of the battle down (which was a great add-on for Wargame Red Dragon). Playing against human players, which have the same decision-making limitations as you, is fun and makes the fighting more deliberate and interesting (unless they play to win and use cheese tactics against you).

The ability to customize your decks gives you the ability to build your own battlegroups, specific to your playstyle. You might choose an armoured battlegroup if you like to turtle up, or you might choose an airmobile battlegroup if you're more into risky moves and quick action. 

I wasn't a big fan of Navy combat, but I did enjoy amphibious insertions, especially on the strategic map. I love how with every game, your strategic flexibility was augmented. 

I'm hoping for either a new game or more campaign-centric DLCs from this great producer!
Great RTS Game, very competitive worth diving deep into. Highly addictive.

Although the game has a very rough learning curve (I myself am still learning), it is incredibly fun once you get the hang of it. A few tips for new players or people who are considering getting the game:
1. Don't start playing with the campaign or multiplayer, do skirmishes with weak custom decks for your first few hours.
2. Ignore the ingame global chat as much as you can, its just as cancerous as they say.
3. Infantry are one of your most important forces, so make sure to hide them in buildings or forest whenever enemies approach.

The AI cheats, getting extra points and knowing where your units are at all times. Paid DLC are the strongest nations to play, and the Red Dragons, the coalition the game is named after, is one of the weakest in the game. Despite this, Wargame Red Dragon is by far one of the best RTS games that I've ever played. It's good macro mixed with a little bit of micro skill, and even though the game is "busted" in some regards with certain mechanics that are easy to abuse, it's still an excellent, well designed game. Look at the players who stick around to play it. Those who know what they're talking about have 2000 hours or more. You'll see lots of negative reviews from nerds with 100 hours who get mad they can't beat the enemy team in a 10v10 - but if you want a game with a lively 1v1 competitive scene that can carry over into casual team games, all set in the Cold War going hot in Korea, this is a good game for you. If you're new and you're planning to pick it up, check out the wargame bootcamp discord server - which can be found on the wargame bootcamp subreddit.

A very fun and time consuming RTS. It's got quite a learning curve which took me well over 100 hours to get comfortable with. 

The community isn't the biggest the player count usually hovers around 400 at peak although at the time of this review it has spiked recently to around a 1000+ players. The community size isn't really an issue for me however as the campaign and skirmish modes are still a lot of fun even if the AI isn't the smartest. 

The DLC for this game is also pretty good, lots of new and updated units for the factions. I'd get them on sale since the game is quite old and their very often half price during the sales.

Overall if you're looking for a good RTS, set in the 20th century then this a very good title I would however like with the DLC reccomend getting it on sale due to it's age. 

The developer is making a new title called WARNO, which is currently in early access. If you're willing to wait then I would say hold off buying this game and wait for WARNO as it's seems to be quite similar to this title but with better graphics and an options for MODS which this game sadly lacks in any official capacity.

Good game, but something else that's also good is this recipe for Key lime pie.

3 Eggs
14-1/2 ounce can condensed milk (sweeten milk)
1 ½  teaspoons finely shredded lime peel
1/3 cup lime juice
Baked Pastry Shell
 
Separate egg yolks from whites:  set whites aside for meringue.  In a bowl
Beat yolks till thick and lemon colored.  Stir in condensed milk and line peel.  Gradually add lime juice, beating at low speed just till combined.  Do not overbeat.  Stir in green fool coloring, if desired.  Spoon lime mixture into pastry shell.  Evenly spread meringue over filling -seal to edge.  Bake in a 350 degree oven for 15 minutes.  Cool, cover and chill to store.  Makes 8 servings.
( I usually add more lime peel to give it that extra lime taste)
 
MERINGUE FOR PIE
3 egg whites 
½ teaspoon vanilla
¼ teaspoon cream of tartar
6 tablespoons sugar
 
Bring egg whites to room temperature.  In a mixing bowl combine egg whites, vanilla, and cream of tartar. Beat with an electric mixer on medium speed about 1 minute or till soft peaks form  (tips curl).  Gradually add sugar, 1 tablespoon at a time, beating on high speed about 4 minutes more or till mixture forms stiff, glossy peaks and sugar dissolves.  Immediately spread meringue over pie, carefully sealing to edge of pastry to prevent shrinkage.  Bake as directed in pie recipe
 
FOUR-EGG-WHITE MERINGUE
Prepare as above, except use 4 egg whites, I teaspoon vanilla, ½ teaspoon cream of tartar, and ½ cup sugar.  Beat about 5 minutes till stiff, glossy peaks form

For a game that claims "phenomenal selection of 1,450 units that have been meticulously reproduced from their source" and "varied, ultra realistic battlefields, dominate the new maritime areas and rewrite history in a conflict that has been directed and designed in stunning detail", there is very little realism at all. At best, most units have cookie cutter stats pasted onto models resembling real world units. At worst, you've got units that are both unbalanced and grossly historically inaccurate. As an example, Chinese and North Korean ships with '50s era AA systems provide as good or better missile defense than their '70s and 80's Western opponents. Or the fact that the Soviet Navy is portrayed as having the most powerful and advanced ships of any nation. Or North Korean and Chinese upgraded T62s beating M1s and K1s in duels... not even close to being realistic, and only the tip of the iceberg. The game can be fun at times, but if you're looking for a realistic war-game, this is definitely not it.

After about 8 hours played, it's clear that this game is absolutely mind-blowing. It's basically Total War: Modern Warfare. But way more in-depth and complex than anything in Total War's RTS element. Hundreds of real world units, and you have to manage your actions down to tiny details like making sure your tanks face forwards, and retreat in reverse etc. Units have weak spots on their armour (such as the back of a tank) etc, and using smart tactics can turn a battle around in seconds. There is far too much to explain here, but I highly recommend this to any fan of strategy games, this is absolutely one of the best I've played.

Reading some guides is highly recommended. The 200-page guide on Steam is a good place to start. And NO, you don't need to read 200 pages of it (whatever that means on Steam) to get a decent grasp of the game ;)

If you want a detailed, realistic modern RTS with spectacular gameplay and visuals, plus competitive multiplayer and a truly demented community of psychotic war-minded maniacs, this game is for you.

Protip: don't take the community seriously. Kim Jong-Un and Donald Trump like to have fun in their spare time too.

Was late to get hold of this game, but it does not disappoint at all.

Pros: Not as grand as the Hearts of Iron series, nor not as 'tactical' as good old Operation Flash Point, this game fitted itself into a nice niche market. Other than Steel Division series, or the franchise's older games, this game provides rare, but very satisfying experience as long as you are into military stuffs. Even the deck-building feature could be fun; at least, it is for me.

Cons: If you are an average RTS player, you have a very steep learning curve to climb; this game is a different breed from the rest of the RTS genre. Your units are extremely dependent on the LoS, their responses are slow, armour works differently depending on from which side your units are hit, and the list goes on and on. So, the emphasis of the game is on the map-reading skills and patience for setting up good attack plans. There are definitely elements of hardcore micro-controls as well.
 
Also, tutorials of this game is downright useless. So, you are left on your own to learn this game. Since the game is relatively old (a new game in its franchise, WARNO would soon be available), there are plenty of resources you could turn to make your learning experience more bearable. Still, you have to go on the net to find the very basics of the game. To me, that is not tolerable.

Overall, the game is for the 'acquired' tastes - definitely not for everybody, but for a very specific niche of players. Could be on sale again when the next game comes out; in fact, the game was once free on Epic Games Store. Until then, go onto YouTube and feel around the game.

WG: RD is a top tier RTS. The only good cold war RTS that has a (battle) campaign-scale perspective while having the depths and complexity to give both historical immersion and fun things to do as a game.

When you jump into a (multiplayer) game, 30 seconds for fast typing and communication, then you are right the midst of action. That's in sharp contrast of AOE4, for example, where you are busy for 10-20 minutes before you get actions.

WG: RD is hard to play. The player base is highly knowledgeable already. But it can be learned for RTS or military fans.

The game is old; yet the graphics is effective. You will get a sense of seeing the historical tanks and planes in action and you will base your game-play decisions on what you see and what you hear. The graphics is minimal (e.g. you need to open a side panel to see some simple unit animation in the abstract, out of their actual terrain). There are some much need UI improvements that will never be made. But on the balance, the graphic is effective to facilitate gameplay and give immersion.

The (base) game is not expensive at all. So many other games are several-fold more expensive but not several-fold the replayability and content. If you are new, you will likely need 100+ hr before you are proficient; still, I think those 100+ hr will be full of fun and well worthwhile .
