I came into this game purely for the singleplayer experience and ultimately I'd give it a solid 7/10. Because I only went into it for the singleplayer, this review is not applicable to the multiplayer experience.

The good:
-Five campaigns of varying difficulty. The first one in particular is very hand-holdey with what you can or cannot do, but the last two (one of which was added in a free DLC) set the player up against fairly challenging odds with a number of tools in their box.
-Generally well-polished gameplay with reasonable depth and a fairly high skill ceiling. Different units all have their own characteristics,  with placement and composition mattering.

The bad:
-The AI is not exactly clever. Its tactics can bluntly be summed up as "attack with everything it has and hope for the best". Sometimes it works, predominantly when it has tanks on open ground, and its artillery/air management is decent, but to say that it mismanages its infantry would be an understatement. After a while you learn how to exploit its flaws and at that point it's rarely going to win any battles against you if you just keep a spare command vehicle around. It's not smart enough to avoid driving its tank columns into your infantry-clogged town, for instance.
-Not much replayability. Sure, you could redo a scenario once or twice in order to get a better result, but each one has a pretty clear scenario flow and ultimately I don't feel any strong urge to repeat them a second time around. I did well on the first go, and because they're scripted in terms of progression the campaigns wouldn't really change beyond how the battles go, how much ground you take/lose, et cetera.
-The in-game global chat is widely known to be a very toxic place. I don't personally care about that sort of stuff, but if you're one of those people who are going to get triggered by it, well, don't say I didn't warn you.
Always love coming back to this game and learning something new every time. Super enjoyable, well balanced and great graphics!

The game is a really fun thought, but it has major drawbacks that make it *tough to learn*.

First, there is no interactive tutorial, just a manual. Expect to watch YouTube videos to understand very basic things about the game. Second, the game pretty regularly glitches up and tells you you have territory at the beginning of a battle you don't have. The graphics are just so-so. The interface lacks ease of use. You can't look back at the strategic picture after you've started a battle, it's difficult to see what units are still in reserve. The "chess board" is very difficult to understand and almost nothing is explained. In the end it just took too much time to enjoy. Uninstalled at first.

I came back. I learned to save my game more often, and a few other tricks with the UI so I could move back and forth to understand what was happening and where. This game will frustrate you until you learn it.

Toxic community and poor game play make this game a pass for anyone who actually expects to have fun with their games. I have more than a small amount of experience with real time strategy games and this one fails to deliver on many of the core concepts that I have come to expect. 

The game requires an absurd amount of micromanagement. Units completely fail to act on their own when facing, say an artillery bombardment. Rather than taking cover or moving away from the exploding bombs they'll shout "Its starting to get dangerous over here!" Then continue to stand perfectly still while the enemy slowly gets the range correct to wipe them out. Oh hey, the building I'm in is covered in napalm? Better sit here and burn to death while we wait for the battalion commander to call me personally to request I move my squad 3 feet over to the not on fire building!

The "unique nations" all feel like re-skins of each other with marginal changes to stats with the occasional interesting unit sprinkled in to push you into purchasing DLC so you can add it to your units. 

The logistics system is an overly simplified for a modern RTS (Somehow my fuel truck is "resupplying" entirely new marines out of it? Were they hiding inside some kind of hidden compartment like a clown car?) 

And that isn't even covering the toxic community. Good luck trying to learn when MrMcPro is screaming at you about how bad you are the entire match without managing to say anything useful as to what he needs or wants you to do to help him.

First and foremost, I'd point out that this is not a game.
It is the training material for a college class named "Micro-management 401".

You don't play this game. You click the mouse about 6,000 times and a bunch of crap happens as the program ignores your clicks and in the end you find it is just a frustrating piece of trash.

The game is such junk, the way it is written, you'd think the Mig-23ML was the baddest fighter plane ever made - it will take it out multiple F-15s and F-16s in a single sortie. What a friggin' joke.

Mirco-management hell. 
It's not a game. 
And it's decidedly not fun.

This is the worst, most-sucking thing I have spent a dollar on through Steam.

The game looks great, but the scale is too large for the level of AI you are given to work with. Command is about delegating tasks. Higher command levels have to delegate to more peopel, and thus they are forced to give less orders. It is up to the ranks below them to delegate the details, or so that's how it's supposed to work. 

The AI in this game cannot complete the most basic of tasks on their own, meaning you have to micro manage them down to the squad and even team level. This would't be a problem in a Squad RTS... if such a thing existed. I have't seen a squad or team level RTS since full spectrum warrior back on the PS2... But I digress, this game isn't that. It's at the smallest, a Battalion or Regimental RTS. And the fact your troops have NO combat AI, no self preservation or agency of any kind, means you are forced to divide your attention in a thousand directions at once. It is humanly impossible to play this game optimally. So instead you have to cut yourself down at the knees and either accept massive casualties for no good reason, or micro a few squads at a time, while your main force is hidden somewhere safe and just pray nothing unexpected happens. 

Some people can multitask better than others, but this scale problem is seriously inhibiting access to higher level play. It unjustly favors heavy weapons and quality over quantity, because you will struggle to manage large numbers of units at once. You might be temped to build a large economy based army, but you'll never be able to use it, because you can't micro manage that many units.

The game has the potential to be a great RTS, but not at this scale. Perhaps if they sub-divided the forces among more players, so each player had a platoon to themselves, then this game might turn into something. But the base game is borderline unplayable.

ingredients
for 16 servings

2 ½ cups warm water
1 teaspoon sugar
2 teaspoons active dry yeast
7 cups all-purpose flour, plus more for dusting
6 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil, plus more for greasing
1 ½ teaspoons kosher salt
¼ cup semolina flour
OPTIONAL TOPPINGS

TOMATO SAUCE

28 oz canned whole tomatoes
1 tablespoon kosher salt
MARGHERITA

tomato sauce
fresh mozzarella cheese, torn into small pieces
fresh basil leaf
TASTY’S BIANCA

extra virgin olive oil
fresh mozzarella cheese, torn into small pieces
ricotta cheese
fresh basil pesto
dried oregano
PEPPERONI

tomato sauce
fresh mozzarella cheese, torn into small pieces
spicy pepperoni slice
freshly grated parmesan cheese

Preparation
“Bloom” the yeast by sprinkling the sugar and yeast in the warm water. Let sit for 10 minutes, until bubbles form on the surface.
In a large bowl, combine the flour and salt. Make a well in the middle and add the olive oil and bloomed yeast mixture. Using a spoon, mix until a shaggy dough begins to form.
Once the flour is mostly hydrated, turn the dough out onto a clean work surface and knead for 10-15 minutes. The dough should be soft, smooth, and bouncy. Form the dough into a taut round.
Grease a clean, large bowl with olive oil and place the dough inside, turning to coat with the oil. Cover with plastic wrap. Let rise for at least an hour, or up to 24 hours.
Punch down the dough and turn it out onto a lightly floured work surface. Knead for another minute or so, then cut into 4 equal portions and shape into rounds.
Lightly flour the dough, then cover with a kitchen towel and let rest for another 30 minutes to an hour while you prepare the sauce and any other ingredients.
Preheat the oven as high as your oven will allow, between 450-500˚F (230-260˚C). Place a pizza stone, heavy baking sheet (turn upside down so the surface is flat), or cast iron skillet in the oven.
Meanwhile, make the tomato sauce: Add the salt to the can of tomatoes and puree with an immersion blender, or transfer to a blender or food processor, and puree until smooth.
Once the dough has rested, take a portion and start by poking the surface with your fingertips, until bubbles form and do not deflate.
Then, stretch and press the dough into a thin round. Make it thinner than you think it should be, as it will slightly shrink and puff up during baking.
Sprinkle semolina onto an upside down baking sheet and place the stretched crust onto it. Add the sauce and ingredients of your choice.
Slide the pizza onto the preheated pizza stone or pan. Bake for 15 minutes, or until the crust and cheese are golden brown.
Add any garnish of your preference.
Nutrition Calories: 1691 Fat: 65 grams Carbs: 211 grams Fiber: 12 grams Sugars: 60 grams Protein: 65 grams

I am not really a big multi-player so I picked this up hoping for some decent single player campaigns. Frankly it sucks, the AI is absolutely garbage and the programming sucks to, bad developers using basic cheats to make up for one of the worst AI I have ever seen. AI will funnel their entire force into a kill box with absolutely no adjustment. 

In open fields the game gives them about 4 to 5 times the units per points you have and they basically know exactly where everything you have is but your line of site is a joke. I have literally had defenses lined up two layers thick protecting my command vehicle and had them bypass all the lines unseen, roll the map edge, unseen and then suddenly appear right behind the command vehicle with a single tank, pop it and you lost the battle because you can have 100 units on the field, killed 90% of the enemy with almost no losses, but when the command vehicle is killed everyone throws their hands up and quits. 

I cannot express the general disdain for this AI. Game is very lovely though, but you never really zoom down to enjoy it, would have preferred less beauty more actual war. I saw folks say it is very realistic, gave me a good laugh. The command system in this game kills that from ever being a possibility 1 second into the game.

Oh forgot to add, very buggy and poorly optimized, frame rate drops every game, game crashes about 1 out of 4 games. Unacceptable for a game that has been out this long.

Most people will already know if they want to play wargame: red dragon, so I'll just sum up some of my grievances:

-Most cheap units are not viable (excluding infantry), seven 25 point tanks will always lose against one superheavvy tank. I think some more nuanced differences between medium tanks and heavvy tanks would have led to larger and more 
interesting tank battles instead of the neurotic micromanaging of one or two superheavvy tanks that is the meta now.

-DLC nations are just better; for the same price Israel gets a 5pt box with 3 machineguns and extra armour where you would normally have your standard m113. The only non-dlc nations that are actually viable are the US and USSR.

- The singleplayer campaign is both short and bad, the ai zerg rushes you with everything they have until they lose, repeat this for 5 campaigns

Still, this game is the only one of its kind out there, so you dont really  have a choice anyways.

I've been hesitant to write a review for this because I honestly feel like any way I describe it won't do it justice. It's a game I love to love and love to hate, all the time. No matter how salty I get at it I keep coming back. It has probably the highest skill ceiling (And skill floor.) of any game I've ever played. It has probably the most freedom and diversity of playstyle of any game I've ever played. I've been a longstanding RTT and RTS player, but absoloutely nothing feels anywhere similiar to this game. No, not RUSE, not even close. Absoloutely not like CoH or Assault Squad like many people like to compare it to. It's more akin to like...a cold war Total War game? But much easier to manage and suprisingly less clunky. 

That said, as this is one of the few games I've intimately come to know, I'm aware all too well of its negatives: Absoloutely no tutorial or anything telling you about the vast ocean of required knowledge to be competent at this game. The AI and singleplayer in general is beyond a joke, the game would actually be better off without it. (And that's coming from someone who strives to find a good co-op or singleplayer experience.) Thanks to the developer's lack of explanation for stats, poor consistency, and generally being blissfully unaware of how the game really works, only a handful of the massive variety of units are really viable in even a casual setting. There are actually really decent parts of the community, but by and large what most players are exposed to are the chronic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ers on the general chat, and the lobby stackers in random games. Bad advice that's two games out of date is common, and many new players are stuck in limbo either playing singleplayer because they're too afraid to deal with all the "veterans" in multiplayer, or playing large team game clown matches because they feel like they're not competent enough to play without relying on someone else. DLC bias for the most part isn't just people looking for something to complain about, it's actually a real thing here, as some units are inexplicably cheaper or better than other units that do the same thing or are the same price, respectively. That said, they still add some neat variety to the game, and DLC itself will not win matches for the majority of the community.

But let's end on the cool things: Never in any other game have I seen such a variety of nations modelled, with their own unique units, with their own full voice lines, and to actual viability. (As long as you use coalitions to cover each other's bases.) Combat is the closest I've ever seen to authenticty as far as ranges, combined arms, and damage models on such a large scale, at least compared to other games. (Some ranges are still not correct for gameplay reasons, but they're within the ballpark.) Despite DLC bias and weird inconsistencies, I'm actually impressed how viable each coalition and major nation is. The balancing could use obvious improvements, but it's still impressive regardless; you can still make trash units work just because of the way combat works, and it feels so good when you do. 

You might take for granted sometimes just how many kinds of cool units are available to you, all right from the start of the game: American F-117 stealth bombers, Soviet TOS-1 thermobaric MLRS, Canadian ADATS Shorad/ATGMs, Danish Otomatic self propelled naval cannons, Swedish BKAN-1 howitzers that fire like autocannons, North Korean apcs with Iglas mounted on them, Yugoslavian paratroopers using ex-wehrmacht weapons, German and American MBT/Kpz 70 prototypes, flamethrowers and flamethrower tanks that actually look like a real flamethrower despite the weird pool of fire they leave behind, even Finnish StuG-IIIs (Sturmis) still around to provide you some fire support for cheap. Plus, all the usual suspects you've come to love if you're a cold war fan, like Pattons, T-55s, T-80s, Leopard 1s, AMX-30s, Leopard 2s, Abrams, BMPs, M113s, Bradleys, Challengers, all of them with many different variants. The pure variety of this game on top of the unreplicable style of gameplay puts it as my favorite of all time. If you've got an unhealthy obsession with military equipment, well known or obscure, do yourself a favor and buy this game. You won't be disappointed.....

This game is a gem, a masterpiece. Eugen has fine-tuned every title in this serie, and in this the latest one put themselves in the absolute frontline of realistic RTS games.
This is a deep game, with a massive amount of real world unit types which allows you to build your own combined force. The game mechanics are quite easy to learn but hard to master, but the pure amount of statistics of every single unit means you have to put in a great amount of time to learn how to use each unit the best way possible.
You have to concentrate on your strategy and mastering the use of different unit combinations for the given situation and be prepared of your opponents units and how to counter them. The campaigns are not the strenght here, but the multiplayer are, and it is excellent. Eugen is continously and often updating the game and tweaking/correcting units, game balance etc to fine-tune the game according to the players response. DLC´s with new countries are continously beeing released.
Prepare to loose sleep. The more you put into this game, the more it gives you back. It is timeless in many aspects.
{UPDATE 2021}
Having played this tile for many years since my first review, and made a pause, then took it up again, thinking I would have lost "my edge" in maneuvering my units around the maps, it was just so intuitiive to pick it up again. Recently Eugen provided a new DLC "South African Forces", including some impressively researched unique units from the SADF, many special vechicles as well as infantry. I voted it "Labour of Love" 2021 as I think the developer has listened very well to the community about requests and are continously supporting and updating this game so many years after its first release. It is not so common these days, and for fans of the cold war / modern era RTS games with depth and excellent MP matches, there are not many, if any, games out there challenging this game. Go get it & all DLC´s!

I just realized that I've put more time into this game than nearly every game I've ever played, and I've never written a review . . . . After 360 hours of gameplay, I can happily recommend this game to anyone who is interested in a deep and authentic Division-level RTS experience.

Pros:
+ Awesome 1-1 scale visual experience
+ Reality-based operational-level combat
+ Complex combined-arms strategy
+ Outstanding graphics
+ INSANE number of nations to play as

Cons:
- Poor, simplistic, and cheating AI
- Limited campaign content

My only real complaint about this game is the lack of single-player value due to poor AI and limited campaign content. The AI in this game is very simple, and resorts to simply throwing waves of enemies at you. I have confirmed that the AI cheats by creating matches where you can only spend 1000 points and witnessing the AI throw 2000+ points of tanks at me in the first wave.

The thing about this game that keep bringing me back, in addition to the fun gameplay, are the number of nations you can play as which are featured in no other game in existence. For example, I have yet to find another game where you can play as the Israeli, Norwegian, Polish, Dutch, or Norwegian militaries (and there are even more). There are only maybe 2 other games out there letting you play as the Finnish military, but they aren't nearly the quality.

When playing the later campaigns, it may feel like the computer is cheating...it is not...it simply knows the units better than you.  As an example, for the longest time I thought the game cheated when my M1 Abrams' could not kill  T-90s....then I realized that my assigned model of M1 did not have enough armor penetration to penetrate the frontal armor of the T-90.  Thus, I had to solve the problem with the T-90s with Legion 90, or A-10 Warthog, instead of  marine M1 Abrams.

UPDATE 11-18-2021:  Developer updated the game with the addition of South Africa.  It seems the Developer also updated the AI in the campaigns:  In the past, the AI would stick to roads, thus making the AI easy to ambush and subject to choke points.  After the update, the AI still favors roads, but the AI will now go through the woods or across rivers if roads or bridges become choke points...in other words, its time for fans to try the campaign again with the new and somewhat improved AI.  Have Fun!

After thousand of hours in this game,  the campaigns continue to present a challenge because of the level of detail applied to each unit, and its particular strengths and weaknesses.  In light of the large number of units in this game, the learning curve is steep...and true mastery reserved for people without day-jobs.  Nevertheless, this is a rare, modern game that will kick your ass and not apologize for it.  It is also one of those games that you keep coming back to figure out new ways to defeat it.  It is never relaxing or easy...but it is also very addictive and fun...there always seems like there is something new to figure out.  I highly recommend it to anyone who has ever enjoyed playing with toy soldiers.

This game isn't nearly as difficult as people say.  It's a basic rock, paper, scissor model but with more than three platforms.  I recommend that if you're new play with artillery in LOW POINT (fewer units) 10 v 10 matches.  This will give you the ability to help other players on your team while keeping a close eye on what works as they duke it out on the front line.  Eventually, this play style will impress upon you the value of recon units and let you put your toe into ground based AA.  Over time, you'll learn by watching and will start to feel comfortable enough to create defensive strategies.   From there, you'll learn offense.  Remember, the ONLY reason to spawn ships to to cover an amphibious landing.  Don't be the "spawn a kongo, watch it blow up, and then quit the game" guy.

Once you get the hang of things you'll start to have a few successful games.   And Red Dragon is probably one of the most satisfying games when it comes to doing well.  Anticipating enemy moves and coming up with a effective counter strategy that wins is so rewarding.  This is the ONLY RTS game I ever enjoyed because of that.

Competitive players would most likely find this game to be befitting and suitable to their tastes. I believe that Wargame: Red Dragon's replay value comes almost entirely from it's competitive multiplayer fan base. There were also a lot of quality of life improvements added to Red Dragon as compared to previous titles in the series , as well as a whole new layer of strategy that comes with the more complex terrain and environment.

In my opinion the RTS genre's ultimate appeal is the strategical rabbit hole you get to dive down when matching up against real intelligent human beings in multiplayer and getting involved in the competitive multiplayer community.

Against human players all of a sudden you're fighting a real war, and if you have the guts to approach this game with a competitive mindset you will find yourself experiencing a level of fun and heart-pumping adrenaline rushes that can not be replicated by fighting against AI.

A lot of people feel like having a competitive mindset is something for those who care more about winning than having fun. The truth is anyone who has put serious effort into trying to become one of the best at these kinds of games is doing so because that is exactly what they find fun.

The replay value of the Wargame series can amount to hundreds if not thousands of hours for these kinds of players, of which most would consider Red Dragon's non-naval aspects and new ground forces to be worth the price alone.

Despite the disaster that is the naval warfare in this game, Red Dragon's non-naval multiplayer stands up on it's own and can be worth buying for the military RTS fan with a competitive mindset.

There are moments where I like to call stategic/tactical orgasms of which the only people who get to experience these are those who put their all into learning the complex details of a game, such as this one. I believe the cost of Wargame: Red Dragon is easily justified for those who crave a new competitive online experience.

Red Dragon is a superb game, but it's far from perfect. I love it, and have sunk a few weeks of my life into this, but having played other games in the series, I just wish it could get a few of the quality of life changes from Steel Division, like the rangefinder/line of sight tool, the ability to order units to 'deploy at location' instead of where they are currently, co-op campaigns, and a less scummy AI.

Pros:
+The game is expansive, and captures warfare in a really involving way on a grand scale. Creating your own decks and armies is great fun, and is almost worth the asking price to play fantasy general on it's own.
+The graphics have held up well, as has the sound. Runs well too, even on my hunk of junk!
+Campaigns are really fun, well crafted and extremely challenging. Though honestly, this is a negative too, since if you want to experience the later campaigns you're going to have to save scum like crazy.
+Impressive unit selection, and some great opportunities to invent fantasy conflicts and see what would happen. Japan vs South Korea? Go for it. CCP vs Poland? Fill your boots! Great stuff.

Negatives:
-Basically no tutorial. Very little information is given, and unit identification is confusing.
-The AI cheats so badly it's not particularly fun. It literally gets to deploy twice as many units as you do, *and that's on easy*.
-Unit balance is properly questionable. I think they've tried to simplify to unit costs, rounding everything up or down to 5 points. But this means you have some units with identical command point costs that are drastically better or worse than each other.
-Finally, and probably most damning, there's very little feedback to the player about events going on in game, pressing space bar to jump to notifications often doesn't do anything, and unit responses are often non-existent. Playing something like Company Of Heroes, or Starcraft, where off screen events are easy to track from minimap icons, unit responses and even subtitles. Red Dragon just hopes you notice things without prompting.

The game is properly hard. It's very rewarding too, but if you're only willing to dip your toe in, and have a casual and relaxed mess around, this may not be the game for you.
However, I've had way more fun than frustration, and anyone with a taste for history, what if's and general cold war f*ckery, this will be a blast.

This game is very difficult to learn and has a HIGH skill ceiling. But, it's always a fair difficulty and even when you are doing terribly online, it's not miserable. 

The first thing you'll notice about this game is that it is... extensive. There are thousands of units to content with; it will take you a while to internalize the basic differences between certain units so you can make appropriate decisions in-game. For instance - the difference between Moto shutzen and motostrelci is pretty powerful. You sort of need to browse the armory for a bit to do your homework. Good thing that deck building even by itself is weirdly enjoyable, especially because there is nothing to grind. (I previously played European Escalation, and I did not like how you had to unlock units based on your progress in the single player. This is a massive improvement.)

I would not consider myself to be that good at Wargame, but I'm trying. In other multiplayer games its possible for a few good teammates to carry the whole team. Not so much here, except maybe in the 10 v 10 tactical matches. This is a high intensity, high stress game when you are really into it. Minor mistakes (and usually dumb luck) can completely turn the battle. 

The community is... something. Take it or leave it. Definitely a game mostly populated by hard right wing cosplayers by this point. For a game of this age there is still a good number of players though; you should be able to find a game with little difficulty.

The single player is not that great in my opinion. It's useful for learning how to play, but otherwise not very inspiring.

Naval combat is also pretty bad. Avoid it if you can.

This is an unparalleled strategy game - you will not find a better strategy simulation out there. It's great if you have a few friends to play with or wish to enjoy up to 4v4 multiplayer games. 

If you are, however looking to play on a grander scale (10v10), you will ALWAYS find the same group of people in servers stacking the teams to their advantage. There is no auto-balance nor does this "community" want it, they just want horribly stacked games (average win-rate of 70% in one team and 25% in other). How it can be fun to stomp bad players every game, every time is beyond me.   
If you think you can turn the tides of such games, even with a friend, you are wrong. At best, you can hold one side while watching the other fronts collapsing due to the horrible imbalance. To combat these stackers, we even tried organising a large group of people to play against them - once they saw our win rates, they simply left the server. So no interest whatsoever in playing a fair game. This is one of the reasons this game is know as "lobby simulator", since you wait endlessly waiting for a (fair) game. On the flip side - you can use this time to enjoy the chat filled with swastika and other nazi symbolism. It can be hillarious at times.

I really wanted to like this game.  I really did.

The main issues are with balance/AI.  I've played the first few missions of a couple of the campaigns and every single time, I was steamrolled.  I expected it the first time around, being new to the game and all, but I learned from my mistakes and brought different units, deployed them into cover with overlapping capabilities.  So the AI just sent stuff that I had no ability to defend against, or that my units simply refused to fire at...  I mean, do I need to tell the anti-aircraft to shoot at each individual plane?  

During the simultaneous assault on all fronts, my infantry don't bother to fire their AT weapons at the armored vehicles, preferring to shoot their rifles at the tanks instead...  Do I need to micromanage each individual soldier or should they reasonably be able to figure out that a rifle will do absolutely nothing to an armored car?

The map showed that the other side brought tanks and recon units, with air support so why the hell do they also have artillery?  And AA vehicles?  I watched a couple of youtube videos on the campaigns and didn't see the AI doing this so wtf?

And what's with the points system??  The difference between my side and AI was about less than 20%, 1500ish points to their 1750ish points.  So why on earth does the AI have 3x the units???????  Forced handicap?  In a game that already teleports whatever the AI needs into the battle?  Yeah, forget that.

Wargame: Red Dragon is a really fun and interesting real time strategy game. Its way more complicated then i expected. Just like with other strategy games you have vehicles and planes and helicopters and these all use ammo and fuel. You have supply vehicles and supply helicopters that you use to resupply your vehicles and your soldiers. You have motorized, armored, mechanized, support (which basically focuses on artillery, AA and resupply), airborne and marines there is so many vehicles and a lot of nations in the game. Its a really fun game.

+Tons of nations. BLUFOR which is basically NATO and REDFOR which is basically Warsaw + China.
+Tons of vehicles. Planes, Helicopters, AT jeeps and AT armored vehicles, Tanks, armored and un-armored infantry transport vehicles. Some of these are amphibious too so they can go across the rivers. There is even some really interesting and rare vehicles in some countries you can even find WW2 vehicles being used.
+The game is much more complicated then it seems. Capturing points requires command units. These could be helicopters or tanks or armored vehicles or un-armored vehicles maybe its just a squad of infantry with these you capture points on the map and these give you points with the points you earn you can call in additional soldiers from your deck (yes a deck i'll get to that later) you can call in special forces and recon teams, you can call in tanks, helicopters, infantry, AT infantry, AT vehicles, AA infantry, AA vehicles, Artillery and just TONS of things you can use but none of these will be useful if you can't supply them. They have a limited range, they have limited fuel, they have limited ammo and they need repairs when they get damaged. And for that you have supply trucks (some are amphibious) and supply helicopters.
+Tons of maps
+Campaings which are really cool.
+The deck system is really cool and fun to use. So you need to create decks. You choose either BLUFOR (basically NATO) or REDFOR (Warsaw + China and a few additional countries like N. Korea and Yugoslavia, Finland etc.) after you choose your faction then you choose your country. And after you choose that you need to choose what kind of army you'll be using. Armored maybe ? Or Airborne ? Some countries have more options then others. After this you get to the fun part you create a deck. You have different categories like armor, naval, support, infantry, helicopters etc. and in each category there are different vehicles that you need to choose from you have point limits and the role you choose will effect what kind of units you can put in your deck. For example an armored army will have extra tanks at its disposal. Adding anything to your deck costs points. So you can't fill out your deck you have to decide on whats important and whats not. Lets say you made an armored deck. Do you need any recon helicopters ? Do you have the points or the available space for those extra helicopters ? Or should you use that extra points on getting more aircraft instead ? Maybe some infantry on trucks ? No, no we are armored ! We should add the infantry with APCs instead ! The APC will offer more protection and unlike a truck it will have guns too maybe even a few ATGMs ! Some of the APCs can swim so we can put them in unexpected locations ! But the truck will be faster on road and it will waste less resources, it will be cheaper and with its fuel it can go further. You see what i mean ? This system is really cool and explaining it is kinda hard. The best way to experience this great system is  by playing the game.

+/- Sometims the game does get a bit overwhelming. There is just so many stuff you need to think about and do that at times the game just feels really overwhelming.

-Honestly my only problem with the game is how long it takes to actually play. Thats the thing with real time strategy games in general so i can't really complain but like 90% of the time instead of playing the game i'm just switching between menus creating different decks. Its a lot of fun but god damn is it addicting.
-Steam store says the game is 20 GBs. I got the game for free in Epic Games Store before and it was 20 GBs. But when i download the game on Steam ? It asked for 40 GBs of empty space. I said "alright maybe its cuz i got all the DLCs this time" deleted a few games, made the extra space, downloaded the game then i realised after the download finished the game only took 20 GBs on my PC. Idk why but when you first download the game you might need to make up some extra space. After the download finished you can re-install everything you deleted.
-Giving orders can be a bit hard at times. Telling a vehicle to unload the infantry in it or splitting up a group of units or just the small difference between right clicking and making the unit move there or instead clicking the "move fast" button THEN clicking on where you want the unit to go and then the unit will go to that location using the roads so its faster these small things just take a few extra seconds and sometimes using them can be a bit hard. Its not a deal-breaker in any way tho. At this point i'm just picking really small things and complaining about them.

Honestly the game is fucking great. Its just so much fun to actually create a deck and then use it in a match and see what happens. The units are so cool and there is so many things that you can do. The game is tons of fun the DLCs are nice too with extra countries i definitely recommend them as well. With a discount or without one if its interesting to you then get the game. Make sure to force some of your friends to buy it too cuz playing against friends or playing with them against an AI is just so much fun.
at first its confusing but at last its nice

Honest review: 

So i am going to talk about this game with my "brief" time with it and what i liked and disliked. Like all good reviews i am going to talk about the negative aspects first. 



ONLINE

This is going to be an unpopular opinion. Online is not that fun which is really impactful to the overall state of the game. I have played about 20 online matches with various players and the community has some clear problems. The one i found to be most annoying is "gatekeeping" in which older players basically bully new players out of playing the game. The common trend is for the veteran players to go on "redfor" and basically have doom stacks and trash new players. 

TO NEW PLAYERS: if you join an online game, and redfor is already all taken, leave.

This really sucks because it would be a lot of fun to be able to play online and go against people who are good and learn from them, and then engage in good dialog afterwards, which happened to me most times. but this was still after 3 players who have 3000 hours trashed me and my 15 hour team. 

There are various degrees of online play with players. You can do 1 v 1s, 2 v 2s, and 3 v 3s and 4 v 4s and even 10 v 10s. They even have 10 v 10 maps but these are uncommon to come across as you need a dedicated server. The 10 v 10s on other maps are not as fun. You are limited to a small amount of units, which sounds fun but get boring quickly because it is hard to plan and communicate. For example, in a 3 v 3 i was in, my ally told me to push. So i attacked with my Abrams platoons and artillery. He however did not push so i was wiped out. He then told me after the match "play more aggressive" 

These were just some things about online. Almost every review on here says online is the way to go. They are somewhat right. that is when you get friends and are in a lobby with people of similar skill, which is far from often. The community is toxic a lot of the time ( although you really have some gems in there ) and new people are often bullied form playing in some strange hazing of an almost decade years old game. 

BOTS BOTS BOTS. aka single player

Now the most exciting thing about this game to me was the singleplayer and skirmish. I bought this game knowing it was not polished and you should too. Single player is not the main aspect of the game. that being said, it is in there so it should at least be decent. 

There are 5 campaigns with various level of difficulty. Upon playing you will notice how linear it is for a strategy game. At least for the first half of the campaign. There is not a lot of options for diverse play style. When you do get your bearings it just gets old kind of fast. The moving mechanics are somewhat dated too. A big complaint is that not all nations are available for both sides. Which makes somewhat sense as you would not see Finland fighting alongside North Korea in the second Korean war. ( the main one i dislike is no British units in second Korean war, which does not make sense ) This brings me to my next point. If the devs made more campaigns, or added the ones from previous games, and just made them a little larger with more units and breathing room, the campaign would be way more fun. 

A reddit post i saw a couple weeks ago made some up. Scandinavia so those nations can actually be used. Taiwan, and the Chinese invasion of it. Perhaps Yugoslavia VS USSR. With Israel added the options grow. Perhaps adding Egypt, Iraq and Iran ( which almost happened ) and allowing a middle eastern campaign. With South Africa being added the options for a Cuban/ South African historical match up in Angola could be recreated. but no Cuba. Adding the option to switch sides would be fun too. Play as Redfor in the second Korean war. Simple but adds a WHOLE new dynamic. Bring back co-op campaigns. Or head to head. 

Part of the reason for this is because the game is set in Asia. Which is totally fine. But games grow and evolve and Israel would never fight in Korea. So adding a campaign where you can actually play with them would be awesome. 

SKIRMISH 

This mode is perhaps my favorite. You make your own battles. Add the AI and make them whatever nation you want them to be and just go to war. The AI bots are often easily managed but again, this game is somewhat old. When you play enough the bots even become very predictable and they often suicide attack. It is still fun though. 

An issue i have with Skirmish is you cannot 10 v 10 with pure AI. Which would be awesome. You kind of can but you need a dedicated server and need to pay for it. This sucks big time as a part of the player base are only skirmish players and they are left out. 

MAPS... SICK OF THEM

The maps are fun! but there are not a lot of them and there are a lot of reused ones. You begin to learn them pretty quickly. More so online as everyone wants to do mudfight for some reason. There are not a lot of maps though and this hurts the game somewhat. The main issue is that there are no European or Middle Eastern maps which sucks because you need to play on Korean maps which sometimes breaks immersion. The maps they have are mostly fun, with cold war Z being a fun hilly mix up from other more flat maps. But again, they get old fast. 

DECKS AND NATIONS... THE REASON FOR BUYING THE GAME 

Now decks are basically your units. You have a TON of options on how to set them up. First off you need to pick Blufor ( NATO and allies ) or Redfor ( Warsaw Pact and allies ) then you need to select a nation ( you don't have to pick a nation but it is a lot more fun in my opinion ) then if you want, you can make it a 'special' unit by making it armored or motorized ect. They have a good selection of nations in the game, and although they share many vehicles and patterns, they play very different. The US ( my fav nation ) are expensive and hard hitting and suited more so for defense. The USSR are the opposite. Cheaper and more geared to attack. The French are more mobile, the Germans have great IFVs and APCs with supporting Infantry. It is awesome. Even still, you can mix and match and create outlandish decks more suited towards you. I made a US Armored unit and learned and added on and took away until the decent set up i have now. the options are limitless. I like to recreate historical and real life units. Which you easily can. 

As someone who works in the military field. The game is pretty accurate when it comes to how some of the warfare would actually play out. ( kind of ) and the nations strengths and weakness are somewhat in real life too. But this game is not 100% accurate, but is still fun. The game lacks several factors such as technical training and doctrine that would matter in a real life cold war match up. For example, USSR personal were very worried about a mechanized NATO force, especially American because Westerners grew up with cars and machines available where as a soviet most likely did not. This made it so the USSR would need more mechanics where the NATO forces probably knew enough already and did not need to send their tanks back to the motor pool. 

This would not be possible to implement and i would not expect a video game to have it. I am just saying that this game is far from a real life military sim. 

MOD TOOLS: lastly. Mods fix most issues in games. If the mod tools were out this game would be getting a way better score from me. 

OVERALL: 

I really like this game. but it could be SO much more. The game has new life as South Africa is coming out. But the game in my opinion is still somewhat bare bones. The online is fun but toxic and uninviting. Campaign is lacking. Skirmish is fun but gets boring. The decks are awesome and are done perfectly. Mod tools are lacking which is also annoying as far as PC games go. 

I would give this game a 5/10. I am never going to "main" this game but i will always come back to it every now and then and play around. Until i get bored with a lack of mod tools and single player.

I don't play this game like most people I guess. I play only against the ai. Yes, I'm pretty bad at this game. Most of my time is spent in the deck builder, trying to create realistic decks and divisions and battlegroups for the AI to use. A lot of my time in game is spent in the air tab, managing all my SEAD (suppression of enemy air defense) planes that I always bring too many of into the game. I try to support my AI team mates with air support and by building an elaborate recon and anti air net that doesn't always survive the first 20 minutes. This play style would probably not only not work in multiplayer, but would also get you yelled at by your team mates (or worse, kicked).

I absolutely love this game. I have a blast doing what I do. The only downsides and issues I personally have with the game (and this might even be positives for some players) is that this game can be very micro-manage heavy. Steel Division 2 has spoiled me with its unit autonomy features and gimmicks, and since playing that game, the micro-managing aspect of this game has become even more of a downer for me. To be fair though, a ton of rts games now are a bit annoying with all the micro-managing that has to be done. I am supposed to be managing a massive fighting force that is literally countless platoons and even a few battalions in size. I shouldn't have to worry about pretty basic stuff that should be decided and done at literally the squad/vehicle crew level. If one of my tanks engages the enemy at his 9 o'clock, he should turn and face the tank at his 9 o'clock. Now I get that doesn't work as cleanly when you are being attacked from multiple directions, but I'd assume the tank should prioritize which direction the most dangerous incoming fire is coming from and face that direction. At this point though I am more or less just complaining about lots of different rts games, not just Wargame: Red Dragon. I also assume that the computing power and resources needed to program the ai to be that effective is quite large when you having dozens of tanks and other units on the field interacting with one another. Okay, I'm getting off topic here so lets bring it back to the game review.

Unit fuel, or "autonomy" as it is called in game, is another feature that kinda seems like a downer to me, or at least the way they implemented it into the game. Unit autonomy is a stat that is present on all ground and air vehicles in game, and is pretty much just another name for how much the gas tank can hold in each unit. Yes, fuel is a factor you have to consider when playing this game. For some that's a big turn off, for others, a cool and realistic feature. It might very well be if the stat was reflective or at least somewhat representative of the vehicles' actual fuel capacity and mileage in real life. For every ground unit it feels way too small and just an artificial constraint made to help balance units out. For helicopters it can feel the same as well. If a unit runs out of fuel, you have to risk bringing up a supply vehicle to refuel it, or it will just sit wherever it ran out of fuel at. That part I am fine with. What I don't like is what I stated previously, the fuel tanks simply aren't big enough or anywhere near their real life counterparts. The map sizes and combat ranges are definitely much larger in this game than in many other rts games, but still not really big enough in my opinion to warrant having to worry about fuel, at least at the level it currently does. Planes are the only exception to this rule, and that is simply so that they don't just loiter 500 feet above the battlefield the entire match above each player's starting zone, flying in a tight circle non-stop. Some planes present in game probably could in real life but for the sake of immersion they don't. Most planes can stay well longer than they need to drop their ordinance and get outta there. For planes, that's fine with me. For all the other units, not so much. You have to refuel your units multiple times during a match, which can be anywhere between 20 minutes to an hour or more. At most you should only have to do that maybe once in that time frame, twice if you are really playing a super long game. I'd prefer it if they treated fuel like they do in Steel Division 2, something that only affects air units. (To be honest, Steel Division 2's units and map sizes are where refueling would actually be much more appropriate if you are going by their real life counterparts, as tanks in the second world war got fuel mileage which was just about what you imaged it would be, awful.) I assume that they didn't include a stat for ground vehicle fuel for the sake of gameplay, which is alright to me. I wish they would retroactively just update this game and let the only logistical needs you have to worry about be health and ammo.

One thing that doesn't really affect how I would rate the game but would definitely love is official mod support. I really believe this game would absolutely spike in popularity and have much more longevity than it does now (which is already impressive but that may be because there isn't a game like it, or at least doesn't do what it does nearly as well) if players could finally be able to make their own maps, and adjust unit characteristics, attributes, and skins without having to mess with this game's very... weird and odd coding.

Obviously, this is all just my opinion, and it may sound like I was just going on about the negatives of this game, but I'd argue the positives far outweigh the negatives. There really isn't a game like this that takes place in a modern setting and at this scale. It isn't a masterpiece, but it definitely is a work of art. It's not for everyone, but I definitely feel that a lot of people that this game is for doesn't even know this game exists. I'd argue it is worth about $29.99, and if it ever goes on sale for $19.99 or less, then it is a steal.

One last thing, then I'll quit: the community in this game is extremely toxic, like on another level sometimes. If you are easily offended by people, I'd recommend you either turn the in game chat off or not play at all. Trolling and racism is very prevalent in the in game chat. It is so prevalent that it's almost meme-like. Most of the people are probably trolling, but it is possible that some of them do mean what they say, which can be very homophobic/racist/anti-semitic/etc. and there is no chat moderation as far as I am aware. It doesn't really bother me because I think most of them are probably trolling. Obviously that doesn't make what they say okay or alright by any means, but it is what it is. All you can do is add those people to your ignore list and move on. It can be so absurd at times you can't help but laugh. Not everyone will have the same reaction as me though, so if you are easily offended, just turn off/mute the in game chat.

If you think any other strategy game is an actual strategy game, you are a scrub.

Lesson 1:

Do not play against AI. You will feel dumb.
Instead make a CV only deck for each side, pick one, and have the AI duke it out up to 3v3 while you enjoy the herbs of your choice.

Lesson 2:

If you play multiplayer, play 10v10.

Lesson 2.2:

If youre a Noob, sit on the NATO team.
All the tryhards play NATO so even the odds if you may.
Real chads play Redfor.

Lesson 2.5:

Whatever you do, ignore the chat in main.

Lesson 3:

Mark your shit. Even if you have no idea whats happening, mark your shit.

Lesson 4:

Play support until you know whats happening. 
Playing support means get cheap recon, cheap infantry and anything that dosnt matter in points if youre dumb. 

You will be dumb.

Lesson 5:

Anything that can shoot, shoots.
If NATO fanboys send their 120 points Apache, send a 40 point soviet ground attack aircraft from the 50's. Satisfaction ensures if you dont even loose it while trolling the Apache.

Lesson 6:

In urban combat situations, send artillery while your troops are loosing, not after.

Lesson 7:

Move your shit up.
If you stay behind, youre out of range. Dont be out of range.

Lesson 8:

Move your shit back.
If you stay where you are, you are in range. Dont be in range.

Lesson 9:

Dont get emotionally attached.
Chances are: everything you send in will die. Dont try to rescue one unit and waste 6 others in the process.

Lesson 10:

Have fun.

This is a cold war RTS game filled to the brim with real world weapons, vehicles, aircraft, ships, special forces and toxic players, and this RTS is hard. We buy this game; we lose this game; we keep losing this game again and again until somewhere down the line we learn this game. Why did we keep playing this game? 

If you're like me, you played this game because of the infamous community with its unfiltered chat.
I come home from a hard day at work and play this game with my upmost toxicity from all the years of personal economic instability, mistakes & regrets, love-life regrets, political frustration, lockdowned loneliness, parental issues and that old forgotten speeding ticket I still have to pay.
All of our puny problems just disappear when we play a nice game of wargame. 

We talk shit to each other, we roleplay as Kim Jong-un and bomb South Korean troops, we kick each other from the match for having poor win rates, we bicker with our nationalistic bias views on which country has the best tank; we make such harsh political jokes that might get you beaten to death by an angry mob; we remind our Russian friends why spamming Anti-Air tanks and Spetsnaz is a bad idea and that they should go back to counterstrike; we speak in racist accents as we stomp the west with the might of the People's Liberation Army; we get our asses kicked by Chinese players; our friend in the military kicks the Chinese player's ass and then talk shit to us for being trash; our better educated West European friends fall into awkward silence baffled by our capacity to shoot out shit talk faster than an automatic. 

It is because our well educated friends don't understand the powerful spiritual healing known as toxic gaming. 
This toxicity is an escape. It puts perspective on how tiny our individual problems are. After every wargame there is a break from the toxicity as the last messages in the lobby pop on screen, "GG Gents." As in the end, we all truly respect one another and enjoyed playing this brilliant masterpiece of a game. This is because we vent all of our real world anger into meaningless text in a video game.

This game reminds us to take our brothers and sisters in open arms. This game helps us come home and greet our wives with a smile instead of  knuckles. We can take a break from all the pessamistic thoughts in our heads by venting it all out in this game's outdated, unfiltered, global chat. Some people dislike the grotesque wargame community.
I cherish it.

This is wargame afterall....

This game is at the same time one of the most exciting yet frustrating games to play.

Red Dragon is a unique game in these times. It is best described as an RTS, or a RTT (Real-Time Tactics game for the old world in conflict players. WiC is probably  the game closest to RD. but WiC was significantly more arcadey than this game.

Some of the things that is enjoyable about this game:
- Strategic and deep pre-game through the deck system
- Every unit matters, and most stay relevant throughout the match
- Deep tactical gameplay, where positioning matters
- Armchair generals wet dream in terms of unit depth and accuracy
- Unique setting, not many cold war games out there
- Air combat
-Combined Arms gameplay

Red Dragon is a game that is close is being a great game instead of a frustrating one. The crux of the issue is the multi-player , which reminds me of something from 1999 and not 2014. I firmly believe that if the multi-player was shored up, this game would enjoy more widespread appeal. There are also some QoL issues that hurt the game.

- Multi-player has an extremely toxic lobby chat, which is not moderated
- There is NO report function for toxic player behavior (IE, team-killing) and you have to report it on the forum. This is totally unacceptable for a modern game
-  Players can leave matches at any time without penalty. I would prefer a more MOBA based system because quitting players ruin the match and can leave the player with too many units to handle 
- No matchmaking system for unranked play or ELO system to ensure fair, but challenging, games
- Unit response times feel sluggish and not 'snappy'. Sometimes units do not go where you tell them to or seem to have a delayed response time for seemingly no apparent reason
- The game relies heavily on ranges and spotting, but there is no way to tell the radius of what your units can see, nor any clear tooltip to show what terrain is favorable. The player should be able to mouse over a unite and see its sight radius. The lack of such a system can make the player feel hepless when units are sniped out of nowhere

Wargame has always been a series that could really benefit from QA and QOL improvements. They remind me of Parafox in that regard, but without the follow-up.

Pick up this game if you're a patient gamer, and can handle consistent negative game experience with the good. If you can't skip this title.

I picked the game up a while ago, because I was looking to play a modern military RTS. The game simulates a "cold war gone hot" scenario, where the communist block faces of against NATO forces (conventional warfare, without the use of nuclear weaponry). You can take command of the forces of individual nations, or of coalitions.

The game has a learning curve, what units to use, how to use them and when to use them is essential in winning a game. For example: an MBT might be very dangerous on an open field at long/mid ranges, but it is vulnerable to AT fire from infantry squads in urban environments, or getting ambushed by infantry or even lighter tanks in heavily forested areas.

I've only been playing singleplayer and I can say that I found the campaigns and skirmishes to be very enjoyable. It also helps that you can build custom decks of units for skirmish battles, making the game even more replayable. It's also worth mentioning that the game balances realism with gameplay, so I wouldn't say it's 100% realistic, but it sure is fun.

when you pick up this game, you are going to tear your hair out.

the "tutorials" are just pages of text, which technically tell you what to do, but playing an actual tutorial would be nice. let's jump into the "easy" campaign, Busan Pocket. you get your teeth kicked in by north korea after the first turn. well, lets try a skirmish. 1v1, on a 1v1 map, as the default BLUFOR starter deck against an easy REDFOR starter deck. you are smacked, but not quite as hard. join a multiplayer game, titled "noobs", a 4v4. hopefully you can get carried and taught how to win. this time, you are placed on REDFOR and you choose the other starter deck, Soviet Battlegroup. you take notice that every single one of the BLUFOR is playing Israel. weird. you begin the game with your comrades, and you are immediately decimated by an enemy artillery strike right where all of your units are, along with the rest of your team. turns out, map hackers camp out noob lobbies for easy kills!

This game is great, but seriously, the learning curve is just a wall. This could easily be fixed somewhat by adding a well and proper tutorial, and also making proper starter decks that are not awful, and having AI play the game normally and not know where all of your units are. maybe even touch up on the campaigns, but they might be okay. maybe add an easier campaign, one where you are not immediately having your back against the wall.

If you escape that by watching youtubers and building your own decks, you are in for a great game. I might argue one of the best RTS's ever. The amount of different playing styles, strategies, and army combinations is incredible.

Oh, and for the love of God, please do not even engage with the Uncensored Unmoderated Global Live Chat™ functionality, truly the scum of the Earth herself there. Better yet, just close the damn thing.
Honestly, I wish there was more campaigns.

This review is in English and Slovak language:
Táto recenzia je v Anglickom a Slovenskom jazyku:

The game excels in high-quality artificial intelligence and a captivating course of battles. Thanks to the possibility of controlling the speed of the passage of time, you can enjoy the game in detail and even during difficult battles you have enough time to think about the next step. The single player campaign is challenging on easy difficulty, which I consider a big plus, because the game forces you to really plan strategically on the game map as well as tactically fight on the battlefield. It is a great pity that the game also has some shortcomings that spoil its course and the impression of it. It is all the more a pity that Red Dragon is not the first kind of such a game from the same manufacturer. For example, the passability of the terrain is greatly simplified. A tank rising to the top of a rock, or the passage of heavy equipment through a dense forest or even a building, is something you will have to get used to quickly, otherwise you will wonder "how that tank got behind your lines when you cover the whole valley with mountains like Mount Everset around. ”The tutorial is very weak, and you can only really master the game after dozens of fights of all kinds. During the fighting, you will find that some units (eg helicopters and ships) are OPs and that the prices of deployment do not always correspond to the potential quality. On the contrary, the vehicles are so poorly appreciated in the game that you rarely include them in your set and they are not even used by AI. The creation of the set is very diverse, but I really lack a free hand to perfection. I am glad that the authors do not forget about the game and complement the countries, even though it is in the form of quite expensive DLC. However, I am a little surprised by the choice of countries. I understand the need to create a certain exoticism, but some of the leading countries of the time are still missing in the game. Finally, there is multiplayer, which is the real pearl of this game. Sufficient player base is a guarantee that finding more opponents in a short time is not a problem and also the game against AI is very good. Long fights in which you sweat a little are no exception. I recommend the game despite several shortcomings. Thanks.

Hra vyniká kvalitnou umelou inteligenciou a strhujúcim priebehom bojov. Vďaka možnosti ovládania rýchlosti plynutia času si hru môžete vychutnať do detailu a aj počas ťažkých bojov máte dostatok času na premyslenie ďalšieho postupu. Kampaň pre jedného hráča je náročná už na ľahkej obťažnosti, čo považujem za veľké plus, pretože vás hra núti naozaj strategicky plánovať na hernej mape ako aj takticky bojovať na bojisku. Je veľká škoda, že hra má aj niektoré nedostatky, ktoré kazia jej priebeh a dojem z nej. Je to o to väčšia škoda, že Červený drak nie je prvým druhom takejto hry od toho istého výrobcu. Napríklad prechodnosť terénu je veľmi zjednodušená. Tank štverajúci sa na vrchol skaly, či prechod ťažkej techniky cez hustý les alebo dokonca budovy, je vecou, na ktorú si budete musieť rýchlo zvyknúť, inak sa budete čudovať „ako sa ten tank dostal za vaše línie, keď kryjete celé údolie pričom naokolo sú hory ako Mount Everset.“ Tutoriál je veľmi slabý a hru skutočne zvládnete až po desiatkach odohraných súbojov všetkého druhu. Počas bojov zistíte, že niektoré jednotky (napr. helikoptéry a lode) sú OP a že ceny nasadenia nie vždy odpovedajú potenciálnej kvalite. Naopak vozidlá sú v hre tak veľmi slabo ocenené, že ich do svojej zostavy zaradíte len veľmi zriedkavo a dokonca ich nevyužíva ani AI. Tvorba zostavy je veľmi rôznorodá, no k dokonalosti mi chýba skutočne voľná ruka. Som rád, že autori nezabúdajú na hru a dopĺňajú krajiny, aj keď je to vo forme dosť drahých DLC. Som však trocha prekvapený výberom krajín. Chápem potrebu vytvoriť určitú exotiku, ale v hre stále chýbajú niektoré vedúce krajiny tej doby. Nakoniec je tu multiplayer, ktorý je skutočnou perlou tejto hry. Dostatočná hráčska základňa je zárukou, že nájsť viacerých súperov v krátkom čase nie je problém a rovnako aj hra proti AI je veľmi dobrá. Dlhé boje, pri ktorých sa poridane zapotíte nie sú žiadnou výnimkou. Hru odporúčam napriek niekoľkým nedostatkom. Ďakujem.
10/10 would buy DLC again.

Red Dragon is a fun and mostly good addition to the Wargame line, a game I've spent time on and off playing as I go from one RTS to another, and it pretty much satisfies that cold war aesthetic RTS itch. 

However, as you can see I am no recommending the game, and while I once and a while come back to enjoy the game, the developers seem to have completely given up on it years ago, the stories about them abandoning non-windows users is true, leaving many users screwed, and reducing an already dead playerbase. 

The Single player missions are interesting in concept, but are ruined because of AI literally being able to cheat against you, new players won't be able to beat it, however there are some really cheesy tactics you can use to basically win, which are only amusing once.

Skirmish mode is fun, but obviously won't keep your attention.

Game had a mostly dead community, so online experiences will vary depending on personal experience.


With the Developers long since abandoning this game, even though it's a game I mostly enjoy, I can't in good faith recommend it.

UPDATE:

It appears Eugen is returning with South Africa nation pack, so it appears they maybe giving some new support to this long dead game, I'm unsure why they're doing it, but it may change my recommendation for this game if they continue.

i bought this game originally like 1-2 years ago, played about 20 hours of it, and i just didn't have fun. but a few months ago, i've picked up the game again, reinstalled it, took some time to learn it. and OH MAN it is fucking incredible

if you look at the screenshots like some of the ones i've taken, it is amazing.
down to the littlest details, you can zoom in and watch your units fight, but not just normal fighting, YOU can REALLY see down to the details. for example, you can zoom in from birds eye view to a soldier's view. watch your infantry fight alongside your IFVs and tanks, whilst tracer rounds fly by and ricochet off the ground, explosions booming around the camera, the earth becoming scorched from the fire around your units.

and this is just ground combat, there's also airplanes, CAS, fighter jets, artillery, hundreds of units, etc, to play, most of them with different weaponry and stats. (ignore the lame naval combat pls)
did i mention you can also use a variety of units from different time periods of the cold war? T-34s, sherman tanks, STUG III's against modern tanks, always hilarious to play despite the old ass tanks getting one tapped by abrams. and occasionally i get a lucky side shot, killing a modern tank with some outdated 80 year old tank

despite having a steep learning curve, it is definitely worth learning in the end. after about 45 hours of playing along with a few tutorials and guides, i learnt how to kick ass against AI. BUT it is even more fun with [b] FRIENDS. [/b] [strike] if you don't have friends, i'm sorry. [/strike] ((but playing with friends and getting to learn the game with them is SO MUCH MORE FUN than playing with random people or alone))

again, highly recommended game if you love large scale combat whilst still being fast paced and arcadey. i tend to find the game pretty casual to play with friends, but you still have to be on your toes and micromanage a lil bit either way.
different style than you typical c&c rts, but, very welcomed if you have friends for skirmishes

There is no point in reviewing Wargame: Red Dragon in 2020. Everything famous or infamous about this game is already out in the wide open. This review instead is intended to be a eulogy to Eugene Systems and the RTS Magnum Opus known as the Wargame series.

My first exposure to Wargame was through European Escalation. At the time, Red Dragon was brand new and superseded Airland Battle as the most relevant. I was terrible at all three of them. My friends talked me into these titles by saying my weird, obscure knowledge of Cold War era Eastern and Western military hardware would be an asset because I wouldn’t need to dig into unit stats as often to know what a unit’s capabilities are. This is both true and remarkably false at the same time for reasons I’ll touch on below, but it was enough to push me into these games.

The next year or so consisted of a cycle of picking one of the games, attempting to play, getting frustrated at how bad I was at it, and not touching it again for another couple months. It wasn’t until European Escalation and Airland Battle’s multiplayer was effectively 100% dead and I started consuming guides through Youtube and the Steam Community Page that I started to become “not garbage” at this game and play more regularly. The fact I had to do this is my biggest gripe about Red Dragon and the Wargame series as a whole.

As I mention in my Don’t Starve Together review, I have a natural disdain for games where I have to spend a stupid amount of time reading out of game, unsupported literature to learn how to play. Wargame anything is the epitome of that, which probably explains why the only people who still play it are racist, neckbearded, and likely unemployed, armchair generals (more on this below). The only reason I was able to get to a point where I could hold my own (not get decimated in two minutes) in this game was because I was in college at the time and I was able to put the reading time in between classes and my part time jobs. I have ~300 hours or so logged in this game. A third of those were probably spent building “decks”, which are essentially the combinations of units made up of “cards” of certain experience levels and quantities that you go to battle with in a game. I know not exactly how much time I’ve spent reading or watching videos / tutorials on this game, but it is probably ~24-48 hours of my life.

Simply put, there isn’t really a tutorial in this game, or any of the Wargame titles for that matter. The closest the series ever came to having anything that was actually valuable as instructional material was the campaign in European Escalation and it isn’t very helpful. This segues conveniently into my next point which is IF YOU’RE GOING TO BUY THIS GAME IN 2020, SAVE THE CASH AND ONLY GET RED DRAGON. Seriously, multiplayer in Airland Battle and European Escalation is “totally dead” as opposed to the “kinda dead” multiplayer in Red Dragon. Additionally, the game controls and feels ever so slightly (and annoyingly) different in the previous title. Red Dragon is the most refined title in this regard. 

I really rip on this game above, but I sincerely love playing it. The single player campaigns are all based on things that could have happened, there’s a lot of attention to detail in regards to the units and their capabilities, and it's a genuinely challenging RTS. The game is not receiving any official updates or balances anymore, but just know this: The balancing history for this game was frustrating as all living hell. We all expect small balance tweaks and adjustments in a game like this, but most of the ones I remember were HUGE. For example, entire infantry squads of a certain class were cut from 15-man groups to 10-man groups, entire vehicles changed category, and napalm based weapons were changed to not do damage anymore for some reason. You have it good if you’re getting this game now because you have no expectations, just remember that.

 If this goes on sale and you like RTS games, get it. Be forewarned though, it is a steep learning curve and the “Warchat” is full of people saying some very racist things for no reason other than because they can. Despite the issues and neckbeards, please keep this game alive. We won’t get another one like it and it needs to be appreciated while there is still a player base.

04/29/21 Edit: While multiplayer was certainly "dying" at the time this review was published, the game appears to be getting some more attention now due to a recent free release on the Epic Games Store. Eugen Systems apparently has control over the Wargame IP again and is developing a South Africa nation pack DLC.

A very solid RTS that hold up well. While the game itself has its own issues such as brain dead unit path finding in towns, limited single-player content beyond a basic skirmish (with a basic AI) or five campaigns (decent replay value, but the aforementioned AI doesn't lead to very interesting battles) and the near total lack of modding support (that's not to say there aren't mods, just not many), the real issue could perhaps be considered to be the community. Being an older game the community is rather developed (if small) and have some experience under their belt, and not everyone is tolerable to newer players. Often people's first games are total defeats, being wiped clean from the field. And that is if they actually made it to the field and weren't kicked/banned from the lobby for being new. Therefore, I recommend if you do pick this game up (because it really is good, grab the DLC too if you can because Reds and Israel are busted AF, NL is still good but just not as insane) look into the Wargame Boot Camp discord and some video tutorials (in-game one isn't great). Committing time to learn the game makes it easier for you to get into and enjoy the game and might save you some grief from teammates.

This game has a huge learning curve; however, once you get the hang of things, it offers infinite replayability due to the vast amount of strategies and decks you can create. If you like modern military RTS, there is no game that can match Wargame: Red Dragon.

A tip to new players... DO NOT play online initially. Learn the game via the campaign and by skirmishing the AI. Watch as many Youtube videos as you can about how to build decks and play matches. Don't make the mistake I did and kill your W/L ratio by playing online first. There is no matchmaking, so veteran players often lure new players into playing SUPER unbalanced games. Join a discord community with veterans. They will most likely be happy to teach you the basics, or at least lead by example when you play games with them.

But the community toxicity is MORE THAN WORTH IT. This game has given me hundreds of hours of fun and challenge. I can't recommend it enough.

One of the best strategy games I've ever played. It can be frustrating if you play it and pretend it is like "Age of Empires", the realism and thoroughness they have dedicated to this game makes it way more strategic. The goal in each map is to capture sectors of cities or fields, and earn capture points in order to be able to unfold the rest of your reserve troops. Once you start to understand the mechanics of the units you will develop your own personal tactics which will make it even more interesting. Try it online as well, you reinforce a lot of your tactics  and it is easy to hop into any match, very fun in teams of 2. Dont be carried away by the shiny armoured units, planes and helicopters, use your infantry way more often, this is the key to victory. You will be frustrated if you overspend on the cool units...they will be blown up by the soldiers as quickly as they were brought into the field. The maps are great, bushes, hills, forests, buildings, you can use the context to your advantage in many original ways. The detail and care put into the game, is just excellent.

Following on from the brilliant Air Land Battle, Red Dragon offers revised nations and Naval Warfare. The latter does not really appeal to me and I often wish they would have just run with an amphibious aspect of the game as the ships are just broken IMO. Which is a shame as no doubt the developers put a lot of time developing the units.

As you can see from the number of hours I have ploughed into this game, I like it and why not. It is a very unique game and nearly all games played on MP are going to be different with the number of viable nations and coalitions. Like ALB it has a near vertical learning curve. So if you have skipped previous incarnations of this game them you might be in for a bit of a hard time. Don't be put off. You can play against the A.I which might cheat and not simulate human tactics and play. They will allow you to get to grips of what units do what. Also how to use them effectively. However this will require some watching of you tube to get peoples views on deck building. As deck building is the core of the game. There are no bases to build, however in certain game modes occupying territory yields an income of sorts to buy units from your pre-configured deck.

The game has been out for over a year now and this means that new players really stand out. However the forum is a good place to post and organise games with newer players. Smaller games are a great way to really appreciate the game. 1v1 up to 4v4 (other variations are available but require dedicated server support). In house games are a great way to learn to play and offer feedback to mates after a game. Again there are more experienced players out there who offer tuition as they want to add to the community.

10 v 10 is great fun and can be quite a punishing place if you are new. As new players have a tendancy to quit the game once they lose an initial push or are overrun. This has a big impact on the players left on the game and which is why a lot of newer players tend to receive the cold shoulder by some players. On the reverse of that it is also a gaming environment where new players mistakes can be corrected by other stronger players. As long you aren't feeding units to the enemy in the games most dominant game mode. Destruction, basically awards points for killing certain units with a set value. More expensive units give higher points.

To summarise a great game with fantastic MP, it has been out a while so expect to do a bit of homework for MP games. If you wish to win that is. Alternatively play it with mates in your own in house environment until you are up to speed. A truly glorious game that deserves a thriving community, unlike the dwindling one of current. Hopefully Eugen will pull another out of the bag.
