In short , this game is much more punishing than other modern RTS games and may be not a good taste for you if you are a casual player . 

In this game unit die very fast , slow to reinforce , can't be built and heavily rely on vision which lead to many situations in which player can just camp inside wood and building , freely destroy enemy and only need to move to dodge incoming arty strike . 

For single player campaign , Eugen is kinda famous for making hard campaign without difficulties toggle , the A.I always know where your units are and move accordingly , along with the problem above can give you quite a headache . 

I installed and uninstalled this game many times , this is the first RTS game that did made me feel frustrate , as a casual player . 

However don't let this review discourage you from trying this game out . Perhaps you will feel at home with the complex tactic this game can offer .  If you a casual player who want more control on unit engagement and production , you gonna have a bad time .

My god, where to begin with this near-masterpiece of a game? Be forewarned: this is a REVIEW, not some pathetic little story, profoundly lame joke or cooking recipe. If you want something stupid to read, look anywhere else.

I guess I’ll start with the obvious thing: gameplay. This game is very complex, and I’d only recommend it to an RTS pro who has several RTS games under his or her belt. If you’ve played a game called “R.U.S.E” (which has since been taken off of Steam for reasons unknown), then this game will be very similar to that (not surprising given that the game was made by the same developers, Eugen Systems) one. However, if you’ve played numerous RTS games but haven’t played R.U.S.E, R.U.S.E isn’t mandatory to be able to play – it just makes things a bit easier to learn.

What’s totally insane is the extreme level of detail and diversity when it comes to units. Where R.U.S.E had 7 nations; Wargame: Red Dragon has 21 nations (split between NATO and the Warsaw Pact) with a collective total of over a thousand units. Just like R.U.S.E, each nation has its strengths and weaknesses, but unlike R.U.S.E, you can actually mix and match units from the same faction into a “deck” (to be clear, you cannot have Soviet and NATO troops in the same deck, but you can have, say, British, Canadian and South Korean units in the same NATO deck, or Polish, North Korean and Chinese units in a Warsaw Pact deck); a deck is your deployment group of what units you can call in. There’s lots of units in the game and some of them may look incredibly similar (in rare, rare cases, some are just reskins of other nations’ units) but there are statistical differences that affect your units’ performances, so I recommend looking up guides and videos on what nations’ strengths are. I’m not going to get into depth about that.

Graphically, and as far as detail goes, this game is INCREDIBLE to look at, even when you zoom in real close. The details on just about everything are absolutely marvelous, from water effects to miniature explosions when a tank gets blown to pieces.

Difficulty-wise, this game actually has a unicorn-rare feature that I haven’t seen properly exercised in almost any other RTS game: you can actually choose how the AI, both AI teammates and AI enemies, play the game, because you can set what decks the AI uses. If you want to play like a wimp and give them really crappy units while you roll out the best tanks in the game, be my guest. If the AI’s abusing artillery, you can make a deck that omits artillery so they won’t be able to deploy any. If you want to have an infantry-only war but you have no friends to do it with (this isn’t a guide on how to make friends, so don’t even ask), you can just create a deck with only infantry units in it, assign it to an AI, and you’ll be good to go.

The only issue that makes me call this a “near-masterpiece” was some lag when playing with three friends against four AI, which resulted in one of my friends being dropped from the game. Occasionally it’ll also lag without warning; the battlefield will freeze but after 5-15 seconds it’ll start again.

It is a pretty solid title for strategy game, bonus points for not being WW2. It has a wide array of nations and kit, and you can put a lot of hours into it. It lacks the coop and VS campaign of the old titles but still holds weight in the scenario based campaign. Though one should not take this to seriously as a sort of simulator strategy game. If you want a simulator, play games like Combat Mission: Shock Force 2, Combat Mission: Black Sea, and other such titles. As for Wargame, it is more meant to be played as a sort of arcade like strategy game, with a solid amount more realism then titles like COH and MoW. Another note of warning, this is best played among friends of yours. Going in this against the usual online players, you will get curbstomped fast. Most people still playing this have, for a very long time, and know every trick in the book. Still with all of this it is a fairly fun game that I have put a lot of hours into and has birthed a plethora of memes. If you enjoy Mauzerwave, and war aesthetics, you will appreciate this game.

RTS was a dead genre for some time, and yet the Wargame series seemed to have potential. Probably because it was a game that focused on a rather modern era. It gained attention for simulating somewhat a modern battleground. Ironically, the developers went on and made a generic WW2 game afterwards. Kinda unfortunate considering the fact that people were genuinely excited that more nation packs could be added to this game and could be kept alive.

There was a time when the Wargame forum was always filled with new posts and debates about the game or new countries. But now, the community seems pretty much dead and although there are still a lot of people out there playing, the in-game chat is full of racist, uneducated and idiotic people. To this day I wonder why the Dev's would put all their attention to Steel Division and totally abandon the Wargame series.

I'm assuming there will be no updates in this game anymore(and it didn't have any for some time). But if you're interested in a modern RTS game, this game is probably the best choice on the market. If the Dev's poured more effort to this series maybe it would have been more successful, but it's already too late. 

Many people that still play this game is harsh to new comers. If the Dev's bad decision was the start of the end, the attitude of the current players is slamming the final nail on the coffin.

I am a total n00b in this game, but 30 hours of campaign play already made me too excited to sleep for many nights. It really feels like a dream game for cold war fans like me.

The game may lack a tutorial but it is easy to familiarize with the controls and make your own gameplay if you keep playing the campaign, making some saves and doing skirmishes.
When assessing the enemies battle strength on each front, you will suddenly become Admiral Thrawn. You start learning what you're enemy is gonna do with what they have and where they will focus that force.

I don't got an essay to type. So I'll just say that the game is fun to play when you learn to play the game and find your play style.

This game has a really steep learning curve. I've played 162 hours and still lose if I neglect one small detail. 

It's micro management on a macro scale. You can control hundreds of infrantrymen and dozens of tanks, helicopters and fighter jets all at once. You better hit that bong AFTER you've got everything set up and rolling because even on the Easy setting, you'll get ran over like a steam train if you aren't 100% ready to go. 

I honestly play with AI Aircraft OFF on most games, unless you're ready to lose every one of your units every single time within 5 minutes of starting the game. I'll be the first to admit enemy Air-Power is WAY too outrageous. God help you on the campaigns. 

No it's not the perfect game but it's so much fun to see what would happen if a Soviet Tank division went up against a US Marine Corps group. 

Mi-25's against Cobra's. Sheridan Tanks against T-72's. M16's vs AK-47. It's basically the ultimate Cold War "What If" game and I'll play for years to come.

Review: 
Wargame, that was a great idea. But it has gotten into the wrong hands! 
Beware, if you buy Wargame, you will first think of it as a shining star in RTS heaven, but that is only half the truth.
If you stay some time you will notice, that you are in RTS hell in many regards.

With Wargame:Red Dragon you will sell your soul to one of the most biased and ignorant game developers and hosters ever. FOCUS is lieing to your face with their shining trailers that do not reflect the gameplay in any facette. While this is not to uncommon for advertising, it comes worse. They also praise this as the "best naval battles ever", which is a plain lie. Prepare to be disappointed by the naval component of this game.
FOCUS is also most incompetent when it comes to support. Today is release day and there are still douzens of technical issues, random crashes, graphic bugs, AI bugs, HUD failures compatibily bugs and so on. If you visit the tech forum you will notice that only 1 of hundred threads is even answered by FOCUS, not to mention solved...
When contacting a Moderator or FOCUS administrator, dont expect to be answered ever, no matter whats the issue.

EUGEN.
EUGEN has found a diamond of an RTS and decided not to polish it at all. Its the best RTS game ever made in the hands of all the wrong people. 
Its really a shame, that a bunch of developers can ignore major parts of their community even after almost three years of often very detailed and intelligent feedback in their forums. 
EUGEN has the bad attitude to send their trolling Communtiy Masters into the board, which do nothing but posting memes or give some random comments, often with a very arrogant and ignorant tone.
They will not listen to your suggestions.
They will not answer your requests
They will treat you like you are some nationalist if you raise your voice for your favourite nation 
They will not let you play Wargame they way YOU like, but make you play it how they want.

You already looking forward to play YOUR favourite nation, be it NATO or PACT?
Forget it! All you get is the same crippled decks we had in AirLandBattle. 
Want to play this game competetive and enjoy it the same time?
Forget it. The only way you can play competetive is by exploiting the weak new deck system to the extend.
You like infantry? Forget it. Welcome to the worst inf META since Suddenstrike 1. 
Like city fights? Welcome to the short range teleporting starcraft mod Red Dragon with the worst city fight solution possible.
You like planes?
Face the worst deck setup ever which allows you to spam a colorfull vairety of planes, but only 1 or 2 of the ones you really want to use (the whole game!).
You like Helicopters? Feel free to rage hard on their nonexistent Unit AI, worst pathfinding, altitude management, movement behaviour and spotting issues. Using helicopters is like playing lottery, no matter how hard you try. And you will soon learn to hate the Message "Angle to high - cannot target" or seeing your helis lose their LOS during firing for no reason.


Wanna join a prosperating, friendly community? 
Forget it. Thanks to the non-existent balancing of PACT vs NATO, Coalitions, nations and navy you will have to choose bteween beeing Pub Stomped from Premades, playing with incompetent random players who are so afraid of doing anything that they virtually do nothing. 
Ah, oh you play 10vs10 just to find yourself inside of the worst lag and spam fest ever in the history of RTS.

What else you get:
Impossible video options to make the game running smooth and look relatively good the same time (worst optimization ever)
Bad Interface options (everything will always be in your way)
Annoying sound when zoomed out. It was critized since 2 years, EUGEN decided not to change it. Prepare to get ear cancer when not listen to music the same time. 
No really usefull lobby options. The game is still virtually restricted to the most unfunny parts. 
Replay value is the lower than in ALB and EE.

My advice: dont buy this game. Wait for a 10 EUR weekend sale, maybe until then the game is at least stable. 
Dont expect anything else to happen. In three weeks of BETA the game meta was not changed at all and community feedback ignored 99%.

Dont feed EUGEN trolls with your money.

Probably the best RTS game out there! In this Cold War gone hot game, you are a commander of an army of a certain country you chose. Here you got two factions, as you guessed, the NATO (Including Japan and South Korea) and Warsaw Pact (Including China, North Korea, and Yugoslavia). Each factions and country got their own unique weapon and vehicle, dating back from World War 2 until the Late-Cold War tech. In this game you have to think fast and act fast or the next think you knew was your army being overwhelmed. Here, they also got campaign and skirmish which you can play solo with bot or together with other players on multiplayer. Anyway, game is a 10/10 for me and is highly recommended.

Excellent strategy game - it plays much like World in Conflict (and not just because of the Cold-War-gone-hot scenario), except on a larger scale. It does have a very steep learning curve: the tutorial is so useless as to be effectively a huge waste of man hours during development, and the community is absolutely venomous at times (we're talking League of Legends-tier), so learning through watching YouTube videos (BoltSauce is a particularly good channel) is the best way to proceed. There you'll quickly get a good grasp of which units are best to use for what purpose, as well as what the various decks and unit tabs do. 

Wargame: Red Dragon is best played with friends, either versus each other or against the AI. Be warned, however: the AI may have its derpy moments (get used to finding BMP-2s in the middle of rivers or even the open ocean, having run out of fuel), but don't underestimate the ingenius simplicity of its tactics. Oftentimes rushing hordes of tanks really [i]is[/i] the best way to break through a defensive line, and on any difficulty higher than Easy, any units you use to engage the enemy WILL get shelled and/or bombed. But devoting time to working out the AI's various quirks, through observation or studious post-battle analysis of replays, can be just as fun as the battles themselves.

Overall, would strongly recommend Wargame as a solid and surprisingly realistic take on modern-ish military strategy gaming.

This is strictly MY OPINION.
You don't have to agree with it and you are entitled to your own.


[h1] GENERAL CONSIDERATIONS [/h1]
- I liked the game but it is best for professional military and war fans with a lot of patience and attention to details, along with a strategic vision for using multiple units at the same time. If you want to just have fun, maybe it is not your best choice.
- Be warned: this is not the norm RTS. It is like a genuine military war-games simulator. It has a huge array of MICROMANAGEMENT options that you have to attend if you want to see the missions completed, be it in campaign or skirmish mode (just check the Controls section for a starter).
- Thumbs-up for ultrawide support. I gave a negative vote only because I expected something else from the advertised "the new reference in RTS" (in my opinion, yet an unfulfilled wish).and I thought the price is a bit too high for what it has to offer. Still, I bought the game because I like military simulators and to encourage developers because it is clearly a hard and thoughtful worked game.
- The game is very good for a military map strategy simulator. It's like playing two different modes, a strategic global view and a tactical close-up view (zoom levels). They each are great but they just don't mix together quite properly. You can enjoy either one or the other.
- The main issue of this game for the regular player is a Clausewitz nightmare: it combines all three operational levels in one: a strategic map with a strategic picture of the whole region, an operational level for each area of operations (Alpha, Bravo, Charlie, etc. where you must conquer sections) and a tactical level of micromanagement for each set of units you are sending in combat (care for how, when and where you combine your units, lots of detailed information about each unit and tons of things to watch and to do, including resupplying, defending, reinforcing etc.). On top of that, you have limited troops you can send in combat based on the command points you obtain through combat and objectives capture. 
- Your eyes can get stuck with a wall of labels moving on a map for hours, I don't find that very enjoyable (I recommend you go to User Interface and select Icons Type - NATO, Labels Size - Small, Label Style - European Escalation and Label Size in Multiple Selection - Minimal, in order to minimize the impact of those many labels on screen). At times you may feel like a general in front of a big map in High Command.
- The game has a proper name ""war-games"", it does a very good job at that and it should be called simulator but not RTS game.
- I enjoyed playing this game in skirmish mode (vs AI).
- The game has good potential but imo needs more to become "the new reference in RTS genre" or maybe it just needs less micromanagement and more fun, it is kind of too realistic and detailed in military strategy, operations and tactics at the same time (therefore I said I would recommend it to professionals).
- Classic RTS games are about resources / economy / troops building and management along with terrain and objectives management. This game has a different approach, you get everything you want, just need to focus on fighting (troops / terrain / objectives) but with a lot of micromanagement. I am NOT saying it is a bad thing, though. It's just a different approach and can be enjoyable. But it's not for the average player.
- The game offers A LOT of info (as troops morale, ammo reloading status, weaponry caliber, range, accuracy,mechanical issues, repair status and such) but they are not of real use in the big picture and should not be included in an RTS either. The relevant info is the supply status of the units (fuel and ammo).
- Unfortunately, the campaign mode has no decent story and focuses on 4X turn-based features rather than RTS.
- The game is good for military exercises (Blue vs Red) in skirmish, plenty of maps and commands available, using all types of units.
- I expected more from a 2014 game. Better graphics, smarter concepts and a story.
- In my opinion, the price should be around $15 (especially 5 years after release).
- Yes, I did.play the campaigns and skirmish and the vote is only for these. Please consider that **I DID NOT TRY THE MULTIPLAYER** side of the game, it may provide a nicer feeling and better opinions.

[h1] CAMPAIGN [/h1]
- The game does well on the turn-based features.
- The campaigns are quite short and with no decent story, in fact some of the most arid campaigns I ever played in an RTS.
- The real-time feature (aka the RTS side) of the campaigns, where you choose to lead your own battles instead of auto-resolving is poorly implemented, it looks quite ugly and definitely is not giving you the joy of massive scale RTS battles nor it has much strategy in it since you cannot diversify units production, upgrades and such.

[h1] SKIRMISH [/h1]
- The skirmish is the diamond of this game. You must try it, it has maps up to 4vs4 against AI or real players.
- It is fun up to a point and provides large scale battles with a ton of units.
- The interface is a bit uncommon for an RTS and you can find at times wondering what group of units is doing what and where.
- Too many labels on the screen, it looks like a military map (good for strategic decisions) but  makes you lose focus of the tactic side and POIs (points of interest) where you want to perform an action, conquer an objective and actually enjoy the game visually. Basically it is like this: zooming out at max it is a map full of labels you don't need. Zooming in at max it is pretty well rendered units but you totally lose control of the big picture. Zooming in just as to control your units and feel the battle, the picture you see is not an enjoyable one (not much to see) and still too many and too big labels. 
- The "Speed" feature is good probably for lazy players but great for simulations. A good skirmish can extend up to two hours or even more if you play with AI on Very Hard.
- Units go straight through any type of environment (literally) be it house, tree, water, rock, other unit. the collision mechanic works rather not. The no-clip problem is something I can forgive. Zooming function has issues sometimes.
- The AI is sometimes behaving strange and just stops its units doing nothing (even if resupplied or fresh) or takes very wrong decisions. I also saw quite often AI units (including infantry) going straight through the burning ground (taking useless damage and morale impact) after the area was spammed with missiles and incendiaries.

[h1] CONCLUSION [/h1]
- The game is great and as I mentioned, with a lot of patience and love for details micromanagement. Best for people with a military professional background.
- Before ranting about my playtime, please refresh your browser and check again.  Not that you would need a lot of time to see what a game can and cannot.
- I played my fair share of games and about all good RTS games around for many years and I will repeat the fact that the game HAS potential, and it's great for war-games but to be named RTS it needs more polish, content, a story and less micromanagement.
- What an RTS game is in my opinion, actually one that gives you playing satisfactions without combining all three military operational levels and without micromanagement headaches, just to exemplify:
** Command & Conquer series.
** Stracraft series
** Halo Wars series. 
** Sudden Strike series.
** Company of Heroes series.
** World in Conflict.
** Age of Empires series (not all of AoE games).
** Total War series (not all of Total War games).

Back when I used to play this, I genuinely used to have nightmares/dreams about this game, something like the [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetris_effect]Tetris effect[/url] as I used to play this game a lot.
Usually they are losing games where I end up having to pull the entire team or suffering a small percentage of the pain as my units in the field, as well as feeling my brain "sizzle" in frustration (just bad dreams, not really nightmares). So I guess this game somehow manages to qualify for "Haunts my Dreams".[/spoiler]

---

[h1]THE REVIEW:[/h1]

It's a good game and a last hurrah for the Wargame series and maybe even Eugen as a whole (sorry, I'm not getting Steel Division, this is the end here). I've been a long time supporter of Eugen back during R.U.S.E. These series have been my dream game (not related to the nomination) come true: A real-time RTS with a myriad of military units from various nations. In the Wargame series there is depth, there is detail, and most importantly, there is fun in both victory as you steamroll the enemy and play hide-and-seek with the last CV, and there is fun in defeat as you fling insults on the enemy, your teammates, and Eugen for making the game unbalanced/unfinished/shit...etc.

Red Dragon, like the rest of the Wargame series is pretty good. It got all the good and bad points of its two previous games (European Escalation, and Airland Battle). There are two main features of RD:
-Adds various East Asian armies and Australia, as well as Finland, Yugoslavia, Netherlands, and Israel (if you count the DLC) to the Wargame roster. Loads of fun for both PACT and NATO, and a nice break from the European theatre of EE and ALB. The timeframe is also shifted a little bit into the '90s, which may be a little late and too fictional for some Cold War enthusiasts (like me). Somewhat related is that there are "prototype" units for several of the armies in-game, which is a bit too much bullshit for my tastes. like the Fallschrimjäger '90 back when the game was newly released.

-Naval warfare, which is unfortunately very "basic" and very disappointing. Unlike the introduction of fixed-wing aircraft in ALB, the very feature that RD was made for comes very short of expectations. The scaling and range of the weapons systems are just not ideal in many ways. That being said, ships are still relatively fun to use. There is nothing better than seeing an amphibious assault successfully land on the enemy's side on Wonsan, Gunboat, or D-Day. My favorite combination:
Landing craft INF, recon, AA + Smoke screen + Landing CV + Heli support + Naval support = Capture the enemy's main spawn = Easy win.

---

[h1]Q&A:[/h1]

[b]Q:[/b] Is it ded?
[b]A:[/b] There are enough players if you are looking for a game.

[b]Q:[/b] Is it hard?
[b]A:[/b] If you got a knack for RTS games, then this will be a fun game to learn. Otherwise, it will be a bit challenging. It isn't anywhere near CMANO, that's for sure.
In the end, you should be able to identify and generally remember the stats of most of the units ingame. As soon as you see "Unit name", you should be able to know what you are up against, how counter it, and what extras come with it. I don't mean literally memorize, but generally remember so you can make a quick decision instead of hovering over unit, pressing TAB, and reading everything all over again...
(I can't say it's hard myself since I've been playing Eugen RTS games since R.U.S.E. and EE.)

[b]Q:[/b] Should I buy the game?
[b]A:[/b] It's entirely up to you. If you have a hard-on for military hardware and troops, get this. If you get a raging boner dreaming about "Cold War gone hot" scenarios, get this (personally I prefer EE or ALB). If you get wet thinking about fucking around, spouting memes like an immature fag in the menu lobby chat instead of playing the game itself, get this. If you just want a good quality real-time RTS that offers a unique experience, definitely get it.

[b]Q:[/b] Thoughts and opinions?
[b]A:[/b] I used to play 10v10 tactical/low income to make up for my toaster PC. The worst aspect of this game is the community and other players on your team. Sometimes you strike gold and end up with an excellent team, or the enemy ends up with a shitty team. Sometimes, it's just not your lucky day: People not using recon, falling to obvious traps, inadequate air defense, artillery spam...etc. If you do get this game, prepare to be frustrated. Unless you get some friends to play with, or join normal servers (that are obviously not hosted by friends stacked on the same team). Also, for your own sake, mute the menu lobby chat unless you want cancer. This is the only noteworthy thought/opinion. You will really see what ESRB's "Game experience may change during online play" means.

There is no better modern military RTS out there. It's simply the best and it'll stay that way until Eugen decided to make a Wargame 4.

In the first 5-10 hours you'll feel like you are banging your head against a brickwall - because it is not a easy game to learn, and even harder to master. You will be completely overwhelmed and desperately trying to save your combat lines. If you don't make it through this stage and uninstall I wouldn't blame you. It isn't for everyone.

But if you make it past that painful 10 hours, you'll start to appreciate that this game is less game but more of a chess game. You are in command of an army that you can configure your way - and there is not a "right" way.

Do you want to have an elite group of army that is well-equipped and emphasize quality? You can do that.
Do you want to have swarms of soldiers and vehicles that doesn't neccessarily beats anyone 1 versus 1, but the sheer quantity would overwhelm any defensive line and lead you to victory. You can do that too.

The amount of freedom the game offers you is staggering, and there are so many variation you can set up your army its replayability is extremely high. You'll get your moneys worth out of it.

There are also many mods made for WG:RD. I personally recommend Ash and Shadows, which introduced the latest weaponry of today to the game + new mechanics (notably, active protection system). This game is one of the greats although I fully accept it'll forever be a niche game thats not for everyone.

Like no other game I have ever played.

By far the most complicated strategy game I have ever played to the point where at times its more of a puzzle game as you try to find the smallest weak point in your opponents front line. 

Every single match provides a new opportunity to improve your play style and work yourself closer to an unobtainable perfection. 

The multiplayer is unbelievably sweaty but with a group of similarly skilled friends the game is endlessly replayable.

This has honestly been a very fun game that for me, honestly did a relatively polished job of breaking out of the standard RTS spam like Command and Conquer games. You don't spam buildings, you bring in units and while volume of firepower has its worth, it can be usurped so quickly and brings a lot more realism to the genre of real time strategy games. 

That said, it does have a learning curve but I always take time aside for my friends to help them learn how to play this new game and we play almost weekly, sometimes daily, still after all of these years and has been a solid anchor game for my community.

If you like spending time learning about Cold War Era hardware and stuff, I think you'll find this a very pleasant game that tries to reflect a lot of the equipment you seen during the cold war years and see how effective and awesome it is. You will notice some "balance" mechanics compared to their real life counterparts, that were honestly very subtle. 

Just one thing, mute the Wargame Chat when you enter the game. For some reason this game has a highly cancerous community that hangs out in Wargame chat.

9/10, because Wargame Chat needs to be moderated after so many years and is honestly the most off-putting thing for everyone I know who has tried to play this game.

Off the bat the community ruins the game. Been years and you can still play on two teams with two computers or multi client. What has been happening since covid hit is a bunch of players playing both teams and having one side feed like crazy. Guys who are more subtle just snipe all the radar AA or infantry in buildings and call it a day. They usually do not snipe command vehicles off the bat. They also largely leave artillery alone unless they get mad. Another issue is balancing artillery. IRL infantry dig in once they hit an objective in a peer war. This makes them nearly impossible to kill using just artillery. Infantry are also too easy to spot. In real life tanks rarely spot infantry unless they are incredibly careless. Another issue is even when you use smoke, as long as one unit has LOS on your push the entire line can still shoot with accuracy. In this regard airland battle is a superior game by virtually every account from map design to the way units are modeled in the game.

Wargame is to RTS is what Arma is to FPS. It's a relatively realistic (as opposed to most other titles) tactical battle strategy game set in 1980s-1990s. The learning curve is a little steep, with so many units and nations playable, so knowing a bit about real-life weapon systems and their (rough) specs will really help you to get started and there's quite a few replay videos online that will help you get acquainted. Once you do, it's really fun to play both single and multiplayer.
A few words of caution though: Don't play this like your regular RTS; you'll lose very quickly. And stay away from the Warchat unless you want brain cancer.
There are only 3 things bad about this:
1) The "tutorial" is a joke. Just go and play easy singleplayer for your first game--you'd probably lose unless you've played something similar, but you'll learn a lot more.
2) Mod support is pathetic. I could only wish this is as customizable as Arma, but sadly, no.
3) DLC nations are a bit OP, and so they're must haves if you want to play online competitively. Just get those during steam sale.

One of the finest strategy games ive had the pleasure to play. punishing, realistic, steep learning curve for multiplayer. There are minor discrepancies in some of the units in how they should look vs how they are modelled ingame, but still worlds ahead in realism beyond any game ive played in the genre. I hope they continue to make more in the series. If they would just un**** their campaign mode and allow coop/competetive campaign, this would be my "total war" game covering the scope of the modern era 1960s-1990s. Your selection of units is so vast (over 1700 unique units last i checked) covering everything from warplanes to infantry to ships, tanks, helos, armored cav, air assault forces, AA, SAMs etc etc... that the people who inevitably cry: "That side is OP" "US too stronk" "new update makes game casul friendly" "USSR tank-rush new-meta" are missing the point. Modern militaries are simply unequal, not all technology held by one nation is comparable to that of others. Sometimes it is superior, sometimes downright inferior. But taken as an aggregate with so many advantages given to the various sides in DIFFERERENT ASPECTS of their forces (IE numerical advantage, accuracy, killing power, speed) It truly comes down to who is the better commander, something not easy to do in a HIGHLY asymmetric RTS.

UPDATE : 02/28/2020

Still playing this game..... now 6 years on -  almost 1400 hours and still loving the game. 

Why >? you may ask  well since my above statement still rings true I am going to give you a better break down and hopefully help people better understand this game especially if your new. 
1) i can not speak for single player option as i have not yet played them.

2) all online play mainly 10 v 10 matches

first you start by building a deck from a vast list of units and you choose the respective country you would like to play from the usa to france and for the soviet block the soviet union to north korea 

what way do you want to play ?

artillery and infantry ?   tanks and infantry ?  artillery ? offensive action or defensive play ?

AA cover ?      my best opinion and most success has come from having rapid fire artillery or mortars close by to support your infantry attacks and have aa to cover the attack close by keeping either 30mm or 20mm cannons and tanks close by for support.


this is why i love this game there is options galore and thinking must go into how your forces are going to take the next 500ft  then hold and secure it before your next move.

the risk of loosing your forces is what keeps you on edge, but when you know your ready to throw the dice throw them and see what happens. 

Patience is required in the game but as your progress it will keep you coming back. 

10/10 



  (your first step is to play a few games and make a few mistakes but pay attention to how everything pans out and how to lay out your units to best suit the situation.  make a few decks and have some fun, over time you will see how to best mix your units for Anti-Aircraft cover and making sure choke points and areas are garrisoned. 

 I never leave expensive units 80+ at the front line i will leave cheap units and infantry to control crossroads and hopefully they can hold them off untill i can bring up my support to either blunt and or counter attack them - if you do leave higher end units leave 1 or 2 spread  them out from different POV's and wait.

This is most likely my favorite game ever. If you like strategy games where the focus is on units management and not on construction of buildings and resources gathering then this is the game for you. The sheer amount of units and their statistics and battle prowess is amazing. The fact that you need to be able to combine different type of units (i.e. infantry, tanks, plane, AA and artillery) in order to achieve success is exactly what i look for in strategy games. I guess strategy game is perhaps not the best genre for this game is more a tactical game. The game is old yet the online community is strong and amazing.

Singleplayer experience: 5 campaigns, 80+ hours of battles, deep tactics, lots of units, good balance, great visuals (not that you would have time to appreciate the beauty in battle), mediocre AI with occasional hiccups.
Multiplayer experience: no 'matched play' option, no 'casual play' option, no 'skill-based balance', no 'quick search' option, hard to find game for a newbie (you may get kicked from a lobby or end up in a match that's too hard for you), no moderator in general chat and no profanity filter there. It seems like multiplayer community devolved into small airtight groups of 'good guys' scattered in generally toxic and uncooperative playerbase.

The game totally worth it if you want to play singeplayer campaigns, but multiplayer could prove to be unpleasant and demanding if you dindn't start playing on the release and don't have someone to show you the ropes.

This is the biggest, most ambitious of the excellent Wargame series. Expanding to combat on the seas, along with the already established air and land warfare, this large and deep cold-war era RTS is not for the faint hearted! With the scope enlarged from ALB and slow hedgerow battles of EE largely gone, this is all out modern warfare on a grand scale. 

The campaigns are a good intro, Skirmishes a great way to build your decks (and learn your enemy's), and mutiplayer is tactically brutal and strategically tense. With 100's of NATO and Warsaw Pact units to commit to battle, it is helpful if you have an interest in military units, their intended use and hard counters. 

For those who go as far into the RTS genre as C+C or Worms, this may not be for you. If you have many leather bound books on military history and generalship, then do try (and be patient with) this game. It rewards the keen commander with excellent gameplay. Thoroughly reccomended.

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

Wargame: Red Dragon is a game I recommend to any weapons and military nerds out there. I love this game but if you are buying it, you must know that it is not your average RTS game based on rock paper scissors. If you are into C&C or Company of Heroes, you may find it difficult to understand but if you are into the realistic military games genre, then you are in for a bliss. Here is my criticism of Wargame: Red Dragon.

[h1] Criticism [/h1] 

[b] Pros [/b]

+Accurately designed and depicted vehicles and units.

+Aesthetics of cold war.

Explanation: I am personally tired of seeing WW2 games as a person from a country that was neutral in the war, I don't feel the patriotic feelings a Russian or American player may feel while playing a WW2 game. Of course I am aware of the importance of WW2 but I just don't have the  same romantic appeal towards the genre. Since most game devs only know of American involvement in Vietnam, the cold war era was equally boring in video games. That's why I find Wargame: Red Dragon to be a gem. It allows  you to create what if's between other major powers in the cold war instead of just America! Hell yeah! stuff I keep seeing in other 'Cold War' games.

+Deck based forces.

Explanation: I was at first sceptical when I heard the game had card decks you have to go through but oh boy was I wrong in my assumptions. I have spent more time making decks or looking at the beautiful units and vehicles than I have in matches. The deck making can be complicated but once you get a hold of it, it becomes so much fun. You get to decide what units you want to bring into combat and design your own army. 

+/- The lack of a base building

Explanation: This may be a negative thing for some others but it does make sense in Wargame: Red Dragon. You will never see an army build a tank factory on the go in the front lines to magically spawn tanks in a few minutes, in real life. The only building there is is the FOB.

+Easy to set-up skirmish or multiplayer games.

+Over a thousand units! 

Note: All of them are unlocked and ready to go(if you have the nation unlocked some nations  come as DLCs), no microtransactions to unlock cards or custom stuff is a fresh sight.

+Active community on youtube and discord. There is help you can find anywhere, just avoid Warchat.

[b] Cons [/b]

-/+ The DLCs and the subject of Pay to Win.

Explanation: The DLCs add interesting nations but there is some criticism regarding them. Although, I do not consider the game a Pay 2 Win game but some of the DLC nations are unbalanced compared to the stock nations. 

-Lack of Moderation and the situation of Warchat.

Explanation: We all know that a lack of moderation and the presence of anonymity is a recipe for disaster online. Warchat is no exception. If you are new and want to learn how to play, avoid warchat and just look for youtube tutorials or a dedicated discord server. Warchat will give you 58 types of lung cancer.

-Eugen Syndrome.

Explanation: The devs have abandoned it for their next game, it is sad but it is the truth. Developers abandoning their hard working product is always sad to see.

-Hard to mod, the game is not friendly for modders.

-Lack of new maps. I have played it over 296 hours, there is more to do of course, there is always something to do, just playing  the same maps over and over again gets boring sometimes.

-Desynch of game in coop against AI and some other game breaking bugs.

-Barely any tutorial.

-Uninteresting and short Campaign against stupid bots with the intelligence of a toddler.

-Minor realism issues.

Explanation: Maybe I am just nitpicking and some features weren't added due to technical reasons but here are some minor problems I have with the game's claim of realism.

-Infantry combat is janky and models look weird, the infantry cannot use mortars, grenades. 

-Vehicles cannot deploy smoke screens, only some artillery pieces can. Vehicles also can only use commander's or the loader's machine guns/grenade launchers/autocannons. There is no coaxial weapon feature.

-Naval combat is fun but unfinished, it is open to too many exploits.

-AI is dumber than a rock and also cheats.

Graphics (9 of 10):  A superb and detailed rendering of real world vehicles.  Works well zooming in and out.  Would be great to have a way to make recordings or at least strip away all of the tags and extra to showcase games.

Audio (7 of 10):  Excellent, but voice dialog becomes repetitive very quickly.

Gameplay (9 of 10):  Some realism was sacrificed to provide for a better gaming experience.  Avoids making the game arcade like in its simulation, but simplifies where it helps.

Learning (8 of 10):  While the game has many units it is well balanced, learning the basics is fairly straightforward, especially if you're a student of military tactics.  If flanking, SEAD aircraft sorties, and Fire and Forget all sound like neat features you'll find them all.  Regrettably a detailed analysis of combat effectiveness is hidden as the combat statistics don't reflect in game realities.  For example high rate of fire weapons may go through ammo faster but may not attack any faster.

Stability and Bugs (10 of 10):  406 hours and no crashes, lockups, or hangs.  I wish Microsoft Windows was this stable.
Overall (8 of 10):  A superb, enjoyable game if you want a visually delightful military simulation.

I've put a lot of time into this game and the Wargame series in general (2k plus hours). It's not for everyone. It takes dedicated time and a lot of grief to learn units, maps, and gameplay. But nothing is more satisfying then being in an hour long back and forth where every movement and action has an effect on the outcome. If you want to play a game that is the best blend of tactical and rts cold war sim, this is it.

It's a challenging game and then some.  To coordinate diverse types of units in complex terrain takes some real planning and practice.  This is not like higher level grand strategy games like Paradox's Hearts of Iron series or Europa Universalis. Those are much more abstract and simplified in comparison.   In this game technical  particulars are important.  Indeed this is between the level of GS and First Person.  "Unlearn what you have learned young padwans"!

Best post Vietnam, pre-9 11 live action or otherwise strategy game I am aware of.  It is very unforgiving with a strait up learning curve.  Major improvements should be made in Ai, game modes, and Ui.  All that being said, it's the best semi-modern day strategy game you are going to find.  So if you want to feel the g's of your A-10 warthog pilots as they draw fire for your flanking Apaches while your ship board point defense systems sitting off the coast pick off incoming missiles and bombard the Russian heavy infantry with T-80 support as it assaults your navy seal recon unit trying to survive long enough for the helicopters to do their job;  you will have to make the best of the shortcomings in this very intense live action strategy game.  PLUS multi player gives a reason to keep turning it back on.

So I am gonna try & keep this short & sweet whilst still laying out all the pros & cons to this game. 
It's an extremely intense game to get into if coming from games like Halo Wars, Starcraft, Empire at War or even the Total War series. Games can last from 45min to hours depending on the amount of people in a match (2-20) & the game mode. The game is set during the cold war era. This is NOT a rock, paper n' scissors style of RTS but instead it relies on statistics, chance & overall unit composition. It requires you to be well acquainted with micro & macromanaging large amounts of units & the terrain they inhabit. The game uses a "deck" system in which you can customize a deck of units for a nation of your choosing for a certain map or for group play. Decks are limited to a "unit cap" & come with their own respective bonuses depending on what style of play you favor, such as reconnaissance (spotting for your team), armor (being the tank), air (providing CAS & quick reinforcements) or mechanized (infantry & highly mobile armor); however, you can always choose to go with a general deck, which has zero bonuses but allows you to field any combination of units you desire. I spend majority of my time outside of matches editing & building decks. Overall it's a helpful tool for you to take advantage of, so you can know everything there is to know about both your units & what you could be up against in matches. Overall, in strategy, I give this game a solid 9.0/10. Reason? Me personally, I love the challenge but I know to many the very steep learning curve will either make or break new players. 

PROS
>Plenty of units & nations to choose from depending on, which faction you play (NATO or Warsaw Pact).
>Able to command units on the ground, air & sea.
>Challenging & highly strategic (no guns blazing or blind rushing).
>Maps are beautiful as well as graphics. 
>Audio quality is great & gives you a feeling of immersion.
>Variety of singleplayer campaigns to play solo & yes, skirmish against the AI does exist. 
>Can choose to set a game timer or not. 

CONS
>Steep learning curve.
>Small community.

I've had years of fun playing this game, doing co-op matches with my dad while we were thousands of miles apart. It was a great way to keep in touch and share our common interest in video games and military matters. 

Edit: Previously this review was negative due to a patch for a multiplayer exploit that was only rolled out to the Windows version of the game, effectively killing the ability to play multiplayer matches with Mac or Linux players. They have since released an opt-in beta branch that rolls back the game version to re-enable cross-OS play. While I'm still not keen on the dropped support, I'm happy to have this option now.

Even though the concept is not bad, there are multiple negative things to this game: 
1. The community is often extremely toxic and you won't have fun playing against strategies that are no risk to your opponent but kill all of your troops without being able to do anything, i.e. spamming artillery units.

2. The learning curve is extremely steep and after almost 60 hours I am still considered a noob. If you don't have 100 hours to spare to learn the concepts of the game, you won't have fun losing against everyone you face.

3. There is no good tutorials, you have to figure everything out yourself.

4. The game is abandoned by the devs

5. The UI is not very well designed.

Overall, the game has potential, but the lack of tutorials and the horrible community make this game not worth playing

As I begin my walk across the motor pool, several things hit me at once. The smell of diesel and oil. The sound of men and machines. The rumble of tanks and APCs as they move for the assembly point.

"We shipping out?", I yell to the sergeant on top of nearest Bradley. "Damn straight sir, we got our orders 0130 this morning!", he shouts in reply. "You know where the battalion XO is sergeant?", I ask. I get in response; "Last saw him heading to Brigade HQ sir!" A quick Humvee ride later finds me at the brigade HQ tent, a large tent at the end of the airstrip our battalion had been stationed at since the beginning of the buildup. As I enter the busy room, I nearly get run over by people running orders back and forth, and get partially deafened by the shout of orders. I approach the general in the center of the room poring over the AO map, being careful not to trip on the many radio wires crossing the floor. 

The general turns and says "Glad you made it colonel, thought I would need to send a runner to fetch you". Smiling slightly, I reply "Damn radio broke nearly 8 hours ago, didn't get one working until this morning." Smiling back, the general turns to the other battalion commanders at the table, and says the words that send a chill down my spine: "As you've all probably figured out from the news and the mood of the natives, this exercise is no longer just maneuvers in the fields. This is going hot no matter what the suits wanna say."

"I'm moving us to the city of...", the general's next words are drowned out in the sound of jets blasting off over the tent, and I frankly didn't need to listen to the rest. Wargame: Red Dragon, the scenario we been training for years to execute, had now turned into Operation Red Dragon.

My favorite RTS; good balance of realism and fun-- and my most played game on Steam (by far). No economy or bases (at least not in the traditional sense); it's really about reading the field and applying your combat power in the right place. Somewhat micro-heavy, but not APM-your-way-to-victory RTS. Steep learning curve, but very intuitive once the fundamentals are learned (note, there is no substantive tutorial for some unfathomable reason). No shortage of unit variety. Excellent multiplayer, although the community is significantly smaller than those of other RTS games. Somewhat frustrating matchmaking system (or, perhaps, lack thereof). Really rewards teamplay.

Get this game if you are a fan of military history / tactics, the Cold War, or non-traditional RTS games.

Wargame: Red Dragon is a magnificent game that has tons of depth and is hard to master but easy and fun to get into. There are modes for everyone, and the singleplayer campaigns are especially fun because of their non-linearity and feeling of progression over time. In terms of singleplayer, the only complaint I really have is a lack of additional campaigns.

On another note, you can absolutely enjoy the game without ever straying into the multiplayer by just playing against bots or with friends. Even if you intend on playing multiplayer, I would still recommend playing the singleplayer 'skirmish'.

Best modern warfare RTS.

Possitive.
----------
+There are over 1,5k units of very various (logistics, infantry, support, tank, recon, vehicles, heli, planes, navy)
+Different deck specialization.
+Decent terrain , hide your units in the woods or protect your units wherever....
+You can make lots of different tactics.
+Massive multipleyer (up to 10 vs 10) or small plays if you want (1 vs 1).

Negative.
-----------
-I find the compare tool very usefull when creating a deck, but you should be able to compare more than 2 units at once.
-Stealth is a bit fucked. A vehicle can detect infantry hiding in urban areas or forest from hundreds of meters away.... (even if you deactivate all weapons aka they should not be exposed)
-Once you are a few hundred hr in, the maps become a bit monotone. Nontheless its not too bad and you will manage
-If you play with blueforce: BURATINO <|°_°|>

This is, without a doubt, one of the best games I have played in a very long time. If you like slow games with limited tactics, this game is NOT for you. However, if you like fast-paced action and the thrill of glory in your head, you will love this game. The following are common questions I get from my friends:

Q: I’m American, is this game biased for Russia?
A: No, A-10 go BRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRT.

Q: Which DLC should I get, and why?
A: Israel because of MAGLAN.

Q: How is the community?
A: The people are nice, but the in-game chat is SUPER racist and toxic. However, you can close the chatbox if you prefer.

Q: Who is asking you questions, you don’t have any friends.
A: SHUT UP

To get a better idea of what the game is about, you can watch some of my favorite YouTubers like Sparky, Stealth17, and Nick-Da-Man. If you are thinking about getting the game, follow the advice of my man, Shia Labeouf, and JUST DO IT.

IMO one of the best RTS games I have ever played. I would recommend this game for army stuff lovers, who are looking for modern combat gameplay. I think that you have to spend at least 100 hours in this game, if someone experienced is teaching you how to play Wargame, or lot more than 500 hrs, if you have to figure everything out on your own. 

Comparing to Airland Battle, Red Dragon is expanded a bit with mechanics and units, but these games are mostly the same. I think that AB has better maps, when RD has more interesting units and mechanics, for example amphibious vehicles. 

I love both AB and RD (for now, I have 800+ hrs in both wargames), a shame Eugen won't be giving us more Wargames due to its problems with Wg copyrights. I would love it so much to see Wargame placed in years 2000+.

Wargame: Red Dragon is a mess

Pros First
You like RTS games? You like modern combat? You like making the perfect play style after alot of trial and error? Then this game will be fun for you it provides for you to make the perfect deck to bring into mutliplayer. These decks come from a huge assortment of countries set during the later colds war. You wanna play the Soviets in the 80's? This game has that. US? UK? West Germany? China? Japan? You can play all of these countries and more If you pay of course.
That's all I can say that's good

Cons
Singleplayer? More like glorified tutorial with not alot of instruction and more you just figure out everything on your own while the AI throws massive waves of tanks infantry and planes at you WHile YOuR uNIts HavE LoW INItiATivE and although the campaigns are beatable they are not fun because of the cheating the AI does in the later campaigns overall singleplayer is a crap segway to multiplayer.

Multiplayer is a mixed bag and there is good stuff about it but the bad overshadows. Toxic community is a huge reason this game is dead and will stay dead. You a level one starting out? well sucks for you level 5000's don't want to play with scum like you and will kick from they're lobbies and although there are "noob games" these games are still filled with people with hundreds of hours. You want fun competition? forget it a huge portion of the people in this game are salty, annoying and above all racist with chats filled with idiots just yesterday I saw a guy insulting Chinese people and the whole chat joined in. You might be asking about the gameplay and all I will say is that It can be a micro with you doing things you never thought you would have to do a big example of this is radar weapons and how you have to turn them off everytime they are done done firing lest they get targeted by a plane with radar seek. Or the fact that every unit must be resupplied after they run out of ammo which is fine by me but is daunting to people starting out. And the META's omg the meta players in this game let me tell you if you want to buy this game for a realistic combined arms experience do not buy this game you will be disappointed by spam and cheese used by people with the pay to win countries in this game.

So unless you want to spend 100's of hours learning the mechanics and strats of this garbage game while dealing with a idiotic community do not buy this game as the devs don't care and will never balance the game so don't fall for the trap of this game no matter how awesome the idea seems and if you do buy it then good luck and I hope you have a better experience than me otherwise...

Fantastic game with incredibly detailed units and maps with nearly infinite replay. The skirmish mode is good but don't expect a lot more than "point and click" swarm attacks. Campaigns are well done.

Building your "decks" is where the real fun begins though, nearly every European and East Asian nation is in the base game without DLC. Everything you do is based on how you want to wage war or even if you want certain units just to mess around with. (As a side note, the Swedes have the coolest [and weirdest] tanks of the game!)

But again, turn the chat box off because it's completely unmoderated and you will see people with swastikas in their username talking about child porn. Same with multiplayer if you are new to the game you will be harassed.

Other than that, it's usually on sale and it's a great buy.

update April 20.,2020: This game is very awesome. I got this game with all DLC on sale, and you should too if you want a high quality RTS for a fairly low price. The campaigns are well made, their backstories interesting and very close to real life, and each one with a different style of gameplay. Busan pocket and pearl of the orient being more of a defense style, Climb Mount Narodnaya being a Russian blitz style, and 2nd Korean War with a mix of defense and offense. I would love a Wargame 4, but I don't think that would happen. Multiplayer and AI battles are also very cool. There also mods for this, which can bring new styles of gaming, such as a mod where planes can spot units, a sandbox/trainer mod that lets you spawn in hundreds of units, and mods that adds new units.

I would highly recommend this game were it not the most toxic community I have ever experienced. The game itself is beautiful, complex, and challenging, but the people playing it will make you regret your purchase almost immediately. So, I suggest you steer clear of this hate haven.

This game is fantastic if you want fast paced modern military rts. Period. Red Dragon is perhaps the best in the wargame series, and I love it. But I'm here to vocalize a need; Wargame: Dawn of War. 

Sure it would probably stretch the engine to its absolute limit but after seeing total war warhammer I believe anything is possible. And the company has used the 40k licence before. 

Just slap that shit onto the Red Dragon gameplay style and I've got $60 with your dev studio's name on it.

The best in the Wargame series: surely the Steel Divisions as newer entries are technically improving upon this, but I just like the way the play feels in this entry with the units, countries and eras feeling somehow more vibrant.

Downsides: I'm not really into the naval play at all, and from the technical side I'd really want some quality-of-life niceties like visualizing given and chained orders, a hold-to-view-ranges etc. some of which I do remember they added later in the series (Steel Division: Normandy '44 IIRC).
WORDS OF APPROVAL

To start off with, the attention to detail in this game is outstanding, they have units of every kind from every nation in NATO and the Warsaw Pact, many of which I'd never heard of ranging from T series tanks all the way to Stalwart and GM series trucks. Considering the scale of the maps and battle areas, the graphics and textures of both the maps and units is very good and still holds up today, 6 years after the games release. The nature of this game is air-land battle which means it incorporates all aspects of tactical and strategic warfare in terms of aircraft, land forces and naval elements which, working in conjunction, can beat any larger force which is managed poorly as playing the campaign will show you. Many people complain about the global chat which I admit can get quite colourful at times, however I personally find it a good laugh to follow a conversation between 2 salty players, usually from different countries, bringing up massive stereotypes and slagging each other off (recently inflated by the Kung-Flu situation). As a multiplayer battle goes on, the environment will of course change due to aerial and land bombardment as well as crew served and shoulder fired explosive and Napalm based weapons. The effects on the environment will be permanent, this means deforestation and craters will be caused within the maps which is a pretty cool feature as it adds realism and even removes cover. Tank and other vehicle carcasses will also stay present on the map as a testament to your failures. The balancing of units is generally very good with prices of units increasing incrementally based off how good the unit is both compared to its class, and other units it may encounter on the battlefield, an example is aircraft is not an unstoppable force as an AA unit that costs less than a quarter of its price can shoot it down with ease, yet a SEAD aircraft can take out any Radar guided AA without much risk to itself. A counter argument to this however is certain nations, such as the DLC nation of Israel is pretty powerful, possibly to carry on the great ROFL stomp of Yom Kippur! Every aspect of combat is addressed in this game as supplies and veterancy/disposition of your units must be taken into consideration when thinking about deploying them into an assault. Logistics is the backbone of any army and this one is no exception with larger units taking more supplies e.g. it takes more to supply 1 hellfire missile than 1 84mm Karl Gustav round. The learning curve is likely going to be the biggest turn off for new players as it seems to take around 30-40 hours to get your head around how to successfully handle all your types of units in conjunction such as aircraft, artillery and armour. You'll hate enemy airburst artillery. 9/10 game

[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review [/h1]

Wargame: Red Dragon is a game developed and published by Eugen Systems

The game offers some really nice graphics and a nice yet simplistic aesthetic which is pleasant all the same and has some amazing attention to detail even though it is a little rough around the edges

The game does suffer with some repetitiveness at certain areas of the game but a fun game nonetheless and ends just at the right time

Wargame: Red Dragon overall, however, is an okay game to play, yet sometimes repetitive and it does get boring if being played for a long time, but is an okay strategy game to play in short bursts!

Edit: I've tried picking it up again, but the micro is just on another level and there's no noob friendly in this game. I tried playing tactical games so there's less units to manage, but again you're probably facing off with someone who has 2000+ games that knows every unit weakness and map strategy by heart. There's not even enough population to consistently get into online games within 10 minutes or so.

I really wanted to like this game but I can't give a recommendation for it. It's designed for online play, but there is only a tiny online community for it. Most public battles are 4 friends on one side vs a bunch of randoms on the other and that goes about as well as you'd think it would.

So what about offline play? The AI is horrendus. All it knows how to do is throw units into a meat grinder. Additionally, sometimes it just stops making moves or spawning units and just sits there (probably a bug, but c'mon this game has been out for what, 2 years now?)

Finally there's the steep learning curve. I like complex games, but forget 1 type of unit and your whole force is destroyed in seconds. The micromanagement is also pretty horrific. Every unit has to be given very specific commands and it will not take any automated action what so ever. Helicopters taking ground fire? They just sit there until they're destroyed. Same goes for tanks. The notification system is terrible. All you hear is "trouble...trouble....trouble..." and no indication of who's in trouble or where they are...yeah lemme just scan the map for the 5 guys standing next to a burning tree...again taking no action on their own to move 3 steps to the left so they don't burn to death.

This Game is no easy walk in the park. It will take Youtube videos to assist your Sun Tzued Mind up their but I do say its all very much, well worth it.... This game will put you in the shoes of a Commander,"Set several years after WW2 id say and focusing more on the 70s, 80s , 90s Army Groups" and in doing so you will have to conduct several aspects of approaching this here battlefield Below You. Whether it is by Land, Sea, or Air the choice dear fellow is in your hands. "Should I go around these Hills, set up an ambush up in these forest here with these Gurkas, or should I land my Canadian Marines and storm up the front, its all done to you Commander. You will have most of the Nations of NATO, and of course our dear comrades over in the Warsaw PACT. "don't forget about them, they don't like that" Over a thousand units to choose from and build your Deck "Army Group more so" and take to the battlefield. You must try to balance you Groups with the right amount of Logistics, Recon, Infantry, Air, Armor, and if you decide to have a Amphibious unit depending on the Map as well, you can do that. If you enjoy armies clashing out strategically then this Game is going to be for you. It may be Old but certainly still delivering great fun for its age. Please do enjoy #Attack, Defend, Counter Attack, Repeat

I bought this on sale and the gameplay is great, however I can't recommend this for any price if your primary goal is multiplayer gameplay.

Here's why; I spent at least 5 hours reading and watching guides before I even played against AI. After playing against the AI enough to feel comfortable, I jumped into multiplayer. The first thing I noticed is the game only averages 500 players online. You can expect some teammates to be toxic towards you because you're new. Although that type of thing doesn't bother me much (plus there are convenient mute features for those whom it does), the main problem was even finding a game. Out of 6 days attempting to play, I was able to get 10 games in. On 1 of those days, there simply just were no lobbies to find or the wait times for the lobby to fill were way too long. More concerning though is that on 2 of those days, every available lobby would simply kick me because of the low games count on my profile. 

TLDR: The community is not welcoming to new players, to the point that you can't even play the multiplayer portion of the game.

It pays so much detail to mechanics that so many other games ignore: logistics, unit strengths/weaknesses, battle positioning, and higher level reinforcements/sectors.  It covers all unit types: infantry, armor, helos, aircraft, and naval units.  I feel like I'm really a military general, part of the war campaign, directing traffic.  

My only gripe is that their maps, while large and varied, all fall short of what would be a true battlefield in a particular region.  They all seem to be in rural areas with generic housing/industrial complexes rather than realistic urban/suburban/industrial-like areas for the given region.

A great RTS game set in the close to modern era. 100s of units to choose from, some nations even have their own completely unique units.

It's late on a hot, hazy afternoon and my veteran K1 tanks have just pushed through an industrial zone on their way to cut off the province's major highway, leaving enemy wrecks burning in their wake. Suddenly, recon reports an enemy SU-25 aircraft closing in fast from the Daegu aerial corridor. Spec-Ops in Huey choppers haven't landed and cut that off yet. Damn. Where are they? Time is running out. The SU-25's cannon growls, its rounds chewing up the road and ripping into the lead tank. I call in my own air support, and a moment later, I'm following behind an F-16 as it screams in for the kill, missiles locking onto the SU-25. They strike true, the SU-25 explodes, and the F-16 pulls away with a wave. My K1's roll on.

Immersive, beautiful, engaging. Great strategic and tactical depth with tense matches and solid AI. A little bit of a steep learning curve, but victories feel all the more rewarding. If you're at all intrigued by what you see in the screenshots, the game absolutely lives up to it.

Three reasons why you shouldn't buy this game:

1. The community is the most toxic I have ever seen. The ingame chat filled with nazis (with the name of Jewhunter, WaffensturmführerSS, Adolf Hitler, ...) who openly talk about how they want to kill either jews or their parents... or in "good" moments just verbally abuse each other in ways that would make 4chan look classy in comparsion.

2. The unit spam is really the worst about the game. It doesn't feel like a military strategy simulation, but rather like an arcade shooter wherein the one wins who can spam the most units.
Honestly it just looks plain silly when I start a bomber and the enemy sends 10 AA jets against it, or suddenly there are 20 helicopters flying in bulk into my zone going full kamikaze.
It's better when the credit gain is set to low on the map, but appearantly nobody likes that..

3. Singleplayer sucks, and so does multiplayer sadly. When you finally get into a game after waiting for 20 minutes in the lobby, you either get an extremely stupid team who surrenders the match in the first few minutes, or your team gets stomped by the pro players, who make up most of the remaining player base.

A big reason for that is that there's no auto team-balance and no way to see how strong your team is - except stupidly clicking on every player and then on "view profile" - so in 8 out of 10 games you get extremely unbalanced teams.
Which just leads to really frustrating matches, especially when you are new to the game. I player over 50 matches so far and only 3 where actually good and worth remembering. This is really not good enough.


Oh and the storefront screenshots are very misleading, you never play in such a close view. Check out lets plays to know what I mean.

I would love it if they added more campaigns to the game or did more expansions. It is one of the few games in existence that let's you play as the IDF so it is actually really cool that they did that. Honestly I'd be willing to shell out $40 if they made a Yom Kippur or the 6 day war or even the Iran Iraq war.

There are many ways to describe this game:

ps: Always prepare a deck for every foe, role, and situation.

Use common senses please, tank in an urban setting? Infantry in an open expanse field? Helo without air superiority? Please don't. (Unless your bluffing)

Sometimes, a strong point isn't exactly strong. Learn to know the lay of the land. Elevation, chokepoint, and visibility. 
Well, there is much more to say, but do read the wiki and guide your fellow gamer wrote. It's very valuable for you and your teammate!

Have fun and stay aware. ;D

At time of writing this review, I consider this game one of my all time favourites. 

The reason why I bought this game are youtube video's. When I watched those video's I was really suprised about the depth of the game. And as a RTS fan, I was instantly hyped and bought the game.
When I actually started to play the game for the first time, I was absolutely masacred by easy A. I.. I tried playing the game for a couple of single player games, but still no visible progress. At that moment I choose to not play this game anymore. I though I had wasted my money. (Eventually I figured out it wasn't.)

Quite some time later I decided to give it one more shot. I started to look up guides and started to watch youtubers who explained how this game worked. Thanks to one particular youtuber I learned how to play the game. I watched his guides.

I added a example video.

Example video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hgmslx7_kLg&list=PLlSUA5AyYAoeDPCjR6weNeiXXJitl4dlc


After playing a fuckton of games I finally passed the learning curve. Currently I have various friends in wargame with whom I regularly play games and share decks with.


Negative;
- Long learning curve (unit placement, synergy between units, utilizing the right opportunities, etc.)
- Alot of failure and roflstomping in the beginning.
- Alot of mechanics to get used to. (soft counters, hard counters, tank shells -> kinetic or HEAT, etc.)
- Even the slightest mistake can result in a total annihilation of your units or even defeat. Which can be quite frustrating.
- In-game tutorials are not sufficient enough to learn how the game works.


Positive
- Playing with a group brings the level of tactical gameplay to the next dimension.
- The game become really fun to play after you are passed the long learning curve.
- The evenly matched online games are awesome to play and even give a satisfied feeling if are defeated.
- When played accordingly the mechanics and synergy systems implemented are brilliant.
- This game offers you a very broad selection of units. There are unlimited combinations to combine into a deck. 

I recommend this game to players who have the time AND the will to learn how the game works.

I hope to see you in my next battle!
