Review:
Really underrated and amazing game and the only real strategy game out there these days besides Starcraft and CMO/CMANO (which I don't even consider a "game"). This game may be frustrating at first but so worth it once you get to know the controls and common units.

Graphics are good. It's just downright fun to fly around your favorite fighter jets (avoid jets while learning the game though) and drive around your favorite tanks. Don't have a favorite tank? Well there are over a hundred to choose from, and you'll find some you like after playing with them. Don't be intimidated by the number of units - you will get used to it and learn them over time. The variety makes the game fun.

Gameplay is good - the controls are fairly easy to grasp (unlike CMO/CMANO) and the game does not demand as much APM (actions per minute: how fast do you need to click) as Starcraft. The "difficulty" is not the controls, it's mostly learning strategies (how/when to use which controls/units) and unit counters. These take a little while to learn. Do not get this game if you only expect to play for 20 hours.

The best part about Wargame is its replayability. There are so many units to choose from, and so many different ways to play, that games don't feel repetitive, like Starcraft, where people have carefully planned builds and timings etc. Hate jets? You don't have to use them at all. Don't want to micromanage artillery? Don't deploy any. I love the flexibilty and general lack of you-lose-if-you-don't-do-X kind of gameplay. Except recon. You lose if you don't use recon units. Use recon units.

As with any game, Wargame has its share of "wow you suck noob why did you do X thing". IGNORE THEM - the other 95% of us are just happy more new people are getting the game! It's better for everyone when new people join, and we'd be happy to have you. Watch out for pubstomping lobbies (i.e. lobbies called "noobs welcome" with 4 very high level players on the other team), but you should be able to find good games/lobbies if you're a little bit patient.

Summary:
I highly recommend Wargame: Red Dragon. It truly is a one-of-a-kind game. If you like strategy or modern/cold war military stuff, or miss Command and Conquer, and are willing to endure a longer-than-usual learning time, you will like Wargame once you get the hang of it. It is extremely replayable and lends itself to a wide variety of playstyles. I wouldn't even call myself "hardcore", but 600 hours later, I'm still here. Come join the fun!

(and seriously, if you get the game, there are players who want to help you learn. the wargame subreddit is a good starting place)

P.S. if you're thinking "I'll wait for the next one", the developers have said they won't make a next one. The hard core fans will not leave this game until the sun explodes. So don't worry about the game dying out, despite the relatively small number of players. We are here to stay, and I rarely have trouble finding games/lobbies/players.
This game will strategically beat the shit out of you and you will like it. (P.S. I was beaten by the A.I. on easy mode lol).
Possibly the best modern military RTS ever made, and much better than the garbage Eugen has released since
Awesome game for people who love to strategize.
Please just release WG4

The concept of the game is great, build a "deck", deploy it to the battlefield, slug it out RTS style with the opponent. Tons of units from all countries, roles, etc; you could spend hours just making the decks. But it's also fairly easy to pick up so it won't be discouraging to use trial and error to perfect a deck. Multiplayer setup is quick and easy and joining a game gave me no troubles, it was all friendly user and intuitive. One drawback is the AI which isn't too bright when entering an AO; I would find my troops moving to the front by driving through enemy territory, often resulting in loss of the unit (poor Delta Force). The experience is akin to the game World in Conflict as far as troop deployment/holding territories, but here we see a much more fleshed out game. 8/10

First, the part of the RTS that is nice. Very nice. 

Industrial buildings and extraction facilities that take months to build are not "created in 30 seconds." like may "real time" games. That is a plus. Finally, some logic, and critical thinking in this genre. That is all. 

What is the point of a "wargame" 

When it has more in relation to chess, and Rubik's cube, than actual war? 

Why have real time when on foot warfighters run at 30 miles per hour? 

Why ruin realistic engagement ranges? Why place fake events with fake timers on random vehicles? 

Why do helicopters not perform normal operations?

Why implement strategic objectives only to destroy the point of completing objectives with silly rules like having officers in certain areas providing "trust" to ask for reinforcements? How is that logical?


You want real time strategy? Arma. Ace medical advanced,  Discord/teamspeak. Multiplayer. Conduct a 5 hour operation to secure an area with 55 other people.  

This is just something that creates pretty pictures that seem realistic without any adherence to actual critical thinking or reasoning. 

Sure, I enjoyed it. It's probably only enjoyable due to the unique implementation of this game. There isn't anything on the market quite like it. It makes you "feel." like your some strategic officer planning and conducting military operations. It does many visual aspects in a non cartoony way which is a plus for RTS games. It does things much closer to real time than most rts games. It uses a lot more logic on the conduct of war than many rts games. And, in terms of talent towards one project, it does not have competition. 

Being unique though, does not mean quality. It's a decent amount of quality fun compared to what RTS can offer at the time of the release of wargame red dragon but that doesn't mean there are many many errors in logical reasoning. 

I mean, the point of a strategy game, focused on militarized objective, is the whole "critical thinking and reasoning" part. Why do stupid things? I don't like doing illogical things. 


---------------------------------
Yet, this game takes stupidity and gives it a trophy. Why use the word strategy? Real Time Strategy.

Not Real Time Stupidity. 
People with low self esteem and too much pride actually develop cognitive reasoning skills who then shell out their wallets to programmers and developers lacking in critical thinking so that they feel smart when in fact the only thing that's accomplished is enhanced stupidity skills. 

So much talent into something so stupidly silly. 
If you like the strategy in real time STRATEGY don't get this, it's more stupidity than strategy. It's more Silly than Smart. 

That is why, I don't want to say i like this. It doesn't make anyone even remotely better at... well.... quality decision making. 

That said, it's pretty. The visual experience isn't too bad. (for $5) (at 2019 so not many competitors at the moment)
It's due time i review this game. It's great and you need to get it.

As I've already heard, this game has a high entry bar and boy, that is so true. Get ready to the fact that you'll get your ass kicked 4-5 times even when playing against easy AI, and your ranks in other RTS probably won't matter anyhow. But when you'll get over the steep learning curve, this game will keep on giving, since it's one of the most detailed RTS that is available on the market. It still misses quite a few options though - you can't order your infantry to get a loose formation when under enemy arty fire, or make them entrench themselves, so do not expect features like this because your hands will be too busy anyway. Managing a squad consisting of 10 units is OK, but when you are controlling over 50 different types of vital units - that becomes quite a challenge. An infantry squad sitting in an APC will perish in vein since they won't be able to add any firepower apart  from the vehicle's weapons, and will die with a high probability when an enemy tank will practice shooting at them, but when disembarked, put into a right position against their type of target - they will be able to put a lot of heat at enemy ranks. I haven't seen this kind of units variety in majority of other RTS games, and every  match will be different due to sheer size of options. Of course, a lot of units inevitably will lookalike, but that's reality - when you have only a dozen of really different wargear manufacturers.  Definitely will recommend to buy

The best card based real time strategy game inspired by the cold war. Some more modern units can really give it flavor but be a bit too OP at times. New player warning: be prepared for a steep learning curve and no mercy for beginners in multiplayer, but also be prepared for the most deep combat system out there(apart from some text based games and grand strategy).  Rich new players can buy dlc nations which can soften the steep learning curve a bit with their power creep and lets hope money spent on the dlc nations goes towards a well polished sequel. Do not be alarmed by that power creep, it's balanced out and nerfed to oblivion by now. 

Should a publisher or developer of this game be reading this: sequel please, thank you very much. I think the idea, mechanics and theme of this game combined with features from your later games has the potential to unite a large part of real time strategy fans with a well polished sequel. Personally I would like more depth with programmable unit orders and programmable unit stances with developer defaults available i.e. Apache Longbow has 2 stances: the default with the 2 missile burst and aggressive where it keeps firing missiles as long as the target is alive. Or i.e. if a unit gets in contact with a enemy unit which it has no chance to kill, depending on the stance it will either: a) continue with its orders or stand still if given none; b) automatically back away or find nearest cover to break contact.

If you're reading this, I'm sure you've already figured out what this game is largely about, so let me give a comment on what it feels like to actually play:

This is, hands down, probably the hardest game I've ever played (when it comes to the multiplayer).

Describing the learning curve as "brutal" doesn't do it justice. It's practically inhumane. The lack of an effective tutorial, slews of hidden gameplay systems and mechanics that are not referred to anywhere in the game itself, and a tiny but very experienced playerbase means that as a new player you will have no clue what you're doing and will almost always be matched against people who very much do. This last part is the most significant by far - the gameplay systems are complex and hard to master, but it's doable. What isn't so doable is beating people with infinitely more experience than you when you've just barely figured out the core gameplay mechanics. The singleplayer mode really doesn't help in this regard, since the AI is criminally stupid and makes up for it with sheer numbers - not a good reflection of real multiplayer matches.

If you are masochistic enough to enjoy a game where you will lose, lose, lose, and lose again, over and over and over, until you sloooooooowly get good enough to start winning, this game is a brilliant experience unlike any other. But if you're not willing to put in literally hundreds of hours to git gud, and can't stand the idea that you will get your teeth kicked in practically every match by people who know about parts of the game you didn't even know existed, this game is not for you.

I've had a lot of frustration with Wargame: Red Dragon, but something keeps me coming back, demoralizing as playing this game may be. Maybe it'll do the same for you.

(On a sidenote, if you're even slightly interested in the field of Cold War era military technology, this game is remarkably educational in the sense of presenting lots of those in an easily digestible format. You'll be able to tell apart a MiG-29 from a Su-27 in no time! Obviously don't use this as an actual resource, but it's a nice starting point for further research of your own - often just going "ooh this vehicle looks cool" and then googling it is enough.)

The concept of the Wargame series is quite an unique take on the RTS Genre: instead of spawning units out of a building and gathering resources with your collector units, you take control points and spawn units from your off-map base (somewhat like risk). The gameplay and graphics are a real treat, although getting into it can be really confusing (it took me 1 hours of watching youtube tutorials and gameplay to understand what I was doing) it still is a fun game. It certainly isn't for everyone, and the Multiplayer Population although small it is really existant, and REALLY competitive. I'd suggest watching non-meme gameplay to understand what is it that you're getting into before actually purchasing.

Unique, semi-realistic Cold War-themed RTS with a great deal of depth and complexity. Small but active multiplayer community; usually ~300 concurrent players on normal weekday nights (EU time). Players are of wildly differing skill levels. Avoid the general chat.

Single player is generally decently playable, apart from naval battles which are completely broken and should be skipped. However, multiplayer is where this game shines. I've found smaller team games (2v2 to 4v4) to be the most satisfying. Avoid the general chat.

Very steep learning curve, due mostly to the enormous number of different units and some unconventional game mechanics. Also, since you construct your own "decks" (unit rosters), rather than using a fixed set of units every time, there is an additional layer of complexity. Avoid the general chat.

There are plenty of good guides and tutorials around, but it will still take quite some time and effort to learn the basics well enough to not be useless in multiplayer. Once you're past that initial hump, the game gets a lot less frustrating and more enjoyable. Avoid the general chat.

The UI has some problems, the lack of a proper LOS tool being the most significant flaw. Avoid the general chat.

This game is quite literally a diamond in the rough with regards to RTS games. Its not for the faint of heart or those who lack an understanding of real military tactics. Combined arms, meticulously placed air defense, stealthy recon, well timed flanking and precise air strikes are the nature of winning but can be so hard to successfully achieve yet so satisfying when it occurs. Wargame is fantastic for forcing you to be so micro heavy you can't spend a single moment distracted or face complete and utter annihilation. Their are so many pros to this title. 1) the choice of nations and the accuracy of the units is staggeringly good and accurately depicts the military prowess of the respective nation at the time. IE. USA and USSR are absolutely beast mode factions whereas Poland or South Korea are a literal joke. 2) This game forces you to think like youre controlling a large force on an actual battlefield. Bum rushing a wall of tanks or other corny tactics are not applicable here in any way. Think like a general or fail. 3) wargame chat is not monitored and is absolutely savage and hilarious. 4) you can skirmish the AI over and over again and get to the point where you can easily take on players in multiplayer one on one with no prior experience.

the only con is naval battles suck so harddddddddddddd.

Otherwise, if you are an RTS fan i HIGHLY reccomend this game. The re play factor is off the charts with war game. Steel Division doesn't even come close to comparing. I hope Eugen steps it up and makes a follow up wargame but modern instead of Cold war Era.

Quite controversial game. There are roughly three types of people playing this game – people who will click anything including farming sims for fun and laughs, competitive gamers who will use every trick in the book, including unbalanced gameplay to win. Finally, there are some people with various military understanding who expect much more from a game with such wasted potential. Make no mistake – this is a game with an enormous wasted potential to be true military, command&control type simulator. Most people will say there is a "steep learning curve" and anybody complaining cannot master the game well enough to play it. It’s not true, however keyboard shortcuts are not intuitive, they are hard to apply mostly due to in-game time limit. There is no tutorial or decent manual, however you’ve got to be quick with the keyboard and read the maps quickly to see and control your units. If you are looking for true tactical experience don’t bother, because fraction of a second or a misclick may cost you units. For some reason they’ve decided to invest in rather impressive graphics in a military tactical/strategic simulator instead of decent command and control capabilities. By the way, the player may enjoy most of these graphics from replays - there is no time for it during the game. 
Once you get over controls and time limit, you gradually will have to curb your enthusiasm, because units themselves are unbalanced and in many cases fictional. At the same time there are units which fall into general description quite well but player can’t use them in decks according to basic military knowledge or nation/coalition potential. The game will provide you with units no one ever has seen, or unit’s availability is broken to the point of fiction. Most powerful fraction in the game is Eurocorps (Germany, France, Netherlands), most crippled nations are US and Soviet Union. The game also gets irrationally pumped up nations with units no one had ever seen in real life. Then again, it amazes me how many units they got somehow right, or at least decently balanced. Over all the game is a half-finished product, rushed to the market long time ago and never fixed. Is it worth buying? It might be, it’s either RD or Space Invaders/Xcom/Rescue HQ. The choice is yours.

Wargame IP is dead and they'll never expand on this game.  It will only leave you wanting more, which you'll never get.

First off - modding this game is possible, but extremely complicated and very limiting in what you can do.  Most of the single player issues can be resolved through modding, campaign is fun if you mod the hell out of the game and remove the extra money per minute / starting points in general for the AI.  That's right; the AI needs a cheaty boost to make it competitive.  This makes campaign mode tedious and dull, since there are [b]TURN LIMITS[/b] that even seasoned experts can't outrun (2nd Korean War; hard-coded 22 turn limit, you still fail if you retake South Korea).  I don't like to be pressured to get shit done in a game I'm trying to have fun with; and some of these turn limits can't be modded out.  (22 turns enough for a 2nd Korean War?  Thought not lol.)

Multiplayer is alright, a lot of vulgarity, politics, hate, anger, etc. in the game chat, but that can be a lot of fun to the right person.  Sad thing is it's nowhere near as large as it once was, you'll see around 200-500 people on at any one time, and nothing is more foreboding than when the chatroom is dead.

When I say it's not worth the emotional investment, that's because this is a really fun game, has the most content in the entire Wargame series, and with a little work, could be one of the best games in the RTS genre...  but Eugen Systems will never put anymore work into it.  Period.

Some banter says it's partly because when they broke off from Focus Interactive, the Publisher retained the rights to the Wargame Series.  Whether that's true or not, I don't know.  At the same rate, Eugen has it's own problems - this is a company that makes a habit of abandoning their games 1 to 2 years after their initial release; they've done this to every title they've come up with.  They've got a damn good idea, but they just aren't the right people for the job.  If the strike they had shows the company itself is mismanaged, this also translates to how their games are mismanaged.  Steel Division 44 and Steel Division 2, for instance, should be a good indicator that they're getting cheaper and cheaper with how they do things.  Not a good future for them.

If you're happy with playing through a game a few times only to ditch it in a couple of months, or if you've got the talent and drive to mod a game that wasn't created with the intention of modding (search the moddingSuite 0.8.6 or 0.9.0 on the Eugen forums if you want to mod), I recommend against this game.  You'll really enjoy it, and you'll have to suffer knowing it'll never truly feel like it has what it needs.

I don't recommend Wargame because it's sad to know this game is dead and abandoned by the studio, and will never expand into what it deserves to be.  Not worth it.

[h1]Wargame: Red Dragon[/h1]

A beautifully made RTS with one-of-a-kind gameplay in a setting that is largely unexplored by modern games.

This game is hard to describe to an observer. It is probably best to start with what it is and isn't. A tl:dr is provided in "Is it worth it?".

This [b] is [/b] a real time strategy game that functions most similarly to Total War* in unit management and in multiplayer. Placement, movement, direction, and cohesion of your units is much more important than numbers, micro, or economy. In fact, this game has a very simple economy that is more akin to a real time tactics game but on a larger scale and with less immediately apparent gaminess. This is a game that rewards players with intimate knowledge of the game engine and the 1450 units the game has. This is a game that has an enormous amount of replayability (many players end up playing for hundreds or thousands of hours) thanks to the deck builder and the amount of opportunity for innovation.

This [b]is not[/b] a game that is easy to pick up and will require a large time investment for many (about 80 hours of gameplay and studying before I was at all competitive) This is not a simulator and you'd be better-off picking up Command: Modern Air/Naval Operations if you are seeking a 1:1 simulator, then probably come back to this when you find out that simulators are, well, not that glamorous.  The [b]single player[/b] experience is limited and is tedious to many due to shortcomings from the game's AI. [b]If you are buying this game for the naval combat,[/b] you should probably look at  Command: Modern Air/Naval Operations as the naval aspect of this game is imbalanced and not modeled well for even most casual gameplay.

 [h1]How does the game work?[/h1]

The game is split into three parts for single player and two parts for multiplayer.**

Multiplayer is split into the lobby and the game. In the lobby you choose your deck. Your deck will be made in the deck editor in-lobby or at the main menu. Decks are saved and then selected at the lobby screen. Due to how the game is balanced you will often use select coalitions and generally will stay away from specializations and nations unless you're in a larger team game or have a specific strategy in mind. While you select your deck the lobby host will have chosen the gamemode, map, number of players, and other game parameters.  After you launch the game you enter the RTS phase. You will deploy a limited amount of units in your starting zone and then start the game after time runs out or all players notify that they are ready. From here you will play accordingly to the gamemode and map. After the match is finished your are shown your kills, losses, and points scored (conquest). You are given a "Kill list" that details what unit killed what and vice versa for units under your command. All replays are saved.

Single player has a campaign map that splinters a geographical region like Japan. You spend political points to mobilize realistic divisions (Decks) to the field. Admitedly, due to the game being balanced around multiplayer and the AI playing more like the Zerg than a Cold War commander, the concept often falls short. You then fight with the divisions in various zones and move them about in order to achieve objectives and complete the scenario. When your units are in a sector along with hostile units you will be given the option to fight. When you fight the game operates like the multiplayer process above but with the decks being determined by what divisions you have. This process is the same for naval units. After you fight a victory type is given and losses are calculated. All losses in campaign  must be replaced in a suitable sector at the cost of unit initiative and political points.

[h1]Who should buy this game? [/h1]

Generally, those who have a strong love for gaming, military history, and an attention to detail will love this game. If you are okay with putting in the effort that many have negatively described as requiring "the time investment of a part time job" in order to master the mechanics and familiarize yourself with this one of a kind game then you're in the right place. With a lack of developer support the community has had come together to give new players all of the tools they need and connections necessary to get a feel for the community and the game alike. After the hurdle of learning the game mechanics you're ready to play on your own and step into the game that is, Wargame: Red Dragon.

[h1]Is it worth it?[/h1]

If you look at the positive reviews you will find many players have played this game for hundreds or thousands of hours. A game that is not predatory in nature, doesn't hound you for money, and is as beautifully made as this doesn't come by often. A game that rewards skill and gives someone thousands of choices to mull over for the next thousand hours to come awaits those who are willing to put in the initial effort. With a skill ceiling that rivals games like Starcraft 2 and Age of Empires you will find yourself coming up with new ways to win and even breaking out of the lane mentality if you're clever enough.

If you read this review and have doubts about the complexity, initial time investment, or the “real-time” in RTS I recommend passing up this title and looking elsewhere.

**Game mechanics are explained in-depth in five comments by me below this review.

Wargame is a complex, interesting, and somewhat annoying game for rts fans and fans of a "Cold War gone hot" scenario.
The game's main feature is the deck based unit system which is every bit as complex as old trading card games without the balancing. This game will not make things easy on new players nor will it go easy on people who make bad decks, so don't jump into a North Korean tank deck before you at least try out the pre-built American and Soviet decks some.

I mentioned that there is problems with balancing. While there is balance to most base game factions, if you play well you can certainly win against a US or France/Germany deck with a North Korean deck, the Israel dlc is objectively and unanimously agreed to be overpowered. Watch the video on Youtube Valefisk made on the subject or read some forum/Reddit posts about it. Apparently the Yugoslavia dlc units are stronger than the base game units as well but not on par with the Israel dlc according to other forum posts I've seen.

This game might be worth it on sale if you got the time to learn how to play, but the tutorial sure as heck won't teach you. Unless you are capable to learn from trial and error or by reading about the mechanics, you might find yourself stuck and confused how to play. In my case, I've enjoyed the game so far.

The combat is deeper then just I have big tank you have small tank I win it demands a certain level of understanding of the unit it's strength and weaknesses and how to tactically use it (yes your M1 Abrams can get wrecked by a jeep with a recoiless rifle if you're not smart).

Just a friendly note the game does not ease you in, and you may get your ass handed to you and rage quit at first but just learn how units work and how to use them as well as how the game work (AP, LOS, Tracking, Stealth, Directional hitpoints) The AI is not unfair and it's easily beat once you figure out how, thats the best part.

Realism in this game has been achieved better than any other RTS games as far as I know, but because it still has to be an RTS game, it's impossible to be flawlessly accurate like other military sims. Mid range air to air missiles have much longer range than just 7kms or so in this game,  and you can never find a Tunguska artillery cheaper than a T-80MBT, nor can you find an Apache attack helicopter cheaper than an M1A2 tank IRL. The airforce is weaker than the real world and gets easily shot down by anti-air defenses because they can only fly at very low altitudes, and the weapons they carry just doesn't do enough damage to the tanks as they should IRL. But after all, it's for the balance of the game as an RTS title. Still a great game to play around though.

Not fun

This is not a fun game. This is some bitter Frenchie Officer Academy wash-out's project to prove to his friends and family he's not a failure at life. Nothing about this is an enjoyable experience in any capacity.

I guess nobody in continental Europe has played an RTS game since their countries so regularly screw up beyond repair that there's some border conflict every ten years - and these are the morons who don't understand the EU and NATO is the reason we haven't had a major destructive continental war in Europe in the last 50 years - so playing a war game of any kind is just superfluous. Let me put it like this, imagine a console FPS where you aim with the D-Pad and fire by pushing down on the analog stick and actually moving the analog stick causes you to jump up and down repeatedly out of cover. It's a needlessly obtuse control scheme that nobody can defend - but somebody will because this is the kind of game made for aspies and autists so they feel smarter than everyone else when really there's nothing intelligent about someone who can't function in normal society because his high IQ misanthropy isn't a form of wisdom in any actual philosophy.

I get the idea behind recon units but they're needlessly helpless and also over relied on. It's not clear at all what your units can and cannot see and as someone with experience in this kind of shit in real life - something not a soul who worked on this game can attest to - if you get shot at, the first thing you do is return fire. You don't wait for some cigar-chomping guy sitting at a computer to directly tell you to return fire. The game is in desperate need of a fog of war to show you where the limit of your range is and just how far you can actually see. I know for a lot of people a fog of war breaks the immersion but it's a necessary thing to show where you need to send them to cover your blind spots. 

That's a real summary of what I think the problems are in this game. There's a serious lack of useful mechanics in favor of creating a bloated and frustrating sense of realism. Older Total War titles are able to give players a sense of realism while still giving you usable mechanics and generating an enjoyable, challenging experience. When the game comes together it is a fun and engaging RTS game but "engaging" isn't having to use four commands to get units to attack-move or worrying about whether or not your soldiers have ammunition - which, by the way, you're never told if or when they run out, you just have to hope you're paying attention. Further compounding on the complication inherent in this game's design you're never given an adequate descriptor of the range/area of effect for buffs, supply, weapon range, damage, etc.. The game instead opts to expect me to break out a fucking sextant and a ruler and a physical map of whatever area I'm playing in and after learning the metric system - because, really, no one outside of Europe using the metric system in normal life, not even in the military in most cases - you can figure out exactly the range and effectiveness of your units. But by the time you've done that some adderal-sniffing artillery player has already destroyed all of your deployed forces. Oh and don't tell me having these metrics makes the game more "realistic," I know for a fact lots of the units have nerfed or exaggerated ranges. This isn't just me, actual people who enjoy this game in between their methamphetamine binges have confirmed this to me as a long-understood fact in the community.

Units are helpless without your direct influence at best and at worst unresponsive. You'll have every indication the units are doing something but they're not. What terrain is actually good and isn't also is not readily apparent. The "topographical" minimap is laughable. Apparently weapons systems that fire just fine and even with stabilization stats don't fire on the move or simply stop to engage on their own; no, I'm expected to in set-piece battles involving thousands of troops hold the hands of special forces teams and elite armored divisions instead of trusting they can do their jobs when I tell them to go somewhere, attack something, bombard an area, carry out missions, etc..

There's even texture pop-in issues that directly affect the gameplay. Units will be destroyed and you will neither see the units destruction nor be able to identify what killed it simply because you're out of range. The camera is jittery and just because I dared to scroll past a certain limit I'm either thrown face-first into the dirt like a French Resistance Fighter in a concentration camp or catapulted into space like a monkey in a Russian satellite, motion sickness included.

Many fans will say I just suck at the game and they're probably right, but that's a lot like saying I suck a billiards meanwhile they've got actual cues and I'm using a tree branch. The learning curve for a video game should be in the meta and not in the mechanics, controls, or UI itself. Many other RTS games and affiliate mods enforce realism and are complex the further down the rabbit hole you go without forcing me to wait six business days for a unit to receive a movement order. You could apply Eugene's design philosophy to a host of other strategy games and they'd all be ruined for anyone that doesn't spend their days doing rails off their keyboard while they wait in the lobby. This is, genuinely, a game made for people to feel smarter for playing where Euro-trash and self-hating Americans can wax about how much better everything else besides the current global superpower is and I guess the sore losers have to have something to do with their time or they might actually organize and do something effective before getting bombed out of existence from the stratosphere like those guys who play Civil War mods and games as the Confederacy so they can pretend their racist slavocrat oligarchy ever had a fighting chance.

It's highly possible the people who've introduced me to the game just are failing to properly communicate the game to me or maybe this control scheme is friendlier to people who play less traditional RTS titles versus myself. Maybe you can get your way past the esoteric controls and mechanics to chew into the meta and enjoy yourself but the game is very deceptive in how it's played and what it is. It's mostly about building card decks and stacking the game so your victory is a foregone conclusion since you've opted for a monastic lifestyle of being an armchair general to nurse your wounded pride after you failed MEPS, hoping your mastery of this game will convince your friends and family you're a person of value and not just another neat who hasn't had his junk touched by anything except the toilet paper he keeps not-discreetly-at-all behind his computer monitor and who's so pale from lack of Vitamin D you could be spotted in Wargame even without the use of recon units from ten kilometers away. This is just me warning people the game is not accessible in any way and is another title with huge potential weighed down by an over-abundance of "realism" mechanics and a poorly designed control scheme that punishes any attempt you make to actually understand how to play.

I've heard from fans that later games in the series improve on these faults and hyperbole aside many long-time fans who introduced me to it admit that some of the design choices are/were questionable in regards to Wargame but it's still regarded as the holy grail like those people who insist the last good music was produced some time before the invention of electricity. Give it a try at your own risk, but it's not for me.

Wargame promises ultra realistic battlefields but its modelling of infantry is so atrocious it makes any claim to realism ludicrous. Aficionados of WarGame will defend this lack of fidelity for infantry as being unimportant and that vehicles reign supreme in modern warfare. As for me, I can't look at infantry sprinting across fields wildly spraying their weapons in the vague direction of the enemy as being plausibly realistic.

I can't yet tell if it's an RTS where there's a simple permeating technique or combination of units that can win any fight, but then again I've only played one level. For twelve hours. Over and over again sending my units to their deaths. Digital scorch marks litter the land where squads of infantry were obliterated by Apache missiles and armored convoys met their end at the hands of long range artillery or guerrilla anti-tank units or that blasted destroyer that always seems to find its way within range of the city I'm traversing. Buy this game and tell me what the other levels are like.


Edit: Spam infantry to beat ai at any difficulty - support with tanks in trees if you want to get fancy (but ultimately unnecessary)

Do NOT go into this game expecting CoH or C&C or some softcore bullshit - this is a hardman's game and you either nose dive into one of the "noob only" lobbies and learn to play or you go straight into a massive 10v10 game and grind your units against theirs in an effort to learn.

One of my all time favorites! If you are into military strategy/tactics/vehicles you will probably love this game. It’s like command and conquer on steroids and much more realistic. 10/10 game, tough learning curve but worth it in the end if you stick with it.

This game will chew you up and spit you out, and the learning curve seems nearly impossible at first glance. However, I have yet to find another game (Especially another RTS) that can provide such an entertaining, nail biting, and satisfactory experience. And I believe that with some practice and determination, anyone can learn to love this game.

The scope and scale is the perfect middle-ground between the grand scope of HOI 4 and the more Up-close style of Starcraft and it is perfect for a Cold War RTS game of this caliber. The game is just over 5 years old and the graphics still hold up rather well (except for the nightmare inducing faces of some infantry units) And when watching a replay of a match without HUD can provide a nice cinematic experience.

Now's what makes or breaks the game for a new player: The skill curve. When you first boot up the game there is no in-depth tutorial what-so-ever and the game essentially leaves you with 4 options: 
1. Go into multiplayer (Where you will be destroyed) 
2. Play the campaign (Where you will be destroyed)
3. Make a Deck (Where you will have no idea what you are doing, But I highly recommend as it allows you to get a feel for it and see what different nations and coalitions have)
4. Play a Skirmish match with AI (The best way to have your first game; create a match with 4 Easy AI on the other team and 3 Medium+ AI on your team)

Skirmish allows you to get a feel for the basic controls and have a little fun with it. From here, I HIGHLY recommend you start looking at some tutorials on Youtube for basics in Deck Building, General unit strengths and weaknesses, etc. After you do your homework and you have a brand-new deck you can go test it out in a 1v1 or 2v2 skirmish against AI or if you're feeling ballsy, a 10v10 Multiplayer match.

It may not seem like it at first but with every loss or victory from being carried by your team you will learn very valuable information. In addition to that I highly recommend going and watching your replays after a match to see what you and your enemy or teammates did wrong or right also watching streamers and content creators play can introduce you to higher level tactics and counters for certain units.

Eventually if you keep sticking with the game and trying out different units you'll come to find your own preferences and you can learn how to build decks around certain units and unit types. The deck creator is a game within itself and can provide and interesting experience as you have to know what role you want that deck you play in a battle. This is where the game gets the most fun and although it may seem like a rough road to get there (and it can be) I promise you that your first 1v1 victory will feel extremely satisfying.

I don't have time to learn all the little f ing things needed to build a military force or start a battle.  So unless you got the time and patience, Don't get it or you will be sorry. good

Future classic. The quintessential Cold War game. Very active multiplayer (as of April 2019),  probably will be until servers stay up, due to its quality and uniqueness. 

Vast number of nations to pick from. Game lured me in with Yugoslavia DLC pack, which in itself is very unique. No other game that I know of lets you play as Yugoslavia. 

If casual multiplayer is your thing, the 10v10 servers are perfect for beginners. Being slower paced, they allow you to learn the ropes & have fun doing it. The 1v1 and 4v4 modes are more serious and fast paced akin to starcraft or other high octane RTS.

Servers are up 24/7. I never have to wait long to grab a lobby, and soon after the game starts. During prime time it's instant with many lobbies up. Bellow I'll include a write up on getting started in multiplayer.
Lots can be said about the community but it's definitely a cult niche, take a look at subreddit /r/wargame. Memes being put out on a weekly basis five years after game release says enough by itself. 

=======================================================================

Beginners intro to Multiplayer: 

10v10 are the noob friendly games, they remind of warcraft 3 customs. You control only portions of the whole army which allows you to focus on micro, and really grasp the mechanics. 10v10 Tacticals are very much suited for solo learning. They give you ample time to make your decisions and observe how others play. It's more like a moba with less units to control and you dont feel as overwhelmed. Once you get ahead of the game you can move on to faster modes that are more akin to traditional RTS if you so wish. 

In said tacticals pick your niche and learn it well. You can stick with your choice of specialty, say tanks. When you learn tanks in and out expand to another niche say infantry and eventually stick to one or be an all rounder. Myself i stick to air, but sometimes i learn different things due to boredom or wanting to win. During the game, focus on securing a sector and observe how others play, their spacing in particular and what units they take.

When you get enough of tactical you can move on to different modes that require faster decision making due to responsibility of sheer number of units. It becomes less of a micro/tactic game and more of a macro/strategic game. Use the knowledge you learned and you wont feel so overwhelmed. You can like myself just stay in tacticals if that's the game pacing you prefer. Beware of elitism here, there is no right way or wrong way to play this game so explore until you find the mode that suits you.

Also recommend picking a nation or coalition and sticking with it for some time so you can refine your deck (a "deck" is the units available to call up, which you can customize in the armory) . If you change a lot you might not learn what works in a deck and what doesn't. There is a lot to memorize but it's pretty much a joy to do if you take it easy.

And lastly, dont take heed to toxic comments during the game, plenty of hotheads around in cold war ;) Hope you find your game mode and stick around because this game has a lot to offer. Incredible scope & depth. 

Enjoy the Cold War & Have fun!

If you love tactics or tactical games without the insane (and unfair) RNG this is for you!

First, let me get this out the way.

[b] The game is not an RTS base builder! [/b]

You have a limited amount of units you need to use efficiently and tactically. Yes, you can spawn and send your best battle tank straight to the frontline, however, they will get melted by two well-paced gunships. There is nothing that brings a tear to your eye like losing 8 Abrahams tanks to 2 Russian helicopters. Worse still is losing 6 helicopters to a sneaky Tungusta hidden in the forest.

This aspect is what I like most. Units are both insanely strong and paper weak at the same time. You need to find the correct time to deploy them. The units you command feel just as powerful as you would imagine in real life. One  AH64 Apache can destroy am entire assault if used correctly or get destroyed by a single missile battery you overlooked before firing a missile.

There is slight monotony between the various units of the different nations (USA, Canada, UK etc), but I find the specialisations (airborne, armoured, mechanised, etc) keeps me building new decks and diving back into combat. 

Since the game is a few years old the units do not represent the latest in military technology, but this can be overlooked.... for now.

I only kept playing this game because steam wouldn't give me a refund for a reasonable amount of playtime to determine if I wanted this game. The following is the result of having been forced to keep this game:

I am now 60 hours into the game. I need to revise my review, and now recommend this game with SEVERE reservations. I now have an extremely practiced and experienced hand with the fine, granular details of the game. I have studied it, failed over and over, and rage quit many times (from SP, I don't play MP). My love of this series kept drawing me back. After mastering switching between bullet time and very slow time modes anytime any actual combat occured; after mastering the campaign map and save scumming when stupid mistakes were made and I failed to PERFECTLY MAX/MIN my moves several turns in advance; after finding every perfect weaponeering, or target to weapon match in the game and ensuring I had overmatch in every battle; and after failing over, and over, and over, and over to get to this point I now feel I can competently take on the AI. I've beaten all the campaigns up to (and currently playing) Climb Mount Narodnaia, and I'm now having a blast.

I've played games with learning curves from hell before. I play DCS A-10 competently and thoroughly understand the flight systems, tactics, and procedures in flying A-10s in order to get the most out of that game. Wargame: RD is different. This games makes it NOT fair. You don't always lose because you did something wrong. you sometimes lose because you did not execute every single minute tactical detail frame perfectly. you sometimes lose because you failed to totally annihilate the enemy. You sometimes lose because they hid one 4-man (infantry) command unit in a jungle and you have less than 5 minutes to find them otherwise your entire division sized advance is halted on the strategic map. You lose for reasons that would make no sense in real life. I despise Max/Min'ing but in this case, the rest of the game makes up for it.

Seeing your forces annihilate a tank regiment frontal assault, barely clinging on and surviving as you desperately hover over the deployment butrton waiting for JUST ONE MORE command point to deploy ONE LAST ground attack aircraft, whose cluster bombs are the ONLY thing that can pause this iron tidal wave for just a few seconds, just a few seconds to get one more SACLOS shot off, or one second for your RPG team to move a city block is exhilarating. Frustrating, yes absolutely.

I think my original review is still valid, I left it in here. The Difficulty settings in Wargame: AB made the game accessable and allowed you to scale the challenge whern things got too easy to give you that sense of accomplishment. Red Dragon gives you a few tools to help along the way, but mostly says "If you are not intimately familiar with this game, go to hell and die". After you suffer for weeks of playtime, however, it slowly reveals its tactical and strategic brilliance.

For those saying practice in skirmish mode with the decks, I can't play a meaningless game with no story or background as to WHY it matters that my tank battalion and infantry regiment should succeed on this map. That's also why I don't play MP. It no fun to have to practice in skirmish.

TL;DR This game is punishing and hates you for trying to learn it. It is blatantly unfair, punished you for lack of mastery, and gives you little chance to learn. If you can suffer through it, and can accept defeat after defeat for the smallest of imperfections, you will learnt o fully grasp the game and can enjoy the brilliant tactical and strategic depth of Wargame: Red Dragon.

P.S. Eugen, RELEASE MORE CAMPAIGNS! Some of us don't give a crap about unit packs we will never see because they don't show up in a campaign!

Original Review:
Wargame: Red Dragon removed the ability to adjust AI difficulty. I do not play frenetic, multiplayer RTS clickfests so the campaign is the only thing I loved about the Wargame series. Airland Battle was a stellar accomplishment and set the bar so high for me, I was looking forward to this one. But without the ability to set difficulty, I will never be able to compete with a cheating AI and finish the hardest campaigns. This is a strategy game, so it takes several hours to decide what the game is all about, in my case 10. Steam will not issue a refund for a game played more than two hours, which is BS since I can beat an FPs in two hours, and I haven't gotten past the character creation screen in an RPG in 2 hours...

I have found after many hours that game difficulty is really controlled by the custom deck allocations. I always use custom decks I create myself. The type and number of units you assign yourself and the enemy AI is critical to the difficulty. An example is tanks. If you allow the enemy AI to have cheap tanks but give yourself only the most modern and expensive tanks (with say only 4 available), the enemy will throw a swarm of tanks against your four and you will die. I recommend using a very restricted deck (for the player and the AI) to start with, say only 6 unit cards available. This will drop the difficulty down and a wise selection of units will enable the difficulty to be adjusted by the user by trial and error. I am pretty happy with my custom decks. I no longer have games where I am anihilated by a vastly superior enemy.

I can't believe of all the games on my Steam library that I haven't written a review on this one. In a nutshell it's, by far, the best Wargame title to date. But what's there to like/dislike:

The good:

- Replayability from a multiplayer experience. Though the maps remain the same, the way MP games play varies each and every time. Sometimes it's a cake walk. Sometimes it's a good fight. Sometimes it's a kick in the teeth contest. Playing with people you know (even if you don't agree with their personal views on a regular basis) is a satisfying experience. 

- Pace. Again this varies from match to match but it's not a "who-can-click-the-fastest" game. The game rewards a player who can view the situation at hand and respond correctly to it. Thinking two steps ahead can be difficult at times and if anything it's this constant "what next" mentality that rewards a smart player. By far situational awareness is one of the most challenging aspects that I still struggle with each and every time I play. Tip: Play as zoomed out as far as your eyes can handle it. 

- Unit selections. The number is staggering of the number of units you can get your hands on in this game. From Cold War era to more modern entries, chances are your infantry/tank/etc is in this one. 

- Deck builder. One of the best features of the game is making a deck from scratch and then seeing what works/what doesn't work/etc. Because there are SO many units to choose from it isn't easy as it sounds. 

- Best played with friends. Months ago I would have said some type of voice communication was essential to play. Now it's an extra bonus. It's easy to meet people who do enjoy playing and despite the community (that part coming) it's rewarding to help people who are new to the game and made the same mistakes that either I still make (lack of recon/AA/etc) or did make in the past. 

The bad:

- Toxic community doesn't do the word "toxic" justice. For someone new to the game the best advice I can give you is immediately mute Wargame chat (the in-game "twitter" feed is about the best way to put it). If you like to associate with racists, bigots, and people who apparently have nothing better to do than spread hate then maybe that appeals to you. For me I muted this a long time ago. Absolutely no good can come from trying to start a legitimate conversation in wargame chat. And for the toxic players you will meet in a game. Click the mute button. You have been warned...

- Learning curve. The game itself (from a single player perspective) doesn't do a good job of teaching what should be fundamental basics. Using recon effectively is such a key to a good multiplayer experience that you can almost tell a person is new just by looking at their recon percentage. And that's just one small aspect of learning the game. Successfully attacking a heavily defended position, using air assets, using artillery are just some more components that come to mind. On top of this, in a multiplayer experience, you need to be aware of how well your teammates are doing (or not doing). The pay off is when it all comes together, it is a rewarding experience. 

- A lack of map editor/campaign editor. I bought this game back when it was released in March 2013. Why the Developers didn't allow modding tools for these two things boggles my mind. Just these two things alone could bring new life to this game but I doubt the day will ever come since the publisher/developer parted ways. 

- Lobby simulator. Do yourself a favor. If you're a new player join or make a lobby for players at your level. And enjoy the waiting game. Depending upon the time of day your lobby could almost instantly fill. Or you could wait 15-30 minutes (and sometimes longer) for a lobby to fill up. 

The indifferent:

I don't know how many hours I have logged on this game. 4000 plus easily over a 5 year period. And with that much time under my belt I still have my days where I just plain suck at it. I learn more from my losses than my wins. And as such I try to review replays as much as I can to see:

1) What I did wrong
2) What the other player did that I couldn't answer to
3) And then use that information to learn to hopefully learn from the mistakes that I made

That being said it's okay to have a bad game. You're going to make mistakes. And chances are you'll repeat the mistakes because there's no "predictability" when it comes to different people you face off against. As much as I have tried to learn the game from an SOP stand-point (Do A, when A is done go to B, when B is done go to C) it simply doesn't work. It's taken me years to finally realize that concept. 

All in all I have to say this game ranks up to one of my all-time favorite games to play. If you have the time and patience to learn the game you will enjoy it too.

I played ALB years ago before taking a couple year break from gaming as this was released. I just came back 3-4 months ago, and the game has a pretty defined meta currently refined by top players across the world since it's release.

As far as multiplayer goes, you can play 10v10s on a few maps and feel safe that whatever you do isn't going to matter very much, unless it is a 'tactical' match. These large games attract people who typically will specialize in tank rushes / plane rushes / helo rushes, or the most cancerous of all, the artillery support deck.
This is mostly played as a destruction game mode where points killed achieve victory.

Tactical matches have very low points given to each team, which allows you to 'role play' a small force in the game, where you can practice micromanaging a tank and mortar combination, a single bomber to use sparingly, or a group of infantry etc.. Some even can play as a 'medic' delivering supplies to injured / out of gas / out of ammo units. 

Now for conquest game mode:

You need to divide the map up in a way to where you can control more zones than your opponent, so your opener is key and aggression and and speed or patient combined arms usage will allow you to push into a fortified zone.

You can play 1v1s ranked and over time earn ELO and may play against some of the top players in the game who still remain. I would recommend starting out playing in non-ranked lobbies you create yourself until you feel comfortable with the game. There is no one to put the blame on but yourself, and learning the 7 maps in the rotation are vital to success.

Once you have the basics down, make some friends or join lobbies for 2-4 vs 2-4 others. You can use smaller maps but it is suggested to play as they are labeled. Double-pushing one side while one of your teammates defends typically gives you an advantage. 

There is a little schism and elitist attitude towards what type of player plays each game mode, but as the developer has made ranked conquest with 1000 starting points, 40 minute, medium income games on 7 mostly balanced maps, it really does become the game mode requiring the greatest skill, and once you learn how to play conquest and attack, going back and playing destruction seems like child's play to a good player.

I feel sad that I missed the heyday of this game, but it seems to be in a revival this month due to some popular youtubers.

I only get 5-10 games in a week, and through trial and error and practice am learning via the 'bootcamp' mentors, razzman and others YT videos, and hopefully will feel comfortable enough with the game to play anyone anytime and it will feel like second nature again, assuming Eugen doesn't have to shut down the servers as a result of a lawsuit they are facing and go bankrupt.

A note on DLC: Israel and The Reds Double pack are slightly OP/P2W, having unique jets that do stuff others don't, stealthy tanks that are high powered, ATGM squads that fire fast and hit hard, and Infrared AA units that are not susceptible to SEAD bombers.

My 2 cents: buy the game while it is on sale, and all of the DLC. Worst case scenario you will fall in love with it and become another salty grizzled vet, best case scenario you will shut off warchat lobby and stay out of 10v10s and git gud :)

Well at almost 300 hour of gameplay now i can say that im not a noob anymore.
I made the mistake of early judgement when i started to play CoH2 and i didnt wanted to make it again so i waited to review the game until i can prperly play with it.
And its good.

So first of all this game has a huge learning curve and not just becouse you have to get use to the controls and hotkeys and tacics. It has more then a thousand unit (more than a 1000) so you cannot predict what you gonna go against from the lobby until you familiar with the nations and its units and its decks when its a specialized decks. 
So i can fairly say that you not gonna be good at this game, not even decent until you hit above 200 hour.
But if you are new there is plenty of noob out there to test your metal, just make a lobby with noob in the name and check profile.

So the game is a strategy game with a huge chunk of tactical elements. You basicly command at least a battalion sometime even a regiment size force on a huge map  (couple dozens square mile).  You can order units pretty much like any other rts, but you dont have to build anything, you capture zones and those zones will provide income to spend on your units.
Zones are huge, and to capture it you have to deploy a command unit on it. But if you doesnt secure the whole zone the enemy can do the same rendering the zone to netural and no one will get income out of it.
That means that gameplay is build around fighing in the zone, securing the flanks and harrasing enemy reinforcments.
There are some cheesier way to win, especially against noobs (helirush, mob rush, air support abuse), but you will learn to counter those.

Units are semi realisticm, they in a way represent how that unit works in real life, and the impact of that unit on the battlefield.. In the same time they have health bars and stay operational until those bars vanish.
To be clear the units have health, armor, moral, accuracy, range, he damage, ap damage, optics, size, visibility, a chance to be amphibious. There are special things with special units, for example some artiery and air bomb is filled with napalm causing huge fires that demoralize and hurt units in them while preventing visibility. Many anti air units using radar to hit its target, but some planes are using those radar sign to lead there anti aa rockets on them. So you have to constantly turn in and out the radasr systems.
There is many little tips and tactics around the net and you should look them up if you wanna play this game.
And of course there is the smoke wich is a must have in attack. Without it your unis will walk into a killzone and they will be destroyed. So learn to use shift + v a lot.

Graphicly the game is aéright, and not demanding. A very mediocare pc can run it high on 1080p.

Sound is generic, i personally dont care.

Multiplayer is alive and well. There are even 10v10 servers where you will  see real warlike scenarios. 
But ofcourse like any other game where you have to rely on your team mates, there are moments when you just shake your head the stupidity of another human being, or get trolled by some miserable creature who try to ease his sorrow over its pathetic life by killing friendly units.

So all in one, thats a good game. Thats a hard game. If you like modern warfare, have patience and a will to learn than its for you.

Find a team and play! once you have a team this game jumps to a whole new level of fun.

The game has aged well too. While there are fewer players on it is still loads of fun. I wish they would add new campaigns though. 

Multiplayer is definatley the bread and butter though.

TLDR: want a technical kickass RTS with big tanks, attack helicopters and Sh*ttalking? Look no more. 

The Wargame franchise and esp Red Dragon show there's still a spot for technical Strategy games. I don't know of a single other RTS game that gives you a seamless blend of tactical unit management and strategic collaborative combat.

RD is not a quick digestible game with heavy handholding. The single campaign is intuitive and definitely a fun way to introduce yourself to the game. The AI gets predictable at some points but it's a chance to see what every deck (nation) is made of. 

The multiplayer is where sh*t gets real. First understand two things:
1. Building decks is a big deal and part of the experience. You can easily find cool videos online (personnal fan of Stealth17) that will walk you through most nations and units. It can take 5 min to 1hr depending on how technical you want to get. 
2. Strategy is something you can easily pick up. Again ytube is your friend - you have some pretty decent players as well as some of the champions. 


I've played a fair amount of RD. I've tried to move to something else but keeps bringing me back. You start getting techie about maps, units and players. In the beginning, it's tough. You're looking for your strengths (airborne, infantry, armoured...) and you end up in some crappy games. But Game types/maps are very varied and you can start with large 10v10s to see how other players play and move on to 2v2, 1v1 when you know you can carry a team. 

The community is a mixed bag. You get some absolute legends - high-level players who are happy to help you learn. Others are special cookies. Thankfully you've got tough skin right?
I like, good game.

War Game: Red Dragon scratches the itch to tinker with military units in a RTS setting.  Plenty of games fall into this category, but I have not played any that match its realism.  Each decision made must consider the speed of each unit, its rate of fire, its range, its strengths and weaknesses, and its utility.  This attention to detail makes mission planning fun and exciting.   

I recommend this game to anyone who wants to play a military RTS and loves the idea of focusing on the application of its hundreds of military units.

But I wish the B-2 Spirit stealth bomber was in it, and also recon aircrafts. While having bombers and atack jets are great, you almost never have a reason to keep your craft out very long due to the dangers of AA and Low Fuel.

Information is everything in this game, So I think they should try adding Recon Crafts, Radar Crafts, etc. Things that have really long range vision and can ignore vision block, but have no weapons and contain high fuel.

It is just something I had always thought about ever since I started playing, that would make taking out AA more of a priority as well as using aircrafts. Most jets are fairly disposable and I really only find myself holding onto heavy bombers and napalm jets, but everything else tends to just be expendable.

The idea is to cover Air, Land, and Sea combat. We have scout units, and those are useful, but they feel underwhelming and not as interesting as the idea of a Sonar Truck relaying coordinates to atillary or a Radar Plane giving a quick data relay on a tank platoon to the east.

Aircrafts are great for offensive use in this game, but I feel as though the "Support" Catagory is really missing out by not having Utility units.

But other then that, this game really does drag you into tactical cut throat scenarios. It's quite exilerating.
Just wish they'd keep bringing in DLC and make some more campaigns.

The game itself is very good. That´s why it´s pretty sad to give a negative review, but I can´t recommend to buy the game.
To quickly sum up the graphics: it´s good, the game looks pretty nice, but not overwhelming. The unit models are partly very good, partly not at all (GB tanks).
The basic gameplay is quite easy to understand. The problem is that there is no way to learn the game. When you try to get into a public game, you will face nearly only players who are rank 20 and above (200h+ multiplayer). And they completely destroy you, while you are sitting in front of your screen and have no idea what´s happening. You just look as your entire army disappears. 
If you want to fight against AI you can do that too. The problem is that it exploits the fact that it is an AI as often as it can. From remembering everything, seeing everything, knowing the exact distances so that you can´t shoot it, the AI just spams as many units as they can, attack you in so many places that you just can´t keep up as a player. On top of that the AI cheats with the points they start with (confirmed) and the points they get (I have read it, but no proof), something that imo happens way too often in strategy games.
It´s fun when you are playing with your friends. Maybe try out the game on a sale when a lot of new players are trying it out. Otherwise, better not buy it

This game is one of the best real-time modern warfare tactical simulators to date.
Not too complicated to step into, but deep enough to keep even the most hardcore wargamers satisfied.
Pros:
- modern warfare era! not many games introduce it in such a great way
- wide variety of units (land, air and sea) with stats as historically accurate as possible
- pretty well balanced, lots of tactics and counter-tactics, and all of that does make sense comparing to the real world warfare tactics (as we know it)
- intense and challenging, especially in multiplayer
- fun naval battles
- multiplayer provides pretty cool
- it is beautiful! and zoom is perfect, the game does look like an aerial view of the battlefield
Cons:
- takes some time to get familiar with unit decks, stats and tactics that actually work
- single player campaign battles become quite simple and repetitive at some point
- if not playing with your friends, waiting for a new multiplayer game to fill up may take up to 10-15 minutes basing on the game type and players' levels
P.S. Steel Division is their next game, and also lots of fun. And Steel Division 2 is coming. But Wargame will always stay the real love of mine.

Great RTS.  Difficult to master.  It keeps handing me my @ss in the Campaign mode.   Its robbery on the DLCs, but I have them and I like having the different coutries.  Multiplayer is fun, but typically hard to find a game, and if its usually more tahn 1 vs 1, there are always quitters in the middle of it.  But its worth the money.

Really hard to pick up, at first, and then all of the udden it all makes sense. It's a great tactical war game with impressive visuals for such a type of RTS. I would just ignore the campaign it has no depth and just feels awkward; the campaign is nothing like say Total War.. there's just very little too it. Instead create a simple deck and practice against the AI in skirmish mode. You can also reduce the points awards so that neither you or the AI get flooded with more units available than you can micro manage.

Is it fun? Yes it is. This is possibly the most fun RTS game I've ever played. Its secret is in its depth and the UNBELIEVEABLE number of units to construct into army decks, which you then deploy directly onto the field with no base-building. This is the game that I play whenever I want to be reminded why I love RTS. It's the most unique and addictive game I've ever had the pleasure of getting stomped in. 

BUT...
There are some caveats. The community on the in-game text chat is absolutely psychotic. There is no playable tutorial, just a set of text documents that tell you about the game mechanics and unit types. The difficulty curve is like trying to climb a 90 degree cliff while wearing roller skates, and for the first few hours you're not going to have any idea what is going on. And finally, the story campaigns are lackluster and honestly not what you're really there for. 

Are these deal breakers? No, they aren't. I still love this game in spite of its faults. It's a masochistically hard Real Time Strategy that shines like a beacon of innovation in a mostly stagnant genre. You simply have to play it just to see the incredible depth and intensity that RTS games can deliver.
for some reason everytime I try to run the game it opens an error box which sys it didnt previously terminate properly. how do i fix this??

A great, challenging RTS game for cold war and strategy lovers.
With the inclusion of naval battles largely improved graphics with a new and improved campaign system it has to be my favourite wargame yet.
It takes a learning curve and even more so for non RTS players but if you get into it, it can be very fun, and you can obviously play online in multiplayer with your friends and do skirmishes with the computer with lots of AI.
I love the campaign briefs and battles, they feel challenging and very rewarding to win and beat with different types of victories to be achieved at the end depending on how well you do: Total victory, major and minor.
Lots of maps to choose and loads of nations with more available via buying DLC to unlock. (I'd recommend Israel since they have amazing units)
Some negatives are that it can suffer from input lag when you have lots of AI going on in skirmishes and it also resource intensive. To get the best experience, aim for a faster PC with a decent graphics card and processor. A GTX 1060/ RX 480 would allow a great experience with higher graphics and a smoother framerate, but you can play it with lower obviously.
Overall a great game and if you like the wargame franchise and enjoy RTS it is worth a try!

Had such high hopes for this game until I got twenty minutes into the very first campaign. Let me start with the good things about it.

Pros: Gorgeous graphics and well-designed units, great feel for modern combat, great concept for the campaign with the strategic resources, naval battles, and amphibious landings.

Cons: WAY TOO FAST PACED!!! I understand people like games fast and interesting, but when you spend literally every second of a 20 minute battle micromanaging every last little unit or else they will kill themselves, there is no time to enjoy the game or it's beautiful graphics. In fact, you'll never get to zoom in and enjoy the game itself, so it might as well be a top down strategy with hexes for what it's worth. Also, there are many many broken features in the game. Recon does so little to spot enemies you might as well not use them, ships are clunky and difficult to understand, infantry is next to pointless, and the air mechanic is rather hard to master too. Throw in the fact that there are dozens of units, all known by their native name (if you don't understand Korean or Chinese, don't bother) that you have to literally study and memorize in order to understand how to employ them effectively. Which of course you can't do because there's no time to stop and watch what's happening in a battle!!!
One of the biggest wastes of my time ever.

This is one of the best RTS games ever made. While difficult to pick up and learn, once you do learn it it's the most visually satisfying and pleasing games ever. It took me ages to learn how to play; I'm still far from perfect but for experienced RTS and modern millitary fans this is  must.

The whole game is amazingly fun to play and the fact that no two matches are the same, really makes it better in my eyes. 

The only real problem has to be the steep learning curve though.
The best strategy game ever! I hope the team continue to develop the game and don't let it die.

I wasn't that into this game at first since I basically had been kick in the ass by the computer in the easiest campaign. And It's true that this game basically have no tutorial ingame. I have absolutely no idea what are those statistics of the unit mean, how the game mechanic works and even how to control my unit. 

Well, this game is not designed for someone who easily frustrated, to be honest. The first 100 hours i put into this game is not playing, it is all about learning, from community, from youtube, from google, etc. Its noteworthy to mention that the community of this game is incrdible that it even published a 200 pages guide  - and I spent like 5-6 hrs to study it, somehow. And even now I hadn't fully explore 10% content of this game - The maps, the units, the combination, the tactics and strategies. 

But those learning worths it. Just worth it. The sense of achievement is AMAZING after i completed the first campaign. Then the second, third and so on. I am now trying out the MP and embarrassed to say have yet to win a game. But I have fun, a lot. 

It is the RTS game might not be as realistic as it claims, but for me, who like to learn, analyze, plan and execute the plan, this is one of the most entertaining game I found.

If you consider yourself a gamer who like hardcore military theme RTS game, you should try this out.
Fantastic game. Huge amount of units, unit detail is amazing, scale is amazing, and the depth of tactics you can use is immense. If you like what you see, buy it. I promise that you won't regret it!
