Well the cold war was amazing right? We've almost blew ourselves up several times by nations carrying nuclear arsenal from across, sharing hands and guns to each other while someone from afar just laughs at you for being dumb? As if there's any hope left in humanity, you should drown yourself with this game instead. [i]Get it? Drown yourself cause this game got ships? Haha... ok ill stop[/i]

But for real though, if you've been playing the past Wargame titles, the only additions here are the factions on the far east, with the dlcs offering more factions at the same time as well. I had my fun with this for a long time, and I thought the Soviets would remain to be ridiculous per strength till Israel came along to prove us wrong. [i]oof.[/i] Read about the other reviews about the core gameplay, but as for the naval combat it's not that much attractive per say. 

Goddamn I love and hate the naval combat on this game, and it all depends on which side you serve on. REDFOR would obviously win naval confrontations unless you play smart against them as BLUFOR. It's an obvious difference of comparison for the opposing navies however, as the BLUFOR ships are more oriented for naval confrontations from a distance while escorting carrier groups, whereas REDFOR ships packs up a punch for direct ship-to-ship combat. Now this sounds like Soviet bias, but it's an obvious advantage by now that unless you have something to fight off their missile attacks, they will always have the seas under their control. This does not exclude them for being attacked from land and air however, as even a freaking M1A1 Abrams a year ago from the match I've played just sunk a cruiser not too close. You obviously have units exclusively armed with anti-ship armaments and BLUFOR obviously includes this with their fighter jets. 

And that's just about it, should I really recommend this game to everyone? Yeah. It's a good game, better than it's predecessors, but goddamn was this game left out on the cold and didn't bother updating it to Post-Cold War conditions like the latest technologies of today right now, would've given it more of a life for a year or two.
Good game if ur not a retard.

Cons

Facing units can be a problem at times, I will tell one repeatedly which way to face and he ignores me and keeps his weak side armor facing the oncoming enemy for some reason, seems more buggy playing game at a slower speed which i usually do. Issue seems resolved in normandy, which they reverse engineered it to this which is probably the best of all the wargames IMO. 

To capture and hold a territory you need a command unit and it has to stay in there motionless forever. They are pricey and make it feel somewhat like a burden to hold captured territories to me, though I guess that is probably reflecting a real world feel of the ease at which you can take land but the difficulty to keep and control. Really bothered me at first, but after you get used to them it does make you choose between holding everything or having a giant fighting force.  

NO TUTORIAL. That is the biggest drawback to this game, it desperately needed one that is playable and instead you only get a few pages to read. Its just not enough to teach you the game. Years later I found and bought the predecessors to this game and you really should buy and start with European Escalation, if you dont you will need to watch some you tube vids to learn how to play. 

Pros

Lot of available units
Lot of diversity in units
Will teach you a lot about military units, the hard way ;)
Great campaign mode, especially if you played and liked axis and allies. I love the setup and wish they had made more of these. They get fairly hard, and there are sadly too few.  
Campaign adds another level by not giving you access to everything, instead you have battleunits that must be in province to allow you to take those units. Chopper for choppers arty for artillery etc. Is great if you can focus down say their anti air one battle and then enjoy the next mission where they have none and you rule the skies with impunity. 
Good graphics when you zoom in for a game that didnt really need to since no one but me ever does lol 

Game has come a long way since release when I gave it a thumbs down. After revisiting this and playing again I am changing this to a thumbs up because I really enjoy that campaign mode. So sad they dont have the same thing in future titles like SD Normandy.

This is the best RTS I've ever played.  The learning curve is high but it's the best wargame simulator I've ever seen, and how intense the gameplay is will probably keep you hooked.  Expect to stink when you're new but you'll get the hang of it pretty quick too, you'll be busy as a bee managing the battlefield when you play this game as well especially with certain decks. 
 The AI cheats like crazy so keep that in mind, you have to be a bad ass at the game to beat the AI on the hardest difficulty when it does stuff like spawn KA-52's the whole game and have more units on the battlefield than it should be allowed.  The rumor is that they're not coming out with another Wargame and this game looks really good graphically too so even grabbing it at full price isn't a bad idea.  

I haven't been into RTS games in a very long time and the fact that they base this game on real life (other than the story that makes the Cold War break into a hot war) is what makes this the closest to a 10/10 game and maybe my favorite I've played in the past decade.  It's a very intense game, I felt awful the first few times my Marines were napalmed.  It's just a game though!

Pros:
-Large unit variety
-Interesting stats and quirks
-Stunning battles

Cons:
-High learning curve
-Some units are obsolete and others are a must have for any deck
-Used to be a victim of power creep(I don't know if it is still)
-There used to be a strike going on at the dev's headquarters
-Some maps are terrible with one choke point
-Small community

Opinionated
-Warchat can be funny to some and triggering for others. I personally find the warchat funny but that's because i'm used to politcally incorrect jokes. So if you're ok with that then the warchat shouldn't be an issue. If you're not just ignore the chat completely.

It's a super niche game with a lot of quirks but if you're willing to learn this stuff you will have a lot of fun. The best part of this game is the deck system. When you start getting used to meta decks, you will start to experiment with deck compositions. Compounded with the game's mechanics, the game opens up a lot of avenues for success and failure. It's a fun game if you like experimenting with units.

Im only listing cons on this so assume anything that isnt listed here is a pro.

A.I. being omnipotent and problems with artificial difficulty - this is literally my only complaint. How the heck can the A.I. always know where im at or what im doing without scouts. I wasnt so angry about it initially because I really loved this game but hooooooly crap I didnt realize how bad it was until I had beaten all the campaigns and started doing 1v1 or more.

Look if i spawn units the AI should not be mortaring the position they are going to before they get there. 

Also why does my smoke blind me but not them but their smoke blinds me but not them???? 

Next im getting hit with mortars so I slow the time to find were they are firing from and as soon as I give the fire POS  command.... the mortars stop and I cant find the anymore. OK IM SURE THEY ARENT WATCHING THE VISION CONE OF MY CAMERA GUYS.

Next how come when im literally just reeming the enemy they magically seem to develope this weird as fuck ability to override LOS and Highground to make an enourmous comeback and even out the score. Yea thats totally not artificial difficulty.

In general the game is great but the AI becoming a super gamer and glitch manupulator when I am destroying it is totally not fair. I even took all the recon units out of a deck I made and gave it to the AI and it just spawned infinite helicopters to make up for the fact it had no scouts. I checked the kill count on my way out and I had shot down over 100 aircraft... he only had 25 so yea guys thats blatantly cheating.

Other than all that suff this game dope. Buy this game.

This game has been in my library for ages, I tried to play it once but couldn't be bothered with Youtube videos lasting 1 hour and reading all the tutorials. Anyway, today I decided to give it a go but I just loaded up a 2v2 skirmish match, I put a "very hard" level player on my side with 2 US pre-made decks against 2 Russians bots and let it roll. I wish I did this before as it made it much more fun and easy to learn than long videos or lots of reading. There is no pressure because your ai bot will handle the other team. 

The first match, I just watched my ai bot rip apart the other 2 players and was impressed with the graphics and the way it played out and it made me keen to learn. I didn't even know how to deploy my units but my ai handled the other team whilst I just zoomed in on stuff and was in awe of how good it looked. 

Next game I'd looked in the controls and found the button how to deploy my units and then over the next few games I was free to experiment with different units and the controls. I've slowly picked most the basics up and have notched up it to 2 medium bots as i've improved. Still alot to learn but it's been nothing but fun so far I see myself playing this a lot. I don't mind watching some videos or reading on deeper tactics now as I have a point of reference and desire to learn to the game even more because it is a masterpiece. 

I think I got it in a humble bundle so it's great value for the level of detail and sheer amount of different units is amazing! I would say for me it would be worth full price as I will get at least 30 hours out it and I rate acceptable value at £1 per hour played for a game.

EDIT: I decided to give Steel Division a go after i liked this much and I like that even more, it's a bit more polished and easier to get into. I will still come back to this because of the modern units but Steel Division is even better for me so I will be clocking up more hours on that first.

I'm going to say this first, I fucking sucked at this game. That being said I still loved the shit out of it. The game runs very smooth and there are many, many, many options on how you organize your forces. I have to say I did NOT play this game for its story. The real reason I believe most people play this game is for the online aspect. I have to say nothing is more satisfying then seeing all the T-54s and T-34s finally make a successful tank rush after massacre after massacre of my brave obsolete armored divisions. The chat room will be immediately confused where all of your cheap Chinese or USSR infantry has been the entire game when out of the blue the red army marches forth in massive numbers of shit units but make no mistake, these are YOUR shit units and you have a LOT of them. You drive the enemy back from their charge driving into the heart of their land as the tide of battle turns and as you rush the enemy HQ you hear a noise. The enemy players have commenced a massive coordinated artillery and air strike against your forces. You close your eyes and shed a few tears as your Red Army is baptized by fire in a clean 60 frames per second... Then you resume doing the same shit over again till your entire team is begging you to ungroup your tanks.
By far the best RTS ive ever played ( - C&C)

I had an issue with the CD key that was included that you need to creat an account in the game. The devs or whoever does tech support quickly helped me out with my issues and cleared it up within a day.

This game is hard, it will challenge you and you will die...because your 4 tanks will have to defeat their 400. But you will get better and will find yourself zooming in to watch your jets rain death on your enemy. 

This is a brilliant game that has something for everybody (for the smartarses out there, something for everyone that likes this genre) with deck building multiplayer matches, a decent campaign that lets you experience alternate histories from invaisions of Hong Kong and the 2nd Korean War. Even skirmishes are fun.

Well worth the sale price, but pick up some dlc whilst it is discounted.

I wanna start off by saying that I've played a lot of RTS games relitive to the short space of time I've lived on this tiny rock in the universe. I love that you game pick most well armed and terrfing countires to battle against each other ona battle group level (as in mass number of units) field of this kind. Yes yes yes I know to, there are other game out there like this. But some of them are more SI-FI or old age game (like total war ROME for example) but this is likst kinda like modern day. ( it's only really goes to the 90's era level tech for ground, air and naval assest and most of them are un a prototype classifcation) but still, this game is alot of fun to play.

I mainly play just against the AI with my own custom decks with friends. I also write this with about 592 hours in this game alone, I've got like 400+ (I think) on the air land battle game before this one. They are just both so good. that's why I'm finally writing this about this game.

So if you like a nice big scale fight with great maps and a boat load of conutires to play, with either yourself, frends or against other players. Then this is the game for you.

Wargame red dragon is one of my favourite RTS I've ever played:

PROS: 
- Very large unit variety, 1470 units main game, I'm not sure about DLC cause I don't have any
- realistic gameplay and units, units are generally how they are in real life down to the stats and looks, gameplay is realistic, 
-lots of different play styles, like tanks? Well then a armoured deck is for you, like urban warfare and infantry? Try motorized, like fast paced chopper assaults with lots of air support? Then there's airborne, there's many more but I won't go in to all of them speaking of different play styles
- Very fun deck building: I could spend hours creating and customizing decks for different types and different coalitions

THE MEH:
-pretty steep learning curve: with so many units in this game it's hard to remember all of them, and without knowing them you don't know what your up against (but there is a menu in match to see any units stats which helps)

THE BAD

Naval combat:very barebones, currently the redfor navy is much more powerful then their blufor counterparts and the only good tatic is spam missiles till you kill them, would love to see Eugen expand on naval however

The community: this is probably the main thing that turns people away from this game, rather toxic with too many ragequiters or early quitters to count, I haven't been through a single semi large game without someone quitting early in a long time, also the chat is probably the most retarded place I've seen,

CONCLUSION: overall I really like this game but it takes skill to learn but once you do its very fun, one of the most realistic RTS you'll find, if you do end up purchasing, I recommend watching some vids and guides on how to get better, my personal favourite is Sandy gun fox's "200 page guide to wargame red dragon" that has everything you'll need

Guide: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=247884292

Played for numerous hours. The game is worse than European Escalation in that Wargame: EE handled much better and the UI was far more accessible. The game felt much more engaging and would submerge you in the action-packed atmosphere far better than Red Dragon does. Furthermore, Red Dragon has too steep a learning curve to it, and the developers seem uninclined to make further developments/patches to RD aside from the periodic DLC releases that usually carry quite the price tag for adding a sole nation to the player's card deck. 

Red Dragon handles worse and I feel at this point its less about wargame and tactics that the brand was built upon, and more about wreckless carnage and destruction in multi-dimensional battlefield engagements. 

Don't get me wrong, Wargame: RD was a necessary breath of life into the dying genre of RTS and it was a relief to have spent time playing this game and re-experiencing what a quality RTS game could deliver. However, we are at a point where more can be achieved for the RTS community, time to move on to bigger and better things. That time is now.

Overall, I recommend this game because it's semi-realistic, tactical, fun, and absolutely addicting, especially if you're into Cold War miltary tech and alternate history. However, there are some important flaws which I think should be pointed out for anyone thinking of buying it.

Cons:
- the toxic community: A lot, if not most of the experienced players display elitism and gatekeeping by kicking anyone who doesn't have a favorable Win-Loss ratio. While it's understandable that they'd want to play with experienced players, it ends up being counterproductive by preventing new players from ever getting the chance to gain MP knowledge and experience, thus driving many would-be fans away to other games/genres. This negative trend is only compounded by long wait times to fill a game, and that games generally last between 40 minutes to 1 hour, in which time many players simply quit once they feel like they're losing, which makes dealing with this community all the more aggravating.

- not as tactical as previous Wargame: in my opinion, Wargame: Airland Battle is the best Wargame (I didn't play European Escalation), only because it was more tactical. Decks were smaller (fewer units could be called), and much more specialised, which meant it was very important to know how to use your deck to win and to prevent losses. While the importance of tactical knowledge has not been erased in Red Dragon, it's certainly diminished. Since units are more numerous, there is greater incentive and ability for players to simply spam units and rush the enemy because losses are much more bearable this time around (fortunately, this is somewhat offset by the income rate, and most players don't do this and choose to play tactically anyway).

-the AI cheats: Many new players will first try to take on the AI in skirmish mode or campaign in order to pick up the basics. Unfortunately, this is not a good introduction to the game. In skirmish, the enemy AI invariably rushes your positions with dozens upon dozens of cheap units. No matter how many you kill, eventually you'll be overrun by the sheer number of units the AI throws at you. This is not how MP games go (usually) and does nothing to help develop players' offensive tactics (as the AI usually force you into defending).

TLDR:
-Pros: semi-realistic, tactical, addicting af
-Cons: gatekeeping community, less tactical than previous Wargame, bad AI

I really wanna love this game, I really do, but I came in looking for something bordering on hyperrealism, maybe that was me with faulty expectations, all the same. I don't have the problems with the AI everyone else seems to, but at the same time, I just can't get behind a game with so many mismatches and historical imbalances. There are units in this game that are able to kill things that they just can't in real life. I understand this is for balance purposes but I feel there is better ways to go about this. I think what did it in for me is one time, right after I dogfought playing as a tomcat and won (what?), my two squad team of navy seals got wiped by an equal sized element of VDV despite light vehicle support. After that, all the game felt hollow to me, I felt like no matter what I did, I was playing with absolute luck as opposed to anything. Not to mention that the line of sight mechanics bother me, even recon struggles to pick up most non vehicle units until they are in knife fighting range. Eventually it just felt like an exercise in frustration, trying to game whatever small exploits I could and praying that my counter actually did its job, or that my SEALs didn't accidentally somehow get wiped by peasant infantry while fighting entrenched. Sometimes it worked, sometimes it didn't, either way it never really felt like what I was doing was happening because I outhought and manuevered whoever I fought, it felt like dumb luck, even if I was making a tactically correct move.

Ultimatley I have a love hate relationship with it, so I can't just rag on it either. The campaign is pretty good, the most fun I have though, is deck building, deck building is probably the most appealing aspect, something about assembling your army really clicks with me. I also really like the artillery and air game, they are probably my favorites to play, despite the fact that some things in air really don't work like they would. Navy is fun but wickedly imbalanced, like, REDFOR air is pathetic, and BLUFOR ships are equally worthless for their point value. F111G spam can control the game in most cases.

Again, I really wanna love it, but its just far too inconsistent and I never felt like I was playing with tactics, I felt like I was playing with dice, and thats not good in a strategy game.

===[ Summary ]===
Highly suggested for fans of the RTS genre. This is a new, rewarding and realistic spin on the old RTS genre. Base building is replaced with a deck building system that allows for interesting scenarios and seemingly more realistic battles. For those new to the series or RTS in general, it will take a little bit of time to learn, but can be rewarding.

Note, this game is older (in comparison to others), but still has a decent community for the RTS genre.

So used to having all my units killed by Maglans or nimrods or Atacms or nighthawks or patriots or stealth tanks or smerch or sead planes or Infantry or regular tanks or Special forces infantry or even sturmi's wait not that last one but damn 10/10 for the killing

[h1]Overview[/h1]

This is still my favorite RTS game, from my favorite RTS series.

I would still highly recommend this game despite its problems and its dwindling active player population. If you are an enthusiast of military history or like to nerd out over military vehicles, small arms, or aircraft, this is the game for you.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Variety[/b] - Huge variety of units, deck types, and countries to choose from
[*][b]Historical Accuracy[/b] Lots of effort put into accurately reflecting each country's military within the time period
[*][b]Visuals[/b] - Wonderful details on units and environments
[*][b]Gameplay[/b] - Fun gameplay mechanics, that in my opinion have been refined over previous titles to near perfection.
[*][b]Replays[/b] - Records replays so you can learn from your mistakes in multiplayer
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Always Zoomed Out[/b] - There's never a real reason to zoom in and see the nice graphics outside of watching replays, it makes more sense to stay zoomed out for maximum awareness
[*][b]Learning Curve[/b] - Steep learning curve if you're new to the genre or to the series (I've ran tests with introducing this game to people familiar with the genre who have never played it, as well as non-gamers and the user experience in these cases is incredibly rough). 
[*][b]Lots to Remember[/b] - Knowing unit types and individual unit stats is important for competitive play and there are over 1000 of these in the game.
[*][b]Multiplayer Lobby[/b] - The multiplayer lobby design is poor, you can view players' stats before you begin a game so if you have a high win rate your opponents will likely immediately leave, and if you have a low win rate, your team mates will likely immediately leave. This can create situations where you have to wait 30-40 minutes to get past a game lobby (and this was when the player count was higher than it currently is).
[*][b]Progression[/b] - Probably only a problem for the most die-hard players, since there are hundreds of faction and deck type combinations to experiment with. Beyond this though, there isn't any meaningful progression to keep things interesting or fresh other than DLC drops.
[*][b]Feature Bloat[/b] - There are some features that aren't really necessary from my perspective, the effort spent on naval combat and having different time-period categories seems like time that could have been spent better elsewhere although I'm sure others would disagree. I'm also not a fan of the single player campaign but I realize others enjoy it.
[/list]

My #1 dream in life would be to re-create this game with a great tutorial, a progression system for your individual decks, and a persistent multiplayer campaign similar to Heroes & Generals or For Honor (seriously Eugen, drop me a line). This game is still fantastic in my opinion, but narrowly missed out on a lot of its potential!

The game is good for the military enthusiasts, I can only see the soldier model for a while, but also found some problems, the soldier model is some mistakes. For example,  in the French anti-tank group, which the data is clearly a submachine gun, as a result, the shooter with an assault rifle and the deputy shooter with a semi-automatic rifle. This is also the problem with ordinary French infantry. Hopefully developers can see that.

A lot of people say the AI cheats; I've never really noticed this and I imagine only people who turtle in their starting areas ever experience any challenge in this game. 95% of the time I get total/major victory in my games and I've never lost a battle in the campaigns. I think people are missing some of the intuition behind wargame and they're used to RTS games like C&C or Starcraft.

This game models 'real life' warfare fairly well (I don't have military experience but speaking out of things I've read, plus the game just feels 'realistic' given the scale of distances with respect to the units). So you need to get some intution behind how 'IRL' tactics work. 

I've tried to compile a bulleted list of basics that new players should understand:
-Units must be spread out (preferably, don't have more than two units per selection). Artillery and air strikes can punish clumped units

-Recon is mandatory!!! You cannot see jack shit without recon units and your units will be less accurate without them. One recon unit per ground unit 'block' is fine; turn off their weapons and keep them alive and behind your units

-Keep your non-infantry ground units on the edge of forests

-Tanks project power in open ground; mobilize them in a line spaced out so that they can support each other. 

-Infantry have two roles in this game: defend/contest urban areas and forests. Spread out infantry as much as possible in a town; tanks attacking your town without infantry support will seriously be in for a nasty nightmare. Likewise, when you attack towns, roll in with APCs/IFVs and unload - it's a deathwish to send tanks to take urban areas

-Anti-air is mandatory if the enemy has aircraft, especially helicopters, but keep in mind that these are not hard counters - enemy aircraft can still fight your AA, and your AA generally cover a small range. Spread them out and keep them forested if possible

-ATGMs counter tanks since they have much longer range, but they are generally not mobile (they can't fire on the move). Your infantry and ATGM carriers are defensive units that should be kept in towns (infantry) or forests and look over long distances of open ground

-Aircraft are so fucking powerful, as they are in war in real life ever since WW2. Use attack aircraft  / other CAS aircraft  to interdict enemy armor in open ground that are outside the range of your tanks. Fixed wing aircraft multiply the effectiveness of your forces. Helicopters are very supply-hungry, and if they catch units in open ground they will generally shred them. But they are vulnerable to machine-gun fire and especially autocannon AA. Manually order evac on your attack aircraft as soon as they run into AA or enemy superiority fighters

-Artillery are very situational and I rarely find myself using them. They force units to move and they stun units. They're good for putting pressure on a place where you know the enemy is hiding. Air strikes are generally far more effective than artillery, but you need to watch out for AA

I would say this game is 'total war for modern warfare' and it really shows how a combined arms force is vital in that every single tool at your disposal is needed in battlefield tactics. You can't just roll down the plains with tanks; they will be destroyed piecemeal by enemy air power. You can't roll tanks into a town without getting heavily bogged down by infantry armed with RPGs/ATGMs.

Wargame Red Dragon is a pretty classic JRPG styled game mixed with RTS made by Eugen Systems in which the power of friendship unites the western world to band together and fight the evil communists and finland. An interesting take on alternate history as seen by other games like valkyria chronicles and animes such as "Gate" and features similar time traveling story elements like how the finnish and yugoslavian arsenal consist primarily of fictional equipment they never actually had or come from outside the games timeline. The game also has an interesting story element that the developers forgot to include where the entirety of the world is fighting over Korea for reasons unknown, this will likely be elaborated on in the future in a stunning plot twist where Korea is secretly home to a rare natural resource that gives powerful abilities to its owner. This would explain why the armed forces of the entirety of Scandinavia, Netherlands, Finland, Eastern Bloc, and Israel are fighting so desperately over a theater they would otherwise not be involved with.
The setting has an interesting mix of realism and fantasy. Similar to how Cyrodiil in the elder scrolls used to be a jungle and was later transformed into a fertile european landscape, this game also has an interesting alternate take where the vegetation and climates of Korea and Japan have been transformed into a tropical paradise with rice paddies, palm trees, and stilt houses similar to what you would see in vietnam. At first glance you would assume this was the developers being ignorant and basing the art assets off pop culture and assume the entirety of asia looks like vietnam, when in reality this is played as a clever plot point which requires understanding of the extended lore of the universe. It's obvious upon further inspection that this is clever climate manipulation, after seeing the defeat of USA in vietnam, USSR tacticians indentified a crucial weakness in American soldiers, an inherent distaste of tropical enviroments. As such, redfor scientists installed several weather machines to transform Korea and Japan into tropical enviroments which explains the absoloutely horrendous performance of American infantry in game. 
The game has an interesting storyline told through patchnotes, currently we are in the "dark ages" era where a team of finnish refugees from the far future come to 1995 bringing with them countless amounts of fictional XA-185 variants armed with Bushmaster II autocannons for incredibly low prices. Will this be enough to change the tide of the war? or will their efforts be in vain? also featured in the dark ages is the complete abandonment from the developers leaving the game in an unbalanced state giving an immersive sense of hopelessness. There is an interesting sequel to this experience where our heroes travel back to 1944 to defeat the problem at its source by reaching berlin faster than the russians and crippling the spread of communism but its not as well recieved by the community.

I love the Wargame series and if you like realistic modern RTS's then so will you. Red Dragon is the most recent installment in the series, but I hope it won't be the last; The Developers Eugen seems to have done a fine job with Steel Division but I hope that they will come back and make a new Wargame soon. Personally, I am hoping for a Soviet invasion of England but, erm, where was I? Ah yes, the current game. 

So Red Dragon is set in Asia and follows a narrative where the Cold War was a bit hotter and the Warsaw Pact forces regularly fought against NATO. In Red Dragon the war has spilled out into the East Asian theatre and there are campaigns set in Korea, China, Japan and, to an extent, Siberia. The combat is tactical and unforgiving, with a rudimentary insight into tactics and strategy on behalf of the human player a must lest the computer overwhelms you from the beginning. Do not fear though because after only a hundred hours or so against the AI you will be professional enough to take your game online and have your arse handed to you by people from all around the world, willing to share not only their superior knowledge of modern weapons systems but also some truly fascinating insights into contemporary domestic and international politics. Ah the internet. Without you where would I get my daily dose of hate from?

It's a game with a steep learning curve in that the tutorial is a bit lack luster.  There are a number of good video on youtube and playing against the AI can help refine what you learn there.

That said, I'm going to tell you the bare bones basics to not being a complete handicap to your team should you just join right into the multiplayer.

First off, you need some variation of these units all the time.

A recon unit or two is not optional to be honest.  Always have one hidden in a tree line somewhere overlooking the battlefield.  If you can't see a unit, your units can't target it, even if you know it's there the best you can do is call for fire missions on the location you think they are at and hope you hit something because they forgot to move it.  They are not for combat.  If your recon are fighting something has gone wrong.  If you think their weapons will target something, turn them off.  If you think they'll be attacked, pull them back a little.

Infantry are extremely powerful when handled correctly.  You must keep them in cover at all times in combat and if anything outranges them then you'll need to pull them back to where they can't be spotted.  Remember that blinking units are hidden and infantry are really good at hiding.  It's generally always a good idea to have some infantry on hand but consider taking less if you face a lot of open terrian or few structures.  If you face large portions of forest or city sprawls they will decide the battle in those areas full stop.

AT comes in a variety of shapes and sizes (ATGM are generally the best but others do their job as well) but are usually critical in holding areas with little cover (like roads or fields) against vehicles.  These open spaces are harder to hold with infantry alone unless they are small like a road going through a forest as any vehicles that stumble upon the range of infantry are generally toast.

AA also comes in various shapes and sizes and more so than AT.  You will need a little variety here so mix some radar with some infared and some guns with some missle (guns are versatile and can fight ground and air usually but missles handle air better) Radar usually is better ranged and accuracy wise but can be countered hard by SEAD (kills radar based AA by following the radar signal back) and ECM (makes radar locks less stable/accurate).  Place them just behind your main units and keep them supplied with ammo as they run out quicker than you might expect.

Supply units sit behind your lines and resupply/fix stuff.  Turn off what you don't need to save supply for stuff you need.  Send them next to a FOB to refill their supply.

The rest are more conditional and have more complex mechanics but I'll let you figure them out as I have to go.

If steam had a "meh" recommendation, that's what this game would get.  Bullet point time for pros & cons:

[b]Pros[/b]:

- The game is smooth, it runs good, and it has it's good qualities.  Like C&C series without the construction.

-Most of the player chat is some of the dumbest shit I have ever seen.  Like Barrens chat, but a little more raunchy and very little substance.  This could just as easily be in the cons section if you expect helpful and straight answers if you ask questions, but generally don't ask in chat.  You'll most likely just get some fool trying to talk badass and never actually answer the question.

-Challenging is the basic name of the game.  It has an impressive learning curve.  

-Units are well defined and have their key applications in realistic fashion.  I find it is more fun to play with your "Deck" build in skirmish mode than it is to play the campaign.

[b]Cons[/b]:

-A logistical nightmare.  You can have a FOB, but it has limited supplies that does not replenish itself.  Fuel, ammo and parts are all pooled into one number, hence the logistiacal nightmare part.  You can toggle what gets delivered, but honestly it doesn't matter because every supply guy knows that it will all be equally needed.  What rubs me the wrong way about it is how the FOB doesn't replenish itself.  I mean, that is the purpose of a FOB (to be the distribution warehouse of the battlefield).  After a while, you're gonna have a bunch of 88Ms with nothing to do and a bunch of vehicles that can't shoot or move trying to hunt down the remenants of the opposition (Grunts FTW, although it takes forever).  I could understand a supplies on hand concept, but not a finite stockpile for the entire match, especially with total destruction as the win parameter if that's your thing like it is mine.

-(For singleplayer) The AI is too predictable, though that doesn't mean it's gonna be easy.  Once you have first contact it is gonna throw anything and everything it has that can fly and shoot at you all at once.  It's gonna be a quick burst of Anti-Aircraft, then it is gonna throw every piece of armor it has at you.  If you can survive the several waves, it will try to flank you with infantry while it pounds you with artillery. Then it's just a matter of going objective to objective that they hold and cleaning up whatever is left. Their recon will usually be and stay hidden at that point and it turns into a seek and destroy mission, if you have the fuel and ammo to keep your vehicles functional...

-Unit orders are pretty limited.  I couldn't figure out how to group different units, like M1A1 Abrams with M11P Abrams.  Or Abrams with Bradleys.  Not a huge deal, but I would rather be able to make preset battle groups with a single click than a click and drag that tends to select more than I want.  if you control click you will select all units of that type in that area, but you can't control click to quickly add another type to that selection, it will be either or.  Shift clicking single troops takes too long for this kind of RTS.

Really, those are the biggest cons I can think of that I experienced.   I'd recommend this game to someone who really likes RTS.  I'm sure with the right groups MP is awesome.  After reading the chat, there's a lot of them I don't wanna play with.  They might be good at the game, but they are better at painting themselves like idiots when they speak and that's not my cup o' tea.

400h gametime and played this game since the start of 2016, I'm here to inform you of the pros and cons of this unique game and hopefully drag you in as I myself am in the opinion that every wannabe Tactician (not strategist, they're a different breed) should play this game.   ... except if the cons looks too bad and overshadows the pros.

Pros:
1) Unique Strategy game "gameplay" = Unlike most RTS Strategy games, Wargame isn't about gathering resources on a certain part in the map and building factories to spend said resources to pump out units. Instead, before you would go into a match, you'd need to create a "Deck" of unit cards... kinda like YuGiOh except with Real life Military units. Once on the battlefield, you are assigned points depending on the game settings of the host and spend those points to deploy your "Units" from the Deck that you've made. Deck making is somewhat complex and won't be mentioned here. So after you deployed your units, you'd maneuvre them around the map and beat up your opponent on the field. Keep in mind that you do earn income to purchase more units overtime and it increases depending on the gamemode, or not at all.

2) Nice Graphics and Unit models = The map designs are clean enough and looks good enough, typical of your average everyday modern Strategy Game... but the real charm lies in the details of the ingame units... for the creators have faithfully stuck with the real designs of units as they are real life, all down to that tiny little hook and hose you see on that tiny tiny tank, indeed it would be there too in real life! and there are about like 500 units in the game so...

3) Diverse units and tactical layer = There are around 500 units in this game, each with their own categories and uses. And the thing is, almost every unit has their uses, from the cheap Militia to the deadly Special Forces; the deadly T-72 with upgrades to the lowly T-55; Don't let the prices fool you, no one will buy the most-expensive thing because they aren't "Cost-efficient", so you'll pretty much see every unit in the game thrown at you or used by you by the time you hit 200h gametime.

4) Well-paced game flow = Wargame Red Dragon is a quick RTS, it ain't slow as there is not wait time to purchase and train units then a lag before it spawns out of the Barracks or some mumbo jumbo. Once you place your units, SCRAM! issue those orders, get them rolling, you want to be the FIRST to the battlefield (If possible) as Sun Tzu once said, but I forgot his full quote... goes something like reaching there by noon and digging in or some ching chong. Anyways, the units aren't slow and sluggish either as the game speeds them up compared to their real life counterpart. The idea is that the battlefield you're in is actually raging on for hours instead of the 40m the game timer is set to.

5) No Microtransactions = Thats a Pros right? folks these days like to make a fuss about em

Cons
1) No good tutorial offered by the game itself = The game offers no decent tutorial so you'd need to learn from either others, guides, videos. Maybe this could be a pros since it forces the person to adapt, get creative and formulate his or her own playstyle along the way after absorbing many lessons as there really isn't a "1 way to win all games" playstyle.

2) An odd community = From my own experience you will encounter lots of people who will either keep silent or cuss at you the minute before the game begins. It get's worse by a cube root in team games and then multiplied by pie once a team starts winning and the other starts losing as they taunt the loser and the loser taunts the "weakest" player in their own team. Rarely is there any chivalry in the community, 1v1s are silent commanders facing each other and team games are "I did well but my teammates squandered my efforts so I abuse them" You rarely make friends here... but, there have been a few exceptions.

3) A community that are frightened easily = In most multiplayer game lobbies, it takes 3x longer than usual to finally start, the issue for this is that people always leave. Why do they always leave? because they checked the stats of their opponents and go "Oh, he's 30 levels higher than me and has an 80% winrate, I'm gonna lose so I'm gonna f**k off." I see this attitude everyday, complaining about "stacked" teams. Sure, they may be stacked but they might be friends and just want to play together, and neither are they stopping you from bringing a stack of friends. And if you're afraid of losing, how do you expect to learn? what will you gain? will you only play "Easy" games with people that are low in level and horrid winrate? This attitude needs to stop and people should just play the game regardless of the statistics of their opponents. So what if you lose? Atleast you learned something, you're marginally better than your previous self before the game started. Be happy and never Stat-check and leave, Commanders in real-life don't check their opponents stats too ya know.

4) Random unit debuffs = I get that in real life, plans never survive contact with the enemy, but can you be blamed when you're launching an assault and for some reason your most-expensive tank or Anti-Air vehicle gets "Detracked" or "Stuck in Mud" ? ... This is a rather bad feature in my opinion and should be removed. 

5) A small proffesional army = By this I mean a small playerbase. The game is rather... old, but gold! Nonetheless, this game really does not appeal to many RTS Gamers except oddballs like me I suppose

6) The Navy = As in real life, the Navy cannot win wars by itself. They merely support campaigns. It gets worst for the typical Napoleonic-era Admiral as Battleships really become obsolete compared to the Aircraft Carrier. Now to win Navy, you'd either bring submarines (nonexistent in Wargame) or Aircraft Carriers (Also Nonexistent) and have an Airwar but with Frigates at the bottom shooting. That's pretty much what Naval battles are like. The ships also turn oddly if you were to issue an order to turn 180 degrees. Gunboats do have a part to play too when providing coastal Fire support. If you're looking for large naval clashes, don't bother because they too won't happen in real life.

Neutrals (Can be good or bad depending on the individual)

1) Steep Learning Curve = This game is hard and requires skills, knowledge, and luck. You will lose a lot. So this means if you're a casual gamer, you're gonna eat dirt a lot. This is bad as well, hard game, hard life for you but good in a sense that you'd be facing dedicated players who are in to win and of high quality (somewhat).

2) Cold War Era = This game takes place at the end of the cold war (1990-ish) and a clash of ideologies occur. Either pick Vodka, Champagne or Rum

3) If it is your cup of tea, then I hope you won't mind spending hours of your life on it.

4) Warchat = In the main menu of the game when you first enter, you can chat with players around the globe to the left. This chat is rather hard to describe. It's a mixture of everything imaginable if the North Pole and South Pole were squished and launched into another dimension. There is everything there from Geopolitics, Holocaust Remembrance, Stalinium Production Protocols and How Mao Zedong invented coconuts. But don't worry, if you do ask a serious game-related question, you're going to be given a serious answer (From the answerer's point of view anyways)

5) The Battlefield goes East = In the previous game, it was in Europe. In Red Dragon, it's mostly in Asia. I hope you enjoy generic Asian house designs.

I give this game 9.5/10 and put em at my Top 5 Strategy Games riiiiight next to Supreme Commander. So I employ you to look at gameplay videos for an hour and if you think it's too much or "Lame" Well, off you go to your own life.

Massive improvement over Airland Battle, in nearly all aspects - from general gameplay like micro and macro management, to graphics and visuals. The new maps feature much more varied terrain than the previous game(s) and you'll need to think your tactics through with the specific terrain of each map in mind. The number of units nearly doubled, with new factions being added, and the existing factions getting some extra units, since the timeline has been extended to the mid '90s. The size of fielded forces in a deck has also increased, considering the somewhat larger maps and need to prepare for all types of confrontations (land, sea, air), or to further specialize with thematic decks (marine, motorized, airborne, etc.)

Best part, though is that you can play as Best Korea. 10/10 GOTY.

I have played this game a total of 134 hours, not much but okay Basically Wargame is one of those games where 134 hours is not enough, to really understand all the actions you should take, but enought to understand how to craft your deck, and get ready. Gameplay works by, you creating a type of deck of cards and utilizing them in the battlefield, each has a veterancy system that ties into how many you get, so you can get 1 Elite Leopard 2A5, or 2 Veteran Leopard 2a5s, but for lower end cars they go much higher like 5 Leopard 2a4s, each has a price for use in the middle of the game like the leopard 2A5 costs 170, while the 2A4 costs 135. Generally people will find something to dislike about each nation, due to all of them having a certain dificult to deal with unit, from airplanes to very heavy tanks, and even elite infantry. I greatly recommend this game, allot of fun with friends, even without friends the reddit community is quite welcoming. The navy aspect although is kind of lacking, most of the time whoever has the most ships, who are closest together to form aa nets, ends up winning. This game does take quite a bit to get into, about 100 hours you will feel overwhelmed, after that you will start to understand, and still do many mistakes, but in the end games are very fufilling, from victories to losses.

     Wargame Red Dragon is one of the best RTS games I've ever played with friends, allowing you to make your own combined arms "Deck" of military forces from around the globe to wage war on a massive scale! As a cooperative experience against the A.I, you will work as a team to outlast and outgun the enemy forces that you can personally tweak through their own seperate decks. This allows for near limitless types of battles you can wage! 

PROS: 

* Land, Air, and Sea Warfare at its finest in RTS form 
* compelling 'deck' crafting for unique gameplay experiences 
* a wonderful cooperative RTS game 
* vast selection of military factions and units from each to play
* I love the smell of napalm in the morning

CONS: 
* You need to learn EVERYTHING in this game on your own, no meaningful tutorials 
* The campaign scenarios will kick your butt until you actually learn how they are supposed to play 
(see above CON) 
* Have I forgotten to mention this game is not casual friendly? 

TLDR: 

Wargame: Red Dragon is a tough but rewarding RTS that is loaded down with fun factions and military vehicles to deploy into amazing firefight spectacles!
Has great qualities but ai may be missing the I in Ai. PVP though still works great. So Strategy Approved

Love this game too bad Eugen dropped the ball on the WW2 version I would have bought it.

The keys to having a good experience in my opinion are:
1. Try to play with people you have played with before. Teamwork is important especially recognizing where a push is happening and where a push needs to be made.
2. Stick with 4v4, 10v10's tend be either spam fest or a stacked team vs random players. (If you see mostly the same players on the same team in a 10v10 two or more games in a row avoid it.)
3. Play conquest where arty spam is not rewarded nearly as much and playing offensively is rewarded more. 
4. Medium income! This to me is the perfect balance of being able to purchase enough units without becoming too spammy. 
5. If your new you will most likely suck, but here is what you can do to avoid being flamed. 
Don't buy a bunch of arty unless your team has control of enough zones and ask what is needed where first. 
Don't buy arty at the start of the game.
Don't buy a bunch of planes at the start. 
Let you team know your new and ask where you should go and what units you should buy.
Always buy at least 2 units of ADA.
Recon infantry is your friend.

Very realistic in its approach to modern combat, Wargame: Red Dragon has never bored, even after over 400 hours of gameplay. 


Unlike other RTS games, Wargame has no base building, instead you call in units from a reserve pool, which is determined by your choices when you build your army or 'Deck'. Deck building is a great part of the game and one seldom seen in any other RTS. There are many different Deck types for each nation, allowing you to specialize in one particular type of unit or warfare with choices all along the way about trading off quality for quantity. This makes deck building a worthwhile task where striking the right balance for your playstyle is a rewarding exprience. 

Although I can't speak for singleplayer, the multiplayer of the game is also well thought out. The main mode is destruction, where the principle objective is to desroy a certain amount of enemy units. Some might think this is encouragement to camp, however the game gives an incentive to fight over the strategic territory because control zones dictate point income. The person who simply camps at his base will lose because his opponent will have many times his income and can simply overwhelm him with sheer numbers. This forces players to strike a balance and use units intelligently to gain the upper hand.

The only complaints I have with Red Dragon are some minor graphical glitches, very weak sound design in many areas, and the fact that some of the multiplayer community are not the friendliest to say the least, but this is not the game's fault.

But in conclusion, I think  Red Dragon is a worthy sucessor to Airland Battle. The maps are huge, and the unit and nation slection is unparalled. This mix allows for an insane amount of tactical diversity. One minute you could be ambushing vehicles in a mountain pass, and in another you could be fighting a fleet action. Combining this with well thought out multiplayer modes and great looking graphics and you have a recipe for one of the best RTS games out there. Although the steep learning curve may turn off some not willing to learn the game's intricacies, If you stick with it you will find that Wargame is a rewarding and satisfying experience. I only wish that Eugen will return to it after the failure of Steel Division and continue to add content to this fantastic game.

With almost 300 hours under my belt, I would like to give a little bit of buyer's advice. If this is your first experience with Wargame, it will look a bit scary but mostly amazing. So many units. So many catagories. When you make your first deck, you may feel happy inside... Then you get your butt kicked in your first AI match. Don't worry, this is going to happen. You will fall and the AI will kick you when you are down. Then you learn the AI's nuances and little tiny things the AI does wrong. And then you win your first match. You finally won your first match. Then you spot a little tab out of the corner of your eye. Multiplayer will be a worse learning curve than learning how to walk. But I suggest you keep grinding against the wall. And then you will finally start winning once in a while then start winning more frequently. There will be a lot of people who want to beat you down who are on your team. You will forget the basics from time to time. But it's all a part of Wargame.

Cons:
- You have to watch the game from a height that the units are sized of a pixel. Zooming in to the point that you see something visually pleasing from the units will make that view totally impractical. Not much fun.
- Reinforcements take ages to get to the front, there is no way that you can use them as a 'reaction' to the opponents tactics. Meaning that if you haven't placed the units that counter your opponents' units, it is almost certainly a loss for that battle.
- Controlling the game is not straightforward as in other RTS games. It is overcomplicated for no benefit.
- You have to deploy troops both on the strategic view and the combat view. Very odd behaviour.
- The game itself is not fun. This is my personal opinion, you can fan-boy-cry a river about it, but still I didn't find this game fun at all.
- Lastly the most important dealbreaker for me why I don't recommend this game is the totally misleading advert video shows action from close range that is totally impractical during the game, so you will rarely ever do it.

If you want to play a complicated RTS with a steep learning curve while Joseph Stalin and Mao argue in the chat about who was the best at making death camps while Hitler questions the sexual habits of their mothers this is a game for you.

I have always enjoyed strategy games and this one is certainly in my top 5's, likely #1 to be honest. 

WG feels like a cross between World in Conflict and Company of Heroes, and has one of the widest and most accurate military arsenals I've ever seen in a game. 
The scale can be daunting, and it's a game which is fairly easy to understand but very challenging to master. The challenge of micromanaging units can be almost panicky, and the tension as you try to reverse your panicked Challenger 2 tank out of range of a T-80A can be nerve wracking.

True strategy is a must, far removed from games like C&C where it can be a matter of massing 100 tanks and doing an attack move across the map. All units have strengths and weaknesses, and a strong tank charge can be slowed or even destroyed by a few well placed infantry and AT weapons. 
The need to monitor your supplies and unit resources can be frustrating at times, especially when your infantry run out of AT launchers during a pitched battle for a town, or helicopter gunships fire their precious missiles into the bloody ground because they lost sight of the enemy for .0001 seconds. However it's this need to monitor, adapt and strategise that makes Wargame a top notch RTS.

As for the multiplayer community, some might argue it's not the best, I haven't had any serious issues with it, in fact many players are friendly and helpful to newcomers, it's just a matter of asking. However team stacking is something of an issue. If possible I recommend playing against friends, or with them on team speak.

As I'm typing this, I have nearly 600 hours on this game and I'm finally almost sort of good at it.

Wargame is my first real RTS (Read: Not a 2D flash game) and in retrospect that may have been a terrible mistake, because this game will flat out annihilate you if you don't know what you're doing, which you probably won't because there's a LOT to know. In other words, if you're new to Wargame, expect to lose a few times.

The trailer was not joking when it said there were over oople-bajillion units in the game. Admittedly, a lot of them are similar or are reskins, but most of them have vastly different stats. For example, there's a cheap, baseline T-72 which is basically a hunk of garbage with tracks and a gun on it, that bursts into flames if the tank commander sneezes. Then there's the highly modernized T-72s that will rip other tanks apart from 2000 meters and shrug off rockets as it roars across the battlefield, powered by diesel, the screams of the innocent, and human souls. Now, you can easily check the stats of a unit in-game by pressing "i", but memorizing them to some extent is helpful. But that's not the point. The point is, if you don't know what you're up against, there's a good chance you're going to get absolutely destroyed.

Once you have a vague understanding of what each unit does sort of, you have to learn how to counter each type. It's kind of like rock paper scissors, except nothing completely beats anything and there's several ways to lose. For example, tank beats infantry unless the infantry are at short range or have an ATGM. Infantry beats anything at short range. Infantry that are good at killing other infantry, beat infantry. Artillery also beats infantry. Plane also beats infantry but not infantry with MANPADs. SAM beats plane, unless the SAM is radar and the plane is SEAD.  Plane beats SAM if the SAM is garbage but only if the plane is ground attack, in certain situations, maybe. Everything on the battlefield plays a different role and you have to find a way to make that role work for you in the grand scheme of things. Learning how to do that can be difficult.

Not only do you have to know what kills what and when and how, but you also need to know the gameplay mechanics too. For example, you need to understand how combat stress affects your units, and how to use that to your advantage by making your enemies scream and cry and soil themselves before you start actually seriously trying to kill them. You need to know how reconnaisance works so you can find your enemy in the first place so that you can actually kill them. You need to figure out how to resupply your units so they don't turn into 60 tonne paperweights, and how to keep your supply units safe so they don't turn into an expensive and tactically ineffective fireball.

Those are just basic gameplay mechanics too. That doesn't even scratch the surface of using tactics and mindgames to actually defeat your enemy.

Wargame will throw you for a loop. This is the only RTS I've really gotten into and my friends who I've suckered into playing it all agree that this is something else. It will take some time to get past the learning curve. No matter how many hours you sink into it, your tactics will keep changing, you'll keep trying different things, but you will never perfect your strategy because a perfect strategy does not exist. This game will challenge you to learn. It will challenge you to think. It will challenge you to adapt, and it will challenge you a lot. But once you start to overcome these challenges, it becomes extremely satisfying to finally win. To lay crushing defeat on your enemies. To know you came from knowing nothing to feeling like a master of warfare.

"War never changes." Is a quote thrown around often.  While philosophically it may not, strategically it sure as hell does.  Wargame: Red Dragon is a lesson in that.  Each multiplayer game contains lots of stress and nail biting maneuvers when player skill is balanced, but for the inexperienced it’s a dredge.  The learning curve is less of a curve, but more of a vertical line, when passed you can hold your own against another experienced player.  This is a target that I am still trying to hit, while I pride myself as a quick learner every map, every game, and every encounter is a mix between luck, recon, and unit composition, which I haven't quite nailed down yet.  A huge variety of units is at your discretion, from the absurd to the very practical, and all of them are worth giving a shot, provided that they are utilized properly.  The controls are simple and endlessly customizable.  The UI is a bit big by default but you can change the size to fit your preference in the options.  The game allows you to make everything just as you like it, which is great for someone who is moving from another game and wants their hot-keys to be the same or someone like me who wants less clutter on the screen.

The AI that you can fight is not a very good opponent, it makes stupid decisions but it's a great way to learn the controls, and test performance (which unless you play on a potato is great).  Take a quick run through a campaign that is intrigues to you and then try the multiplayer.  I also suggest sticking with the default decks, or if you are so inclined building your own, be warned every unit has a ton of info, and some aren't as good as the prices suggest, read each stat and use the compare button as needed, also check out the competition through the armory, it lets you see every vehicle you could ever want to know about or kill, also hover over icons if you don’t know what they mean, sometimes they have multiple definitions that change between units even if they look the same, they can also give hints to the role of the unit.  Alternately if you tire of the provided decks but don't trust your building skills, you can import them, all it requires is a simple copy and paste and there are great resources online.

This game is a wonderfully strategic, if you have the cash pick it up now with the Israel DLC, otherwise wait for a sale.  Any new players would be a great help in revitalizing the player base, and I can promise that this is the best realistic strategy game you can buy.  This game offers hours of endless–admittedly stressful–fun which I personally love, while games can run long, on a weekend it's a great way to break boredom.

A couple of quick tips:
RECON EVERYWHERE- there is no sense in charging blind

CHEAP UNITS FIRST- when advancing it makes no sense to put your valuable units first, let the replaceable stuff take the hit, it can save you from a bad advance

DO NOT FORCE UNFAVORABLE ENGAGMENTS- unless you’ve been forced back to your spawn there is no reason to keep throwing units at a wall, you can always retreat, reorganize, and then soften your enemy with artillery or airstrikes

IF YOU LIKE IT HIDDEN DISABLE ITS GUNS- if you want to keep a unit hidden in a forest or some other type of cover, make sure that their guns aren’t on, they stop being hidden when shooting, this is especially important for forward recon that doesn’t really have a need to fight, if you want it to fire just turn them back on.

COMMUNICATE- if you are doing an air heavy rollout tell your team, so that they don’t waste points on their own aircraft, or if you want to take a specific point, call it out, so that your allies can focus efforts elsewhere.

This has some good things about it. Single player is ok but really short for such a game. Multiplayer can be fun however in my experience the player base for this is just awful. Sportsmanship Nation Bashing, Racism, and really just a boatload of trolls more than usual are what you are likely to find. This can make learning the game a frustrating experience. In single player your aircraft bombs are not likely to wipe out an entire garrison of infantry in a town however in MP a bomb will wipe 40+ troops out in a single drop. It can be a challenging and fun game so I can't say it is all bad. It is also clearly biased in terms of units to make the European soldiers and equipment more favorable. Being that it is designed by a French developer   that it is to be expected.  For Instance the American Infantry in the game are mediocre in terms of accuracy and training compared to their French, and English Counterparts. While U.S Equipment is not invincable the lack of decent Infantry in the U.S Deck can be a major problem ingame if you choose a U.S Deck.  The Single Player campaigns are fun but in terms of replayability they don't offer much. Nation pack DLC for multiplayer often being offered for free is a bonus however they do not come with additional singleplayer campaigns to broaden the SP experience.

Again, not really any other games like this one, so recommended for that reason with reservation. 

Even on the easy AI (which on other RTS games gives you some space to breathe), the computer will swarm the map and take all the points. 

There are dozens of units named only by seven-digit numbers, each with specific roles to play. The game doesn't help you out with that. 

The tutorial is laughably non-existent, consisting of five pages of text. 

For the length of time necessary to get something out of this game, an equivalent effort with an actual tutorial and some help with what units do would be useful. 

I appreciate that the game is purposefully difficult, and that war is meant to be neither fair or easy. But the amount of time I think I'm expected to play on this just to make some workable combinations, and the lack of a beginner AI means that the game really requires a lot of investment to become fun. 

Read the positive reviews from those who are better than me at this game for what the game is like should you persevere.

This is an ultra-realistic wargame.  If you are looking for a Command and Conquer or Starcraft style game, this is not it. I used to think I was an amazing general, the second coming General Patton or Rommel. This game made me realize there is more to warfare than securing the most resources and pumping out the most troops. I’ve had an armada of tanks wiped out because I charged in without securing the high ground. I’ve had planes shot out of the sky because I underutilized my reconnaissance. To put it simply, if you fancy yourself a strategic mind, then buy this game. It will test your intelligence and common sense. This is the first and only game to really make me feel like a General.

Wargame Red Dragon is an amazing RTS game.
The singelplayer campaigns as well as the multiplayer offer a huge variety of experiences.
Be warned: This game is hard to learn if you never played any other RTS before.
It can take 5-20 hours alone until you can play the game "properly".
In your first game the AI will probably destroy you. Even on easy.
Once you beat the AI on hard and go into real games you will have to check opponents levels.
If they are more than 5 levels above you this game might not turn out as fun as you imagined.

This said its a great game to play alone or with friends in coop vs other palyers, 1v1s or even as teams of friends vs friends.

Tldr; Its hard to learn (watch bubblebox youtube tutorial series to save time), but worth it.

The game is a well made game. It's very pretty, battles can get very intense, and there are tactics you need to learn in order to survive in the game. The maps are well designed and the campaigns have believable stories behind them. The community also isn't as bad as communities in other games. There's a good deal of military and political talk in chat, but mostly it remains civil. All in all, it's a good game that has more good than bad, so I can recommend it. However, there are several things lacking...

- The economy for unit summoning is out of whack for the stated goal of ultra realism (Abrams, I'm looking at you). American and Soviet units cost the most to deploy on the battlefield, an attempt by the developers to not have the game dominated by those two armies. However, the time period WAS dominated by those two armies, and they had the capability to deploy their best units (M1A1 and A2 Abrams tanks, T90's, F-15's and 16's, MiG 29's) in vast quantities. This simply is not represented well in the game's battles. You can do better as North Korea than you can as the Soviet Union because of this. That being said, I've had some AWESOME battles where it's, say, Israel and France against China and North Korea.
- The AI is not programmed well. In fact, it's programmed like AI were programmed back in the early 2000's. It knows exactly where your units are down to the last soldier. As soon as you fire upon it, all your forces are immediately 'visible' to the AI, even if they wouldn't be to a player, and attacked overwhelmingly. The AI acts like a player using hacks to see all your units and give itself infinite resources. Harder difficulty levels don't mean more advanced algorithms are used. No, harder difficulty levels mean more buffs for resources and unit stats for the AI.
- There's no taking into account some of the superior technological strengths of either side. Units are balanced for a more arcadey feel. For example, NATO tanks have thermal optics that allowed them to see through smokescreens at the time represented in this game. However, because the Soviets did not have this tech, the tech is not represented in game.
- Aircraft performance is still completely idiotic. For example, the aircraft do not naturally try to evade a missile on their own when fired upon, as a real piloted aircraft would regardless of what orders you give. And ground attack fighters armed with specialized anti-tank weapons will abandon the battlefield too early (A-10, I'm looking at you). THey'll expend their missiles then break off and RTB without using their anti-tank gatling guns. And, going into anti-air, you will NOT see any dogfights. The jets do not go to engage each other and enter into spectacular dogfights. No, they fire their long range missiles, and once those are dry, they strafe at each other. Think ye olde knights in a jousting tournament.

Despite these flaws, it is a fun game, especially when you play it with friends, once you figure out how to actually succeed.

Okay. After 500+ hours of wargaming i've decide to write my opinion. Bear in mind Wargame Red Dragon isn't like classic RTS games we've known so far. It is more like Blitzkrieg style but with more immersion, freedom of pace, and visuals. 

Here are my in-depth gameplay review.

There is no Fog Of War. Use recon.
Planning your assault requires planning especially when recon unit is vulnerable to everything else. However, you your troops cannot survive an assault and ambush without recon. You use recon to detect hidden tanks, incoming aircraft, or to find enemy's artilerry. There are several type of recon. Each type has it's purpose realistically.

Tanks rolling enemy infantry in forest? No and don't do it.
Just like real modern battle scenario, tanks usually used in open field. Never ever a commander stupid enough to send tank into forest and urban areas thinking their tanks is some sort of god. Except the terrifying veteran superheavy when it wasn't flanked. Still can be killed. Use your ATGM plane.

Air support. No longer save from ground unit.
Unlike any other classic RTS. Wargame Red Dragon offered a lot of killing opportunity when using airstrike on your target. And unlike any other classic RTS also, aircraft and helo isn't a magic which keep spawning after every cooldown. A helicopter however are useful only in certain situation. You can helorush the infantry and tanks but not a bunch of anti-air support. Also, a single helo shouldn't do a flyby over a forest and urban in happy manners. 

Naval.
To me and several other players. Naval is actually a mistake made by Eugen. There aren't alot of tactical option in naval battle. Which make Total War series naval battle superior. Naval unit's pathing are also the most terrible i've seen.

Artillery and infantry.
These two units always have close relationship even in RTS like Company Of Heroes. Which is why you shouldn't exposed your infantry in the open field and to enemy recon. Or else they'll get raped. However, artillery smoke is my choice when commencing an assault to urban areas using infantry.

Multiplayer.
Here is a few tips. If you looking for large scale unfair batlle, try a server with 50000 points destruction and high income. If you are looking a realistic tactical gameplay, then a server with [Tact] title is for you. I've felt  overpopulated maps are less in entertaining and unproductive compared to low income and scarce in point maps. Be aware that some of player like to leave their keyboard after deployment. 
But in online multiplayer, whether in game or not, community are very cheerful and revolutionary. Warchat sometimes defeat the purpose of the game.

Pros
-Realistic rock-paper-scissor battle system compared to any other RTS.
-Excellent graphic and framerate.
-Lot of unit choices suited for several playstyles.
-Immersive sound.
-Decent background musics.
-Joyful (and hateful) online community.

Cons
-Naval battles are the terrible one.
-Too powerful artilery.
-Uninteresting single player campaign.
-AI were using mongols running towards player.
-Naval units are too powerful to be taken down by anti-naval ground missiles.
-No electronic warfare. Which make modern battles felt less creative.

I've played the whole wargame series yet this one doesn't really differ. Don't get me wrong, i'd play this version any day other than the previous ones, but its the same concept. This just has naval units and more stuff. There is one issue though that I'm having but no one else seems to have touched on it. People are saying the AI cheats, in my case I don't think so. I haven't legitametley lost a battle with an AI (I sometimes end the game halfway through to do something else thus its not really losing right?). But I have noticed that when AI is put on easy, it throws everything it has at you, whilst on very hard, it uses strategy but its quite easy to see what the AI will do next.

Not really sure how I feel about this game. It's good, but there are some issues with it (which may or may not have been fixed, I haven't played for a while TBH).

Pros:
-In depth strategy game which rewards good teamwork and mirco/macro skills.

-LOTS of units.

-Large scale battles.

-About as good as a Wargame simulator can get, and offers a huge amount of different ways to win and have fun.


Cons:
-Teams; players giving up the moment their good unit is killed, putting more pressure onto their teammates, which in turn causes them to get salty as their stuff gets murdered, often leading to them leaving which worsens things for everyone else. It can feel like a 50/50 chance of getting a toxic team or an alright team, which can mean that you can go literally days without seeing a team that doesn't arty your units for shits and giggles.

-A lot of hard counters. This is kinda a good and a bad thing, but it's in my con list mainly due to death stacks being impossible to counter if your losing (due to points decreasing as territories get taken off your team which decreases your options in terms of units). Get 2-3 players who know what their doing on the enemy team and you'll be stuck, often on your own as everyone 'conveniently' moves their stuff to the other side of the map, facing down endless waves of bombers, tanks and artillery as your units get utterly flattened. 

-The global chat. This is more a personal gripe than a problem with the game itself, but some of the stuff that got posted there during the time I played regularly was actually disgusting, and I had never seen those levels of hate in any game I had played up to that point.

I am going to redownload it sometime soon to see if anythings changed about it for the better, in which case I'll delete this review but my hopes are not particulary high.

Hope this review helped, and as always be somewhat critical of what a random internet gamer has to say. Look it up and decide for yourselves if it is worth it.
Cheers.

A complex and management-heavy RTS that suffers from some of the worst balance issues I've ever seen in the genre. Weapon ranges and strength are all over the place, and not one of them makes sense. A T54 (Soviet, 1954) outranged and one-shot my Abrams (American, 1992), and I haven't played since.

Like all the wargames before it, there is one hell of a learning curve. Units have more stats than many mainstream rpg games and the daunting level of units makes it an incredible game of trial by fire as you learn what units work, what don't, and when to use them. If you've already played Euro escalation and airland, then the only thing this game really brings to the table that is new naval units and naval battles. They are very hit or miss. Exclusive naval battles now are non existent because they frankly succckkkkeeeeddd. It bassically involved in NATO trying to spam ASW planes because they couldn't hold to the Soviet/redfor ships. However, bringing them into the fold when it comes to land battles actually makes for pretty intresting gameplay. Other than that though, the only new things are a ton of new countries, new units, new maps, and new campaigns. The campaigns are fun but are incredibly unsatisfactory. The best part is probably the new units and countries, as new comers like japan and china take the stage, and new units like the big baddie M1A2 abrams make an appearance. If you loved the previous ones, then I totally recommend this.
