tl;dr Wonerful little RTS with virtually infinite possibilities- would certainly recommend, but only to players who are willing to spend some time learning mechanics.
Wargame: Red Dragon is an awesome little realistic RTS that simulates war on a scale rarely seen in such a genre, spanning miles upon miles of territory. It forces one to use real logic and strategies to outfox and eliminate the enemy. For example, approaching the enemy without combined arms is a disaster waiting to happen- e.g tanks without AA will easily die to helos and planes, infantry without armoured support gets obliterated by tanks, etc. 
The game can be split into two parts- building 'decks', in which a player builds a force using 'cards' of various units, and actual combat. The battles, on the other hand, are (quite literally) bloody fantastic. Every small detail from the whistle of the Katyusha as a salvo of death gracefully flies across the map to the empty cartridges ejecting out of an infantryman's rifle is faithfully modeled, as Soviet-backed Warsaw Pact and allied countries engage in a massive showdown of epic proportions against NATO nations and their supporters in the beautifully depicted landscape of East Asia. A huge number of units from both sides feature, compelling the player to make several crucial decisions that could turn the tide of battle- whether it be to risk sending an unsupported force against what you hope is the last thing the enemy has, or to pin your hopes on a small squad of recon infantry to find and take out the enemy's command vehicle before they can call out more reinforcements. 
But something one can really appreciate about this game is the diversity of the units, allowing the player to send out more or less any kind of unit fielded during the era of the 80-90s- whether it be surplus WWII-era T-34/85 tanks supporting North Korean reservists armed with Chinese PPSh-41s, all the way to the cream-of-the-crop T-90 tank and elite troops armed with grenade launchers. This could lead to some interesting realistic strategies, such as sending out cheap 'meatshield' tanks to weaken enemy defenses and waste their ammunition, before deploying a proper, competent task force to finish 'em off. 
Of course, like any other RTS, the game suffers from a couple of balancing issues, such as a pathetically underpowered North Korean military (even though it's 1980) and a rather controversial DLC pack, but otherwise most nations are similarly competent against eachother. Usual issues such as kiting isn't very common, since ranges are very strictly controlled (e.g all tanks in the same class have the same engagement range) but issues such as the infamous "helo spam" (self-explanatory, some jackass sends a ton of Hinds your way, can (sometimes) be dealt with by spamming your own AA but unrealistic and not very fun nonetheless) remain. Also worthy of note is the extremely shortened engagement distance in this game- the longest ranged tanks in the game have a maximum range of 2.275km. 
However, the game really isn't new-player friendly. The community is your best bet for learning this game- the "tutorials" in W:RD are among the worst I've seen, simply being pure text about how to use the menu and introducing the naval units, with nothing actually explaining how to fight! Thankfully, an AI skirmish mode featuring some of the most incompetent AI I've ever seen exists, so that can be used as a stepping stone. Many guides exist on the Steam and Eugen forums about how to actually play, along with many excellent videos one can find on YouTube. 
Overall, in conclusion, this game is great albeit slightly flawed, but it's a perfect fit for RTS fans and military enthusiasts of the Cold War. Granted however, it's quite difficult and frustrating- but playing it properly will reward you with hours upon hours of fun. Oh, and one last thing-
Expect most of those hours to be in menus.

Do you like real-time strategy? Do you like the close-combat series? Do you like massive and near-scale battlefields? A game that can handle 1v1 as well as 10v10? Fantastic RTS.

There is quite a learning curve with these Wargames but once you get an understanding of them, they are great games. I've played RTS games all my life and this one was probably one of the hardest to learn just based on how they use their mechanics and the sheer amount of stats for each unit as well as the unit diversity. It's just a lot of info to process before you can really dive in, but once you do, its hard to put down. 

When you enter a match (non campaign), you use a unit deck, kind of a deck building process. You have access to every unit in the game to add to your deck, and each deck is generally the same size. You can modify the size of the deck with modifiers such as only using units made prior to 1980, which will allow you to take a few extra units. Or you can choose to only use Sweedish units which will give you bonuses to using those units. Overall its a very nice way to let players customize their armies.

The actual gameplay is fun too. After the initial learning curve, the gameplay is pretty straightforward as RTS goes. Move recon ahead, locate enemies, and blow them up. Units in this game are fairly vulnerable at all times and it only takes one mistake and a few seconds to lose 4 main battle tanks sometimes so patience in this game is a must. Graphics are on point as well. Adding in the naval aspect to this game was great too.

Overall this is a fantastic RTS series that you can solo or play with friends for hours and hours. My friends and I have each made about 4 to 5 different army decks to play with to keep things fresh. Buy with confidence.

Where to begin on this game? I suppose the best place is in the middle, it is fairly well balanced and extremely well detailed. Combat is intense, fast paced and decisive at times, than at others battles can grind on with neither side gaining momentum. Here you will take command of large armies, your strategy will largely be your own as few people play alike. What ever your play style, the tools of your enemies destruction lay at your finger tips. Now, this game does have its draw backs but depends largely on the person as the learning curve is steep and likely to deter the less determinded or those daughted by swift defeat. However if you can handle getting your ass kicked for your first few dozen matches as you figure out how things are supposed to work you will find no peer in the RTS community in my opinion, you may find newer but I doubt you will honestly find better. To be fair, the community is relatively small due in large part to the fact that the game is fairly obscure compared to many more iconic titles, those that do play are often fairly helpful while not happily crushing you and your allies. In short, if you enjoy easy, and casual gameplay you may find this is not your thing. If, however you find yourself up for the challenge, be prepared to be humbled as your perfect your command skills.

This is hands-down the finest RTS ever made.  The level of detail and sheer complexity (and associated learning curve) are unmatched.  Other reviews cover this well though so I won't elaborate on this.

After playing 700+ games (on a different Steam account), I must say though that it suffers from a horribly fatal flaw -- you can see the statistics of other players in the lobbies.  Why is this a problem?  Team stacking.  It's horrendous -- I might have played one game in ten that was balanced.  With all the others, the "smart" players (myself included), click around to see which team is better, then go to that team.  And the cycle repeats until you get a team of noobs against a team with 5000+ games of experience between them.  This leads to other problems.  It can sometimes take 30+ minutes to fill a lobby, as skilled players join the team destined to lose, realize it, and quit.  Or they linger hoping a spot on the to-win team opens up, then quit en masse right before the game starts.  Or anonymous lobby hosts will kick newer players and people they aren't buddies with off of the stacked team.

If Eugen simply removed this option -- the ability to see the win ratios and game counts of other players -- this game would be very near perfect.

I love this game. It so much fun to command an entire battlefield. The community is generally very nice. Wargame Chat is full of trolls and radicals. The multiplayer is deffinitely not for those who just started the game. I am still not the greatest at the game but I am gradually getting better and better with more skirmishes I play. The campaigns can be very fun and each time you play through it, it will be different. The units that you choose to use can be very wide ranging and you can choose how to go about taking a sector. The skirmish battles are fun even when you are alone. I would reccomend this game if you do not mind a lot of micromanagement. There is less micro than games like Hearts of Iron but more than games like Company of Heroes because your units can run out of ammo, fuel, and need repairs. 

Overall I would give this game a solid 9/10.

Very little changed from the first game so I'll copy my review (the only reason I bought this version is because the multiplayer had a higher population):

Fun tactical game of modern warfare, with just enough realism to be enjoyable while still being more of a game than a simulator.

One option of score keeping makes your soldiers's lives valuable so that zerg rushes lead to defeat, not victory. You have to attack the enemy where he is weak and without suiciding your units, like in civilized countries in real life.

I applied lessons learned from modern war veterans to great success. Noobs get steam rolled, veterans are dueled in the realm of psychology (feints, bait and trapping, counter-attacking).

Unfortunately the interface is trash, memorized key commands a necessity and air defense requires micro-management, so it's not the perfect game, but still fun occasionally.

Turn off ambient noise or whatever it's called, otherwise it will drive you crazy and you'll still hear it hours after shutting off the game.

Wargame: Red Dragon is a cool rts game that is set in the 80s to 90s, basically it has that "Cold war" feel. It is definely the most advanced rts game i have played (however i have not played some well know rts games so someone might disagree with this). There is a lot to learn when starting the game and many strategies to beat your enemies. 
Game has a campaign, all of them are fictional conflicts. I won´t spoil them for you. Then there is the skirmish, where you can practice against AI and then there is multiplayer.

Do not forget about the Wargame chat, the place where you can find highly educated political opinions about current events in the world, memes and helpful advice with computer problems.

I would love to recommend this game but I can't. The game itself is a lot of fun. Very punishing and rewarding play or you can soften it up a bit by having more points. The units are INCREDIBLY varied and I am still seeing new strategies tried. There is a very steep learning curve for this game and to be good you need a lot of micro. 

The reason I can't recommend this game is due to the community that surrounds it. There is no moderation in the wargame chat and there is no punishment for team killing. Team killing a command vehicle can sway an entire battle and there is nothing stopping it from happenning. To report someone you have to have a copy of the replay and create an account in the forums but it doesn't do anything. 

One particular player literally had a change.org to get him removed from the game. That's how bad it is. I literally can't even post the chat here because it's too explicit and racist. I can't play a match without constantly moving my command vehicles because I'm worried for friendly fire from my team. I would return the game if I could. 

Oh, and single player is fun for about ten minutes so you HAVE to play with the community. 

Do not buy this game and if you do then do NOT play with John Brownwood.

 There is no active playable tutorial, just read some vague sentences and then go give it a try.  For a game this complicated, that is a huge mistake.

Once you get past that, figuring out what unit is useful where, or how to get it to deploy what you want, is a mess.  Unless you've studied actual real world military units, there is no way to make sense of the letter soup you get on the deployment.

Have you ever wondered, what it would be like to command a "Huge" army in quasi-realistic strategy game that tries to make the war balanced and fun experience ? 

Then this game is for you. 

Obviously you can find some flaws in this game like the fact, that T55 can destroy M1A2 or M60 can destroy T90 or the missing features on merkava tanks, or the unrealistic ranges on all the weapons and guns for sake of balancing russian shitty equipment or mabye fact, that TOW missile won't annihilate any russian tank etc. 

In the end it does't matter since there are MODS on WG:RD forum, which turns this game into fun/realistic experience for everyone who is found of realism and authenticity. 

Base game is good. 

Modded game can be exellent.

There is very little feedback as to why you lost a particular match, or why one unit was spotted while another was not. The inner workings of the game are not explained, besides a cookie-cutter description for some of the visible characteristics, so one does not know how far a poor visibility unit see, nor a excellent one. You just know that one is better than the other in some capacity(range? seeing in bushes?). It's all archaic when it doesn't need to be. 

Navy is basically worthless, and the general blob-spam strategy is all too common. Airplanes disappear when withdrawing rendering all hits, no matter how close the rocket was to the plane, void.

In the 93h I apparently have on this game I don't think I had a single one of honest fun. In the matches I played either: I stomped, or I got stomped, or it was an hour long artillery duel Donbass style.

This is probably the funnest and most in depth RTS I've played in a long time. I truly wish they made more games like these. It kind of reminds me of World In Conflict but much more detailed and much more challening. This is one of those games that you will suck at, even after 261 hours I can still get whooped online. But when your strategy works and you deploy your troops just right theres no better feeling. Do buy!

I originally got the game for the campaign, but upon realising it was in the Airland battle style (not scripted storyline) I decided to try out the multiplayer. My biggest complaint would probably be the campaign not being the original European Escalation style. Other than that, watch out for noob stompers and you'll be fine.

This game took a while for me not to suck at it. 
Key lesson: If you don't utilise the advantages of each unit, they will die quickly and you will lose. 

In a nutshell: This is a real time tactical game with over HUNDREDS of real world units to choose from. It is the perfect sandbox to employ modern millitary doctrine with said units to kill the enemy. The way you would build a British Army is different to how you would build a USSR army. How you use soviet infantry is differnt to how you would use US marines. Soviet helicopters are different to the US helicopters. The key to this game is building a deck that is optimal for your tactics, and understanding your units pros/cons.
 
If you are unsure the nature of this game - watch some pro replays and see how the macro/micro mechanics of this RTS works. It is quite unique. TO ease into it I recommend playing some solo skirmishes before playing some 4v4 online battles.

One of the most satisfying games to learn to play, with a competative multiplayer community. As an RTS fan, this is one of the deepest games out there that has captured my attention. 

If you are looking to get into some deep strategy with a steep learning curve: Red dragon will reward you.

>restart, lose, restart, lose
>Exit game

>Learn game mechanics
>Watch 400+ hours of tutorials

>Load Busan Pocket
>ready to go
>Use 50000 airstrikes
>Whole divisions fall before the mighty f-86 Sabre
>EZ 4 Ence
>Head to MP
>Make deck after doing research
>test deck EZ win
>head to 2v2 game
>Rekt by helo rush
>triggered

Wargame is an RTS series about a cold war going hot. With about 2000 units, it can be hard to learn how to play, yet is very interesting to use these units to their strengths. Also, the game developers frequently patch the game for free, as well as add nations as DLCs every now and then. Finally, in multiplayer, there are games with 10 players against 10 players, as well as smaller games. Just a tip, if you are a new player, you should probably play the Soviet Union, or USSR, as it is much easier the learn how to play with, with a unit for every job.And always remember to bring AA, helicopters and tanks are extremely common and very dangerous.

Wargame: Red Dragon is the culmination of 20+ years of RTS legacy at its purest form.  Cover, veterancy, supply, fog of war, unit limits, force specialization, etc... and the best thing about it is that these are all real world units.  

The graphics are amazing.  The choices of countries to play as are phenomenal.  What other games let you play as China, Finland, Israel, North Korea, or even Canada?  Yes, even Canada.  I mean the game obviously takes place before Trudeau, but that is still a testament to including even the most irrelevant for the sake of enjoyment.

Also, that public chat is very sophisticated and geopolitical.  You may find yourself getting lost nights watching Russians chant Putin over and over or hearing your local, domestic Navy washout rant about the F-35 being a false flag attack on the war again tooth decay.  Sometimes I go to turn the television off while I'm watching NCIS and instead realize I've been chatting on wargame.  Wow.

I only discovered the Wargame franchise this week due to the sale.  I can't believe this one slipped under my radar.  

I'd say of all the RTS games I've played over the last few decades, the one this is closest to is World in Conflict.  However, there are way more units, and the high level campaign is really well done.  It's like a game of chess, even more so than in any Total War game I've played, since you don't have an economy / research you can lean on to stack the odds in your favor.  It's all about how you set up the board.  You can recruit new units, but there are only one of each type in the end that can be used on the map.  The name "Wargame" isn't just a cool sounding title; it's very, very apt.  

The simplified rock, paper, scissors approach of traditional RTS (i.e. calvary beat archers who beat infantry who beat calvary) is greatly enhanced by the variety of real-world units.  You'd need a lost more nouns than rock, paper and scissors to make that metaphor apply here.  This game is very well done.

A couple very minor gripes, mostly with lack of documentation on gameplay mechanics:
1) the manual doesn't explain a whole lot.  I can't figure out of there's a way to issue complex movement commands (waypoints) like you can in every other RTS game.  Maybe shift right click works, but there's no clear indicator.
2) What does R&R do?  Does that give you more command units?  I think there was a pop up somewhere that migth have told me, but I can't find that online, and it's not in the manual.
3) How precisely does Line of Sight Work?  How far from the edge of the woods does you scout need to be?  Do you need to zoom into the scout to see what it sees?  Does it matter which direction it faces?  I frequently find my scout units fail to find targets I would think they should see.

I really really really love this game, like, alot. When I saw this game was on sale i bought the pack for me and two friends at a grand total nearing 50 bucks, a total fucking steal honestly.
I had seen this game before on youtube and i knew it was something that id love to play. when i installed it and loaded it up the first thing i noticed was that the tutorials are more like simple manuals than anything, infact im really happy i had airland battle because that game comes with a playable tutorial, that showed me many of the basics, afterwards i spent several hours on youtube learning about all sorts of different stuff in the game like tactics, unit types, how to build a decent deck, etc etc.

Once I thought i had the basic idea of deck making down i made an american deck and went into a 1v1 against the AI and got my ass whooped, i revised this deck several times and have since made dozens of decks for america, with just as many for other nations as well.


This brings me to the AI, it is extremely frustrating and seems to carry the same issues with it that the previous games had. it seems to have limitless points and it will always know where your units are. if youve got an ambush set up with whatever unit type, when the enemy arrives, if ever, it will also happen to bring with it what it needs to fuck your shit. In other cases they have a large attack elsewhere that forces you to redirect your forces and right when you do that, they come rolling through the now lightly guarded flank you just moved forces from. another thing i noticed is that its either to easy or to hard, medium and easy bots i can steam role so much so that it normally ends in a 15 minute man hunt with every single unit i can muster searching the whole map in one large net that covers everything, however if i play agaisnt a hard bot my units are always out numbered out preformed and destroyed with ease.


When i got this series i also bought it for two friends, we hopped into airland battle first and had fun playing the defense game mode and the multiplayer campaign, both of which i was heart brokento see didnt return to red dragon, which is fine, because the 3 it has are fun to play regardless, just kina sucks i cant play those great modes in this new game.


The first issue i ran into in this game was deciding what units to use and what nations i should play as. i eventually settled on maining the US and brits and making specialized decks for pretty much every occasion, and decks that covered more than one specialtty and were more generalized. this game has way to many units for me to even begin to memorize honestly, i look at youtubers or listen to players who can identify a vehicle just off of its fire rate, mobility, or its black outline. each of the larger nations have its own one of a kind units, while smaller nations not only use some of their own, but have a large slew  of tech from other nations, one of the most common examples are leopard tanks. some nations even get really old units from WW2 and that makes for some fun custom games with friends or against bots. each of the large nations has its own specialty, with the US your airforce is unmatched and for the UK you have some of the most powerful armor in game. while the game doesnt showcase exact armor values, speeds, or preformances of vehicles, it gives you an accurate representation in values much easier to understand. rather than saying that tank A has this much armor at this angle and this ATGM can pen this much at this angle it will say tank a has 12 armor at the front and this ATGM can pen 20. same thing carries over to planes with their values. there is honestly so much when it comes to units its very overwhelming to many players.


one of the biggest issues this game has is the spam of one unit type, it can either ruin your forces because its a shit idea or ruin your enemies fun because its fucking cheap. something that bothers me heavily is jet spam or heli spam, the first half is more true for american forces while the second half more so for russians. with the jets they comletely fucking ruin your ground forces and your AA normally cant kill them, or tank all of them out. when it comes to heli spam youll have tanks or infantry roling into a city or jungle and out of nowhere there are dozens of rocket choppers ruining your forces before the enemy sends in its ground forces to slaughter any of the remaining stunned units, and to be fair this is a legit tactic, but  9 times out of 10 your AA cant handle such a large task and will get killed by the choppers. the same can be true for arty, something any nation can spam, but with that you can actually pinpoin the enemies location so generally they either have to move after a volley or two or risk getting killed by counter arty or some kind of plane or heli.
another thing is the spam of cheap as dirt units, 60 jacksons, hellcats,chaffees,T3485s, or any other out dated unit costing 10 to 15 points they are often wasteful and its great when your enemy does it but infuriating when your ally does it, now there is nothing wrogn with sending these units onto the exposed flank of heavier armo to take them out or sending them against APCs and such, but spamming 60 or so and rushing the enemy with SU76s is fucking stupid.


the community itself is very much alive in this game, and is, interesting to say the least, you can meet some great people playing this game  but ill say this, enter warchat at your own risk.



all in all this game is excellent, and the issues i listed really get overshadowed by the pros. this game is a super in depth and fun to play RTS i seriously suggest it for any hardcore gamer who likes these kind of games and really wants a challenge.

Wargame Red Dragon, a game that can make RTS fags to cum, i can't think of any RTS game that uses the same theme as the wargame series (The Cold War), most RTS tends to take Medieval theme, the Civil War theme, WW2 theme & even Futuristic theme

The game also tries it's best into balancing units and depicting the real life counterpart's stats, and not many RTS games has this, even the so called "Realistic" ones (Men Of war series), unfortunately it still uses an HP system for the units, but that's only natural considering that making realistic damage models & system would mean that the game needs more higher specs to play, which is not really that great since i am on a Low-end Macbook 

Pros :
+ A fuck ton of playable nations
+ A fuck ton of deployable units
+ Different nations varies in tactics and special units and they're still taken from real life
+ A large variety of multiplayer maps
+ Multiplayer matches are hosted everyday by players and dedicated servers alike
+ Affordable Price (The summer sale Discount makes it really cheap)
+ Outstanding unit control and user interface 
+ Active developer that adds more playable nations (even if that you'll have to pay extra for it, the developer knows what

'Wargame: Red Dragon' created by Eugen Systems for their game series titled 'Wargame' is a real-time strategy game where the player commands a military unit that comprises of everything from logisitic assests to naval assests. The game or more correctly the entire 'Wargame' series has the player either play as a country or coalition from NATO or the Warsaw Pact, as the game takes place during the Cold War era. Specifically for this release of the 'Wargame' series the developers have you be in East Asia, focusing mainly on the relations NATO and the Warsaw Pact through the Korean Peninsula. 

In the several months that I had played 'Wargame: Red Dragon', I found that the game has an amazing assortion of different units from both sides and from many countries, inside that assortion were tanks like the Centurion to the M1A2 and infantry equipment ranging the early L1A1 to the modern C7. 

Playing the game I also found that it has your brain working and improving overtime, this is the case because the game expecially in multiplayer where you're pitched against expierenced strategists, has you thinking critically on where you would or could be moving your assests you, where could that enemy mortar be, what would the enemy throw at me this time. Like these questions I have just said even if they sound vague to you right now is something that has you seriously thinking and probably in-game could possibly have you panic depending on the situation. This is an even more accurate statement as even though there are a few assortion of maps that people actually play, the maps themselves could even if you have a superior force could have you play yourself, everything from difficult terrain to forests, strange terrain angles and small towns, perfect for an ambush or an artillery bombardment or aerial strike.

However playing the game, I have found that the naval assests no matter how amazing that sounds like, is utterly bland there is variation of naval units strangly from 9-12 different nations on the NATO side and there is also no variation of units from the 6 nations of the Warsaw PACT side. In addition to that I have also found that the ships on the PACt side are utterly overpowered, you would find it impossible to kill their ships compared to those on NATO. 

Nonetheless, I find that 'Wargame: Red Dragon' is a highly enjoyable game especially once you actually put yourself into it. It has it's flaws but overall a really good build and on a side note if the developers of the game actually read reviews from the community "FIX THE NAVAL AND ADD MORE NAVAL". Overall I rate the game out of 10 a 7.5.

Pra quem curte um jogo de estratégia "de verdade", esse game é sensacional. Quem nunca jogou difícilmente vai conseguir fazer alguma coisa na primeira partida, aconselho a ler o manual ou ver umas gameplays. É nesse jogo que quem não conhece nada sobre o universo militar aprende alguma coisa. O jogo é muito fiel à realidade, tornando-o um jogo leal, onde realmente vence o que tiver a melhor estratégia. O jogo oferece salas multplayer com capacidade para 20 jogadores, cada um controlando seus exércitos, batalhas massivas, dignas de um filme. É um jogo sem frescura, cru e complexo, isso é estratégia de Homi de verdade, deixe o MOBA para os pré adolescentes. Aqui não tem magia, não tem runa, não tem poha nenhuma. Tem muita infantaria, Anti Aérea, blindados, morteiros e artilharia esmagando qualquer um que tenta ficar entre o objetivo e o comando. Se você tem tendências socialistas, gosta dos comunas, vai adorar jogar com os vermelhos (Rússia,China,Coréia do Norte, ETC) já se vc é um soldado da grande extrema direita, discípulo do Bolsonaro, vc vai adorar jogar com a Bluefor  ou OTAN (EUA,Reino Unido,Alemanha,etc). Aposto que depois de aprender a jogar vc terá a sua unidade preferida, a minha é o Challenger 2, um tanque britânico muito foda e bonito, uma pena ser muito caro, no campo de batalha é um alvo chamativo, tem que usar com sabedoria.

I'm not generally a big RTS player, but this game has such depth (and a steep learning curve) that it has sucked me in. Great fun to plan out and build decks around a strategy or style of play you have in mind. I much prefer this style of game, in which you call in and deploy units, to the type of RTS games where you have to build and manage a base. 

If you're on the fence about it, there's no question that you should pick it up next time it goes on a $10 sale-- that is an absolute steal. I'm also glad I picked up the DLC nations as they are all fun to play and tinker with.

This is my first RTS purchased on Steam and it's certainly going to be my last because no RTS compares to Wargame: Red Dragon in terms of depth, eye candy, difficulty, realism and entertainment!

I don't even need to entail why. Look gameplay footage of this game. Now compare that to spamming bunch of units of one type in a tight cluster attacking another set of units in a tight cluster with a 5 inch distance between the two groups like you see in other RTS's. Case closed.

If you're a scrub-weakling like me then I hope you have a lot of patience and love for the game element because this game is ABSOLUTELY ruthless and you really have to dig across the internet to get every bit of knowledge needed just to figure out what to do. Then comes execution and I find this game challenges your micromanaging abilities but not so much that it's Starcraft AZN APM or die level. It's just that you need both to do well.

I still recommend this game to beginners because there are valid alternatives via doing comp stomps (You and rl people versus the AI), Single-Player Skirmish Mode or just simply finding a weaker player than you. Just note that you should pursue 1v1's instead because 10v10's diminish your ability to influence games. Plus, all RTS's are a pain to learn so really seeking easier RTS to get gud at will still leave you feeling frustrated, especially since this is the BEST RTS ever in terms of realism, graphics and gameplay YET YOU DON'T OWN IT because you're still playing Battle of Toontow...err I mean RA 3.

Expert RTS'ers should buy this because I'm obviously qualified to tell you so. Really though, I'm not a expert RTS'er so I'm in the dark about everything.

Watching replays is quite a satori though. Especially if you're a beginner and you win you first match and it's well executed.

Also qualifies as a educational game. Good for the children to teach or just those who like learning new things about real life military equipment and outfits.

Community is toxic. Much worse than the World of Tanks community from my experience.

Tl:Dr: Best RTS ever with the same hard af learning curve. Good for beginners because all RTS'es are hard to learn either way and might as well pick up a S tier RTS. Extreme challenge with extreme rewards.

330 hours played. RTS at its best. 

The good:

This is the most detailed, tactical RTS you've ever played. It is quite well balanced even for multiplayer, with no single team holding advantages that can't be counteracted by other teams. The community is generally pretty good. You do occasionally find people surrendering too early in multiplayer games, especially 10v10, but if you're playing 10v10 you're not taking advantage of how tactical the game can be. 

Micro is somewhat important but not to the same degree as in other RTS - tactics is at least as important. The wide variety of nations and coalitions to play and the variety of units within them will see you not get bored. 

This game rewards attention to detail, well-planed logistics, knowledge of each army and general tactics, and dedication bordering on study. 

The multiplayer community is still active several years after release. 

The bad:

There is a steep learning curve to this game. It is likely more complex than other RTS you have played before. There is no build queue so preserving your units, accomplishing actual objectives and getting your logistics right will be unfamiliar to someone coming from other games. However, you can download other people's decks (army composition), watch replays online and there are extensive beginner and advanced guides out there. 

Buy this game. You will come to judge all other RTS by it.

Never in my life have I sucked so bad playing a game with a difficulty of "EASY".

The Good:
Wargame Red Dragon provides a unique RTS experience that is plenty challenging, and frequently rewarding. The playable units are beautifully detailed, in both form and function. I loved learning the difference between semi-active and f&f air-to-air missiles, and the paint jobs on the Leopard-2 models look phenomenal. Players who value detail and authenticity will be in for a real treat. Each individual unit has its own set of statistics and abilities that a good Commander should be well familiar with. What level of optics are your recon infantry equipped with? What is the dispersion rating of your long-range artillery? How much armor penetration can you get with your anti-tank guided missiles? Are your APCs amphibious? Are your surface-to-air missiles radar-guided? What's the turning radius for the F-15 Eagle? Do your main battle tanks have enough top armor to withstand enemy artillery bombardment? What may seem like an overwhelming array of available choices to a novice player is actually a true tacticians dream. There are a dizzying number of play styles, but it's up to you to make your tactic successful.

The Bad:
The learning curve. Everyone complains about it, and rightfully so. With each new Steam Sale comes an army of new players who insist on throwing units at the enemy, Starcraft style. The instant gratification type players typically choose the most expensive units to feed the other team, and it's not uncommon to see fighter jets casually sailing over the enemy lines, only to be effortlessly swatted out of the sky by enemy AA. Worse, is that after the novice player has squandered all of the state-of-the-art units in his arsenal, he will promptly quit, leaving teammates to pick up the slack for the rest of the battle. Since the game has no form of quit penalty, this behavior often goes uncorrected.

The Ugly:
To this day, the game is punctuated by occasional bugs and crashes that the developers do not seem to have any intention of fixing. Units get caught on bridges, planes will clump up inside each other so they are destroyed by a single missile, sometimes selecting multiple units also selects a random unit on the other side of the map. And a match can be ruined at any time by a single team killer. Bomber aircraft can drop bombs on friendly units, but there is no way to target that bomber in response. Vote kick? Report player? Nope. The game has nothing of the sort. Players must visit the developer's official forum site and post a complaint. So instead of fixing glitches, and adding critical game features, the developers seem content with rolling out a new DLC every now and then, to rake in more money. I bought 0 of them.

Conclusion:
In spite of these shortcomings, I'm glad to say that I own and still play this game. I can't believe how much I've learned about battle tactics and modern war from the detail offered here. If you have more patience than a twelve-year-old, go ahead and pick this up the next Steam Sale. Be patient, have good Recon, take smart positions, and read the unit stats! See you on the battlefield.

On my third review, this is still mostly a negative experience. Which is a shame because this game has so much potential to be a GREAT game, rather than a mediocore experience.

Let me keep it simple:

-Small attempts have been made to balancing, but frankly it needs a complete overhaul, especially with Infantry and Prototype units (more so with DLC nations)
-Power difference between Nations and Coalitions is shockingly poor.

-Navy is officially dead.

-Terrible gaming community full of pros and new players, leading to extremely one sided games.(great game tho to play if you have a group of friends to play locally).

-Pointless Cat C and B decks/theme. Dont expect a Cold War game, this is now effecetive a fictional game of Cold War going into the mid 2000s.

-Poor single player experience.

If they fix these issues, this could be one of the best strategy games in my two decades of gaming. It could be up there in e-gaming with Starcraft, Company of Heroes.

For a single player experience, I highly recommend World in Conflict which has a fantastic campaign. The multiplayer is good too, but I think given its age, its probably a empty scene.

This game has a very steep learning curve but is well worth the time investment.

I would recommend that you start by watching youtube videos of the mechanics because of the lack of a good tutorial involved with this game.  The next step would be to play some skirmish against the AI to get a feel of the game.  From there you should probably venture into 4v4 or 10v10 games.  I personally don't like 10v10 games as they are nothing but arty spam fest.  As for game mode, Conquest is my personal favorite.

As for the community, this is where the game needs help.  The main game chat hub is not moderated at all and is filled with nonsense.  It really needs to be cleaned up but it is what it is right now.  The other problem is that finding good, balanced games can be tough sometimes.

The developer for the most part is really good, I just have a slight problem with the recent DLC Nation Packs.  My problem with them is that they feel more fleshed out then the OG Nations of the game and I would like to see these Nations balanced against the new Nations of the game.  Overall though, they do a good job keeping things fairly balanced.  I do wish that the series would have stayed in the European Theatre.

Lastly, I really wish that this game was looked at for competitive gaming.  It has all the tools to get there, just needs a couple things.  The first thing is to clean up the community and get rid of the cancer.  Secondly we would need a few maps that offered a balanced match, so maps that mirrored each other on each side.

Steep learning curve. I would suggest playing your first round with a friend and going over the workings of the game before you do anything serious. That being said, it's a great game with hopefully more fun DLC on the way.

Wargame is a gateway drug. It's like weed. You may think it's bad, may think it looks bad from its difficulty, or just don't like it anyways. But all your cool friends say it's great and you should try it. So, you being curious, you decide to try it to fit in more with your friends. Turns out that it's better - [i]much[/i] better than you expected it to be, and you want more. You say you'll only do it once a month, but that turns into once a week, which turns into once a day, which develops into an addictive death trap. Even if you're a newbie to it you still do it since it's so damn [i]addictive.[/i]

You do it more. Do it alone. Do it with friends. Do it with strangers. You can never stop; saying "5 more minutes" soon turns into 5 more hours. Once you get the hang of it, you start experimenting more with other things - things that will make your little gateway drug of a Wargame look like a vitamin gummy. Your friend shows you one such thing. It's some strange pill in an orange bottle called "Israel DLC" that's supposedly way better than the Wargame you've been smoking. Pretty soon you've devolved into some froze vegetative zombie state like someone dependent on Opium. You start taking risks, challenging other people, and, worst of all, you cheat. You troll. The warchat - previously the area where all the other junkies like you gathered, has self-destructed into a hotspot of hatred and vice. Your whole personality has changed  just by taking that one choice - something that'll haunt you for the rest of your life. And even if you quit, it'll still haunt you forever.

Take my word for it. I was a Wargame addict for some time - I quit a while back, and I've limited the toxicity coming into my system. I still do it, even if it's wrong, because it feels so right. Every waking hour on this planet I'm thinking of Wargame. It is my only love, and my only life. Nothing can change that. Even as I write this review, I can still hear the voices of my troops, calling out my name for their next objective. I still see rows and rows of tanks on the roads to certain doom, just so that they can satisfy me. And- oh god.. The artillery. The MRLS... The apaches... All those units, all those points gone in an instant, for what? Fame? Bragging rights? Money?

I'm going to have to leave now. My army calls me. I leave you with this message: Don't be like me. Don't be the guy sitting on his ass writing reviews for a video game for humorous effect. Don't overdose so much on Wargame. Go outside and ride a bike or something. 

I'm Gucci Gilgamesh, and I approve this message.
Great game, wonderful design...... xenophobic, anti-Semitic, and anti-homosexual community. Pretty much turn chat off unless you really want to talk to the alt right.

I have played WarGame before from the start of AirLand battle and a fan of RTS games. 

Positives:

- Great RTS gameplay.
- Very nice balance between realistic battles and action packed battles. 
- Runs well.
- Supportive Community, constant updates in terms of free/paid DLC's. 
- Good map scale.

Negatives:

- Graphics are starting to fall behind with leading RTS games.
- I would suggest in-game VOIP for better teamwork as this game heavily relies on teamwork in MP. 

Specs:

CPU: i7 4790K OC 4.4 GHz
GPU: GTX 1070
RAM: 8GB DDR3 2133 Mhz
Installed on SSD.

You have a bit of homework to do as there are tons of unit types. The multiplayer is a great way to get more knowledge of the game and test different army composites. Join the 20 player games though, it is a bit more forgiving. Still I have no clue what every weapon does. It's a great strategy game worth playing. 

I've also added one of the nation packs, still not sure if it was worth it. It unlocks one nation in the game.
